I really like the fresh chips that came with the salsa.  The carne asada tacos are pretty good, and I enjoy the small, diced nature of the meat.  FYI, it comes with onions and cilantro, which this muchacho is ok with. The al pastor tacos are ok.

My friend once ordered a ridiculous torta that came with (in order of importance) - steak, bacon, ham, and hot dog.  Well, that's how I would rank them in order of importance.  He says it was pretty good, so I'll have to take his word for it.

So, to wrap up, when you have that regular craving of a torta filled with steak, bacon, ham, and hot dog, get at me cause I got a recommendation for you.  I'll have to try the nachos everyone raves about someday. 

Plus, it's BYOB!

I came here and ordered 3 tongue taco dinner. The tongue had no flavor, no taste. It was like I was eating just the tortilla. My friend had the steak tacos which were better. If you come here, stay away from the tongue tacos.

What do you do when you and your kids are hungry and craving tacos at 10pm!?! You call this place! We were wanting tacos and most places that were open were either over priced or didn't sell individual tacos. My little ones can't eat a whole platter by themselves. So I used my trusty Yelp app and found this place. Open until 2am, and serving individual tacos at a reasonable price. I honestly didn't expect much but boy was I surprised. First we paid $15 for 6 tacos, an order of rice and beans and a large horchata. I decided to take a bite of the chicken taco first and it was the most seasoned soft chicken taco I'd had ever eaten. The green salsa was also delicious! I really loved that they put in carrots and jalapeños in vinagre. Those were equally amazing. I have every intention of coming here on a regular basis. ;)

This is a neighborhood joint that is convenient because it's open late. I've eaten here several times and the experience has been alright.

Except for the time I found a piece of hair in my steak torta. I showed it to the waitress and she didn't see it. I kept on pointing to it and she just gave up and she would get me a new one. 

I don't think it was an entirely FRESH new one, but I couldn't find anything else in my food.

Been going to Taqueria San Jose for many years and really have no complaints.  It's pretty good food, at decent prices.  My go to meal here are the tortas.  They haven't let me down yet.  The tacos are ok, nothing to write home about.  On my most recent trip, I tried their sopes and I really really liked them..they may have to be added to the heavy rotation list - I had a Sope de Papa (mashed potatoes) and a Sope de Picadillo (ground beef) - the sope itself was crispy yet soft - this is key.  I have an issue with restaurants that serve rock hard sopes - not good at all.  These, were very yummy.  The mashed potatoes were seasoned nicely - also key.  Some places that make mashed potato dishes serve them with too little spices, these were nicely spiced - with a nice kick!  The picadillo was your typical picadillo - pretty good.  Both piled with beans, guacamole, sour cream, lettuce, tomato and sprinkled with cheese...  damn, now I'm hungry and no where near Taqueria San Jose.

Credit card minimums yes, but I remember for years when they didn't accept cards at all and THAT was more of a pain in the rear, so the fact that they take them at all is a step up in my book.

Underwhelming atmosphere, so definitely not 5 star dining, but for my purposes, a can't miss casual Mexican BYOB restaurant in the heart of Bridgeport.

Excellent mexican food, was starving after the White Sox opener went here and ate like a king, I had the steak taco dinner which came with brown rice and beans, my two drinking partners both got steak burritos, which they didn't complain about at all..will be back again...drunk I'm sure leaving a White Sox game.

Customer service is the best that's why I gave the stars, my husband loved the steak super nacho, but my chicken taco salad was not good at all. I absolutely hate shredded chicken with bell peppers as an entree, meal just becomes soggy with broth. Yuck! The servers are the best though;)
The chips served during table service are legit. Fresh, tasty, and the salsa is on point as well. Really loved the tacos, reliably tasty food. And super cheap. No complaints at all.

I wish I could give t
his place 10 stars. The mother & the daughter of this place are super sweet. Tacos are bomb! They are quick, cheap & filling.

I ordered through GrubHub two days in a row and I promise it was like night and day!!!! I ordered the Shrimp and Garlic and Guacomole the first day and the shrimp was flavorful and had plenty of sauteed onions, garlic, and peppers. DELICIOUS! The guacomole was creamy and had lots of flavor. However, on the second order of the same entree, there was no sign of onions, garlic, or bell peppers in the shrimp although it was flavored. The real disappointment was the guacamole. There was SOOOO much onion that you would have thought I had ordered onion dip with a side of avocado and there absolutely no flavor. There must be two different chefs so I have to catch the right chef or I won't be ordering again. I really enjoyed my first experience but the second prder really soured my overall experience.
Good food and friendly service
Love It!!! They have great customer service, friendly delivery guys, and all around great Mexican food. There are not many words except, Try it, you'll love it!!

Great place for delicious and inexpensive Mexican! They are open late, it's BYOB the staff is very cool and pleasant and always helpful.  With tacos you get a choice of onions and cilantro, or tomatoes and lettuce,  and they come with complimentary carrots and 2 kinds of hot sauces, the verde is my favorite!  The meat that I've had (chicken, steak and pork) has always been tender juicy nicely seasoned and none of the nasty fatty chewy parts that sometime find their way into your 2am tacos at other joints. Maybe I've just been lucky, but then I'm really lucky because I've found myself here a lot in last five years!  Great smoothies too!

I do not like the fact that I've had to ask for water and chips and salsa because the server was negligent. I love jalapeños and carrots but unfortunately they serve soft, less fresh ones here. I really dislike the chicken tacos- the meat did not have much flavor. It's always annoying having to wave down the server because my table was my checked on. I gave it 2 stars because I like that they offer fresh juice on the menu, and I also like its 24 hours and BYOB
Cheap eats; huge portions. It will take you a week to finish the super nachos.
This is a good p lace to go if you are drunk and want to get drunker because you can byob here.  Have had much better Mexican Food .  It is always way to hot in there also.

I usually just get the carne asada burrito. It's good and filling. 

When I'm in the mood for Mexican and something quick....this is usually where we go. 

I see people talking about the chicken tacos. I'm going to have to try it out next time.
Ordered Huevos Ranchoes, it was great!
If you are looking for some cheap Delicious Mexican food than look further. The portions are huge, the food is cooked just right and the staff is quite nice.
Little pricey I think and did non not have updated menu
Tacos, guacamole and tortilla chips are amazing.  Love the lemonade!  You can not go wrong if your looking for great tacos; chicken and beef

Simple Mexican goodness. Steak nachos have been a favorite for years. Al Pastor tacos are my newest addition to an order. Take out is quick & easy and ladies working are awesome & friendly. Now take debit/credit over $15.

Thank God for TSJ! 

I was one starvin' Marvin last night after a festive yelp event and stellar planetarium after hours party... get it? Stellar? PS- I'm totally retelling this joke in my planetarium review so don't get sick of it yet. 

First off, I have to give it up to Carol K, who has once again saved me from going hungry with her knowledge of the Bridgeport area and all around impeccable taste. Thanks, Carol- forever and always! 

The bf and I go in and it's just us, the super cute girl behind the counter, and the cook who's eating his dinner. We sit down and the girl, who is also the server promptly comes to bring us water, spicy delicious carrots, peppers, and onions, and takes our order. Now, we were both hungry so between the 2 of us we got 4 tacos and 2 burritos... and I have no regrets about consuming this most unhealthy meal. I finished every scrumptious calorie on my wax paper and in my aluminum foil and I'm happier man, er, woman because of it. The veggie food was good and I'll defo be back but I would have liked some cilantro or other yumminess on my veggie tacos like the meat ones my bf ordered had. Sadly, my veggie ones just had shredded lettuce, wah, wah. At least next time (which will be very soon) I'll know to ask if I can sub lettuce for cilantro and gives this place the 5 star bump. 

Ooh... and if you're in need of a good pairing to go with TSJ, I would recommend starting the night out at Bernice's Tavern across the street, getting good and schwasted, then stumbling over to TSJ to refuel. 5 star night, guaranteed.

Wow.  At first I wasn't going to write a review because I see so man but you know, I think it's always good to give your won experiences because you never know if someone is ordering exactly what you ordered, how you ordered it...  So here's my experience.  

The Guacamole was very good.  The chips very fresh and the salsa and sauces were very good.  

The last two times I went there, I first had a chicken burrito with everything but cheese...and then asked them to add onions and cilantro to the burrito.  They did so  and I truly enjoyed.  

The last time I went, I had the chicken taco dinner.  I ordered with tomato, lettuce, onions, cheese and cilantro on flour tortillas.  It was very yummy.  The rice was tasty and the beans were yummy too.  

Simple, good and delicious food.  I can't wait to go back!

I love Taqueria San Jose. As a college student, this is definitive as the neighborhood grease spoon that's open late. The four of us go in and share the nachos supreme (I'm not sure if this is the name exactly) and it is a giant plate. Delicious, unhealthy, and basically cheese, beans, carne asada (choose your meat, I recommend the steak though!) on top of their homemade tortilla chips. I love their salsas that they keep in easy squeeze bottles on the table. The horchata is plentiful and vey reasonably priced. I've had the torta, which was only okay.

Wow, i was just let down by Yelp.  Perhaps they need a way to distinguish between late night drunken reviews and day reviews, because Taqueria San Jose was marginally average at best.  I can think of dozens of better taco shops all over the city as well, so i was really disappointed after seeing the 4 star rating and then eating here.

Ok, best thing about the meal was the gigantic fresh orange juice I had.  I love fresh OJ, and they had a juicer up front.  Good stuff.  

Second best thing about the meal, the chips and salsa.  The chips were freshly made and their red and green salsa's were both fairly tasty.

ANd the owrst thing about the meal was the tacos.  If you can't make good tacos, i don't care how good anything else is, you can't call yourself a #1 Taqueria.  I had the Lengua, Carne Asada, Chille Relleno and Trippa tacos (one of each).  I didn't want to drown out the flavors, when i was ordering, so i went with the onion and cilantro topping instead of the mounds of cream, avocado and cheese that the neighboring table had gotten.  This was my mistake clearly, because those tacos needed drowning.

Lengua - was a thin slice of tongue laid out on the taco.  It had no flavoring and was completely devoid of taste.  I had to check that it had not fallen out of the taco after my first bite.  It hadn't, it was just tasteless.

Carne Asada - Tiny chunks of fried steak, that were greasy and unappealing.

Chille Relleno - The cheese definietly helped this taco out, becuase it was the best of the bunch.  It didn't really work as a taco though.  I like Chille Rellenos, but apparently not on a taco.  

Trippe - They fried the tripe and it tasted like dirty leather.  Yes, i know where the stuff comes from in the body, but that is no excuse.  I doused this sucker in lime juice and salsa and i still had to spit it out.

This meal was a total waste of calories.  I knew i should have gone for a hot dog at 35th St dogs instead...

Carne Asada - greasy small chuinks of steak
DELICIOUS food at reasonable prices, clean bathrooms even at late night/prime bar time, open late and a pretty and clean restaurant. What more could you want in a late night restaurant?

Can I really love a Burrito joint?  I guess I can cuz I'm crazy about this place.

The carne asada burrito is huge, delicious and exactly what I needed to fill my tummy the other night.  We just popped in for some take out but the place was clean (even the bathroom was spotless and had one of those padded toilet seats that always make me laugh!), the prices reasonable and the the food?  The real star of the night.

A friend has been raving about this place for some time.  Now I finally get what he's been saying.  Open late.  Open early.  Check it out.

I ordered delivery.took a little while cause driver got lost but staff was very sweet. Food was very traditional mexican. Was great and glad I gave them a try.chicken flautas were perfect.beans a little salty but very creamy.u get pickled mexican veggies with each order as well.
Outstanding authentic food and service. Veronica and the rest of the staff were very gracious to our party of 5. Highly recommend.
Service was fine, very friendly and prompt, but their tacos are ok. I've had much better tacos from the back of a grocery store, but it wasn't bad, mediocre at best.

In the midst of running errands with my sister, I was craving mexican food. Some place close to home and a friend referral, I parked my car in front of this restaurant.

I didn't know what to expect but said it was good.
My sister ordered a steak burrito and regular size horchata.
I ordered 2 steak tacos and a breaded steak torta with a reg size horchata.

When we got home, my sister was confused at what she ordered. We paid for a reg size, but it looked like a king! Unless that is the reg size. haha.

I forgot to order onions and cilantro with my tacos and got lettuce and tomatoes. Horchata is very flavorful, and instead of breaded steak torta, i got the regular steak torta. Although the order was wrong, it was still good! They gave me both green and red salsa.

Now.. I would like to go back and dine there for the free chips and salsa. Great places exist in my neighborhood and gas is getting expensive.. Guess where I'll be going next?

just moved near the area with my beau and thought we'd check out San Jose... I'd been there once before with a mexican so you'd think if mexicans go there it must be legit.

I don't remember it being as gross as it was going with my beau... but then again I hadn't been living in Pilsen yet, the mecca of authentic mexican food in Chicago.... and I didn't know then that that mexican I went with was half white either.

my beau eats almost 100% of the time camarones a la diabla whenever he sees it on a mexican menu... regardless if the mexican restaurant has a pop music centric jukebox or is showcasing "COPS" on their flat screen tvs.

let me just tell you.... never eat any seafood at a place that plays "COPS" or "AMERICA'S DUMBEST CRIMINALS" during an evening dinner at full volume. If you must the burrito suizo is a safe haven... 

and my polish/italian mother makes better guacamole... let it be known my mother is the type that thinks guacamole is  spanish for simply "mashed up avocados in a bowl"

annndd I'm pretty sure I witnessed a single mom putting horchata in her babies bottle.

Cheap and yummy. Steak Burrito was a bit greasy from the meat, but tasted great. I also got some tacos..lettuce, onion, cilantro and meat. Just how I like it! About $1.60 each? (I forgot). Friendly staff

HUGE portions, especially for the price.  I ordered the carne asada burrito with cheese and my boyfriend got the nachos.  We both had crazy amounts of leftovers and left the place uncomfortably full.  

BYOB is pretty awesome.  But honestly, their horchata was better than the beer we brought.  I almost got some to bring home with me so I could have it the next day with my leftovers.

Also, great service.

Ordered for delivery and they got our address wrong. It came 45 mins later total (we live 5 blocks away & could've gotten it ourselves).  We ordered burritos (carne asada), basically we were eating a cold, soggy burrito. But the portion was good for the price we paid for.

I've definitely experienced better.  Decent place in the hood to get a taco and cheap.  The service is under-whelming and they were watching "Fast & the Furious 5" in the dining room.  The opening scene has a fecal explosion in a bathroom.  Not too appetizing when you are about to fork down re-fried beans.

This place isn't awful.

But things are spicy when they shouldn't be. And the corn tortillas seem chewier than usual. And the Jamaica could be wayyy better. And the steak quesadilla is horrifying - it was 90% grease. And one time they brought us chips without us asking and then charged us for them - not cool.

Basically, Erendira (which is right down the street) is much better. La Mexicana on 35th is better too, though not as good as Erendira.

(But hey, thanks for being open until 4am.)
LOVE IT! This place is cheap and delicious. The service is great and the portions are GIGANTIC!! If you like inexpensive Mexican cuisine, I cannot recommend this place highly enough.

DoIt is what it is, a grea late night Mexican food restaurant. You can sit down and relax. The staff is amazing. They are friendly and patient with every drunken fool that walks through their door.

BYOB too!

Yesterday was just BAD.
Like a Friday the 13th - minus Jason (thank God)
Let's say it was more like a sit-com remake of the movie. Less drama, more triviality.

My dry eyes need extra medication, nobody was available to have lunch with me, I was totally unable to focus on my work, my dog was just intoxicating me (furrealz, dude...) and I was out of milk for my cereal.

Still bad enough, right?

So I decided at night after a killer workout orchestrated by the maniac JM that some tacos al pastor were in order.

Carbs+pork+a touch of sweetness+hot sauce = bliss
Equation proved accurate times and times again.

Taqueria San Jose does the job just right. A tacos dinner will cost you around $7 and will satisfy even the most irritated "mujer al borde de un ataque de nervios" (that's me, Almodovar style). Onions, cilantro, juicy and flavorful meat, slightly charred, warm tortillas, beans, rice, salad.
Green and red salsa come on the table in squeeze-me bottles.

Careful though:
- the tortilla chips are super greasy
- the TV program is quite unstable on a sports night and keep changing from baseball (White Sox) to basketball (Bulls) to baseball (Cubs) according to the customers' wishes.
Disturbing, but not enough to stop me in my recovery dinner.

Good place to refuel. Far enough from everything else for me to show up in sports gear, still sweaty from my intensive session of kickboxing.
Please don't ewww. You would do the same.

Big, big fan.  Get bombed at the Sox game, then go here.  

Carne asada or al pastor burritos are among the best I've had in the city.  They're just the right size, whereas burritos are often obnoxiously big.  Great prices, never crowded, and the tubs of pickled jalapenos and carrots have the cure for the daily blues.  

Sentimental points as I stopped here the night the Sox won the World Series.

This was our last full stop on our gastronomic tour of Chi-City and booooy were we winning. We started with the butcher's daily cheese plate (blue cheese), sausage plate (which came with a blood sausage and two milder meats), frose and a mimosa. We could've stopped there and been over the moon...but we didn't, of course. 

I had the biscuit sandwich -- holy shitake -- that little sandwich was packed with serious flavor. It came with breakfast potatoes that were equally delicious. I really recommend this spot -- especially to sit outside on a beautiful fall Saturday afternoon for brunch.

Review is based on the Dinner Menu. I'm probably the only one who was willing to review this place that hated it. For the past 5 years, my partner at work has done nothing, but rant and rave about this place and how amazing it is. I mean he literally could be their employee because he speaks of it so much. Being that he is a food loving guru who should host his own show at times, my other coworker and I decided to try it out and see why it is that this man rants and raves about this place. Needless to say we are still pondering the answer to that as tonight I can assure was my first and last time at this location. Allow me to begin with what we ordered:

Appetizer: 
Squash- this was pure heaven and the only thing on the menu I'd like to think we would order this again.

Dinner:

1/2 Farm Chicken- it fell off the bone which was nice. It came with fries that were well cooked and crispy. While they praise themselves on everything being grown local, the fries tasted like something out of a frozen bag. I just had to wonder, was grown local, frozen local, and was the packaging just as local?

Pork Belly- we ordered this because they don't serve the glazed bacon during dinner hours, only brunch, and let me tell you what a mistake this was. The Pork Belly was nothing but fat and dry meat. More fat than meat though and the size was nuts for the price! We wondered how this little thing was supposed to feed two people? Maybe if we wanted to eat the fat it would. We were definitely not impressed with this one. 

Country Rib- this was far from a rib! It was extremely undercooked and was impossible to cut. The flavor was more on the sweet side and it was so chewy that I felt like I was chewing gum. In the end my friend and I decided that my two boxer mixes would enjoy eating this more than we would as they would be able to handle it. I'm sorry, but the moment it becomes better for my dogs than me, it's a MAJOR problem. They like princes, but I'm the only one who get to eat like a Queen. 

Dessert: 

Waffle with a Cheesecake Napoleon ice cream- we enjoyed the waffle a lot as it was just the right texture. As for the ice cream, they make it themselves, and I tasted no cheesecake in it. Definitely not impressed with the ice cream. Waffle yes, ice cream no. 

Bavarian- we both loved the Bavarian. It was the perfect texture and the perfect dessert. It shared the same texture as a mousse and was simply lovely. 

Drink:
Lemonade- When you think of lemonade you think of sweet. This is not the case here, this lemonade is carbonated water and has real lemon it which made it so sour. I drank it even though I hated it because it was $3. No refills, not saying that I would have done it would they have offered them anyways or did they? I was to afraid to ask. 

Atmosphere: 

The restaurant was loud, had us screaming across the table, and listening into others conversations. It was nearly impossible for us to talk to each other. Think of a high school cafeteria with kids screaming and loud music trying to hide their screams. That's what eating here was like. Not only this, but I deal with Chronic back pain and the chairs were beyond uncomfortable. It was like sitting on the ground. I actually had to take an additional pain killer because the pain was that bad. If the food was better the pain would have been worth it, but it wasn't. 

Not only were we unimpressed, but we are still trying to wrap our heads around the fact that the bill was so high when the food tasted so low. Definitely not on my places to eat for dinner again, but hey maybe we caught them on a bad night.

I will say though that I would be willing to try this for breakfast and lunch as the photos look delicious, but dinner is a no go for me.

OMG, this was maybe the best meal I've had this year. I came here for an event/honey summit (for work) and they had arranged a private meal.

We started with a charcuterie board, and beer and wine, and went on to an avocado salad, sea bass filet, country ribs, and peach and nectarine cobbler. Each course was divine. I even tried the sea bass although I generally don't eat fish, and that was good too.

The country ribs and the tempura cauliflower with honey were by far my favorite. The cauliflower tasted like candy and I could NOT stop eating it. The ribs were so tender and also very delicious.

I'd like to come back here when next in Chicago just to browse the store too, they seemed to have a good selection of meats and cheeses.

Cute brunch place. Seating wasn't difficult to find on Saturday morning. The hostess and waiter were both very friendly and accommodating. Charcuterie was tasty with chef's choice of meats. Quiche was some of the fluffiest I've ever had in my life. Definitely would order that next time. Super awesome hash browns - so crisp on the outside, so creamy on the inside.

Wonderful complement to the Publican next door. Coolest thing about this place is probably the bathroom setup: down the stairs, and kind of near a huge kitchen. Neat.

Stopped here for brunch with my family. Lots of cool variations on brunch items with some interesting sandwiches and salads thrown in for good measure. I had a wagyu brisket sandwich, but the slice of blueberry/blackberry pie was heaven. That puff pastry tho ... Wonderful place to eat outside and enjoy a Chicago summer. Pro tip: park on Lake!

Fulton Market District is one of Chicago's hottest dining neighborhoods. This area was previously known as a meatpacking and warehouse district, but has recently been transformed into a neighborhood full of some of Chicago's best eateries. Two of those being The Publican and its counterpart, Publican Quality Meats.

Deciding between The Publican and Publican Quality Meats is a matter of preference. Location is not an issue as both are located across the street from one another. The prior is just a restaurant, while the latter functions as a butcher, sandwich and specialty foods shop that also offers brunch on the weekends.

If you are looking for a more low key dining experience, I would recommend Publican Quality Meats. The X factor of dining here is that there is an al fresco dining area which is great on a warm and sunny day.

Last month, I visited this spot to enjoy brunch on my birthday. Got a spot at one of the outside tables. The brunch menu changes every weekend, but there are many items that seem to be regular items on it. You can find this menu on the restaurant's website.

Ordered one of the special weekend brunch items, the pork dirty rice ($12) and bottomless Intelligentsia coffee ($2.50). The pork dirty rice seem interesting as it isn't something that you would find typically on a Seattle brunch menu. Don't even know what kind of cuisine this is though it seemed Latin American or Cajun/Creole to me.

Whatever cuisine it was, I really like the dish. Primarily because of the pork shoulder which was tender and reminiscent of baked ham. The dirty rice was lukewarm, but the flavor was there. Maybe that is just how it is intended to be served. As for the coffee, it was as expected good since it is Intelligentsia. The service was great as they refilled my cup a couple times during my meal.

If you enjoy meat products and sandwiches, I would recommend checking out this spot. Brunch here is good on the weekends too, particularly if you can score an outside table.

Being a fan of the Publican, I came here for a Sunday brunch to start my business trip week ... and what a great way.  I saw this place last time I was in Chicago and thought it was quaint when I walked by it to the Publican.  Little did I realize that it has some of the best brunch and baked goods I've had in a long time.  Couple this with friendly and personable service and non stop refills on great coffee... oh my god, why didn't I do this the last time in Chicago!

We arrived fairly early on Sunday brunch so we had our pick of the tables but I do see the patio filling very quickly to enjoy the sun.  There is a bunch of inside communal tables and when we left, it was getting quite full.  The restaurant shares the charcuterie/deli and their storefronto so it can be a bit lively with a lot of people moving in and out but oddly enough, it never felt too loud or too congested like many of the other West Loop places.

Service is sooooo friendly here.  LOVE IT.  None of this pretentious eye rolling service that I've seen plagued several good places.  They're so knowledgeable about all the dishes and ready to recommend someone based on my interest and steer us in the right way.  They also share an infectious enthusiasm for their baked good which made me buy a few  that I didnt plan and WOW, i'm so glad. 

We got the salmon club, broc wallbanger, biscuit sandwich, kale side, matcha rice crispy, and their version of the chocolate chip cookie.  Oh plus two bottomless intelligentsia coffee.  EVERYTHING IS GOOD.  Honestly.  The salmon was not overcooked and had a great smokeiness to it which was just enhanced by the bacon vinaigrette,  ... the bread ... oh the bread.  Forget what you think of spongey tasteless white bread... this multigrain bread was so flavourful.  A bit of natural sweetness with a touch of nuttiness on the crust... I can only imagine it from the whole grains and being baked till it had a nice thick dark crust to it.  Honestly... just come here for the bread.  Broc wallbanger was awesome for our veg who inhaled it, the biscuit sandwich was said to be the perfect breakfast sandwich anyone can think of... bacon, perfectly cooked fried egg on top of a soft and tasty biscuit!  Kale side was really good cause of the nice balance of citrus on it.  

Before you leave this place after getting some amazing food... stop by the baked good area and pick up at least 2 things.  You owe yourself to be amazed at their spin on some traditional childhood treats.  These are a little upscale but damn... it will make you reminiscence of the good old days while thinking "I've been scammed my entire childhood not eating this."  My matcha rice crispy was ridiculously huge.  It was so good... the green tea gave a hint of bitterness, strong wonderful flavour of green tea but the marshmallow and vanilla (?) really balanced it out with a perfect sweetness to still make you smile.  It was that perfect gooey, chewy, and yet crispy texture that you want every time out of the oven.  Sooo goood.  As for the chocolate chip cookie... I didnt get to taste it cause the person said they would bit anyone's finger who attempts to take it from them.  They said it was so buttery and yet nutty (the whole grain flours I'm assuming) while the chocolate bits were large irregular and had a true dark chocolate flavour... none of the waxy fake chocolate chips that is in most bakeries. 

So simply said,  truly one of the best brunch places I've been to and definitely would return... even if it's just for the baked goods!

Great sandwich shop in the West Loop / Fulton Market area.

Came in on a Saturday afternoon and there was a 20 minute wait. There's a little waiting area by the counter where they sell different meats and cheeses, and lots of interesting condiments / sauces line the shelves by the window. While we were waiting the meat guys offered us some pieces, and we had beers -- not a bad start. The interior feels more like a specialty meats / cheese shop rather than a deli or restaurant, but most people here come for lunch or "a whole meal of food".

The seating here is communal, so if you're not down for hearing little snippets from the table next to you, this place might be a no go.

We shared the biscuit -- which was a biscuit so it was awesome -- the beet salad (also very good) and the parm. The parm was really gooey with cheese and super flavorful. Both times I've been here I've had it -- what can I say, I know what I like.

Oh yes! Imagine Brooklyn hipsters getting into this business. Only now imagine if they had a thorough knowledge of their craft, not condescending and weren't douche bags from Brooklyn. It feels a little to clean and well run and professional overall to be legit but it absolutely is. This is one of the finest meat-anything shops in the country; certainly in in Chicago. And please pay attention to my other reviews and general take on food. I basically know more about cow and pig part so all their forms to be taken at least with a grain of salt, if not with a proper piece of bread and dove smalec'. 

Truly one of the finest cured, smoked, salted, brined and generally finessed meat purveyors anywhere. Pricey though.

Excellent portion, quality and food preparation with a decent price.

HOT CHARCUTERIE OR SAUSAGE PLATE ($18) -- I'm not a sausage person, but the 3 different selections compliment each other.  Addictive.  Perfection to dijonnaise drizzle.  Taste great when freshly served, it still taste the same when reheated.  Serves 2+.

APPLE PIE ($5) -- the best apple pie in Chicago.  The crunch on top is addictive.  $5 is hefty but worth it.

CHAI LATTE ($4) -- housemade Chai.  Woo hoo!  Balanced spice with milk.

SERVICE -- Jessica was knowledgeable with a just right timing on follow-up.  You go to the baristas and they will be glad to tell you the magnificence of what they do.

VENUE -- communal tables.  Plenty of employed guys eat here.  LOL

Amazing burger night is what we had last Weds when we went to dine at this fabulous restaurant. We did a walk in put in our names and got a table within 15-20 minutes wait. The staff was super friendly and nice we tried their traditional pub burger which came with fries, yay! I loved their caramelized onions in the burger with this special sauce they do that tasted a little mustardy and sweet. I loved it I think they make an amazing burger. It was a very tasty burger. I would recommend everyone to check this place out for a great burger night!

I had one of my greatest meals here while in Chicago. This restaurant wasn't on the planned list of places we wanted to try, but sometimes the greatest meals aren't always somewhere you plan. 

My friends and I ordered the Butcher's Cold Charcuterie Plate with 5 different meats. It was absolutely delicious and how great that it comes from a butcher shop. I ordered the spinach and potato soup because it was raining the day we came here. The soup was good, but came in a small bowl. If you come here, you MUST order the "Return of the Gyro." I had never tasted anything like it. The sauce with the pork belly was something I still dream about even a year later. If I happen to ever be in Chicago again, I will be sure to stop by here.

Few days before coming to the Publican quality meats, my uber driver told me that he used to work here. C.O.O.L. He told me how wonderful this place is and how he loved grabbing a Parm#2 or a big dipper before he got off work. 

I definitely believed him as I spotted the "Humboldt Fog" and the "Midnight Moon" by Cypress Grove Chèvre (CA) displaying in the cheese fridge. Both are one of the finest cheese I've ever tasted.

So I ordered
THE BIG DIPPER: sweet and spicy braised wagyu brisket, green garlic aioli, radish, jalapeno and snow pea slaw on ciabatta bread (4/5):
The flavor of my sandwich was undeniably rich. The side kale salad it came with was amazing as well. I have only one complaint: the brisket and the bread were both of the hard side. Painful to chew for someone with a disjointed jaw (like me).

note: I normally would not order a sandwich anywhere I go, but since the Publican Quality Meats is famous for its sandwiches, oh well. Gotta sacrifice.

Service was fascinating. The people working here are so friendly~ They come around and fill up your glass of water v often. Hurray.

Food delicious 
I had the chicken salad with the buttermilk dressing on the side. The lettuce was delicious but I had to do a lot of cutting and work.

The cheese plate was also quite good and the pickled cherries they serve with are as my friend said "so good I would eat a million of them if I could"

Chicken parm sandwich was also amazing.  

Our waiter, Mitch seemingly wanted nothing to do with us after I innocuously asked for a carafe of water for our table. He said he couldn't do that, okay. Then did it and we drank the whole thing. Brought the check without ever checking on us, I did want another drink but ok, message received. -1 and really probably -2 for service but I'll round up.

Girlfriend took me here for Saturday brunch to show me her workplace for the summer :) We sat outside in the small patio area along the side of the shop, it was a beautiful day to soak up some sun. We ordered a couple dishes to share: the porchetta sandwich, a hot charceuterie plate, and also a side of fried eggs cause we really wanted eggs :P I had a Kyle's go juice to go with my meal (coffee drink). The go juice is made with coffee, espresso, honey, and angostura bitters. 

The porchetta sandwich was absolutely phenomenal; it's served only on Saturdays after 12. We saw the butcher bring out the entire roast on a large cutting board. The meat is juicy, succulent, and tender. The sandwich is served red onion, pickles, aioli, mustard on a ciabatta bun. The porchetta portion was huge! We had difficulty keeping the sandwich together while eating it. The onions and pickles gave it some acidity to help balance out the fatty delicious meat. Comes served with a side of chips. The charceuterie plate was comprised of 3 types of house-made sausages served on a bed of red peas, pickled cabbage and mustard. They were all delicious; but my favorite was probably the cajun blanc sausage followed closely by the cajun boudin. I forgot what the other one we had was called :/ It all ate quite well with the peas and pickled cabbage and our fried eggs :)

I would absolutely recommend PQM to anyone looking for a casual, delicious meal. Their meat and cheese selection from their shop is excellent and they also sell baked goods as well. They have a small grocery section that sells some nice preserved goods and even select wines and beers. Would love to come back and try more of their delectable offerings.

Visited here a couple times now, first late Sunday afternoon and then a little before noon on Sunday. First time missed the porchetta sandwich only available on Sundays after 11:30am but happily ordered The Big Dipper (sweet and spicy braised wagyu brisket, green garlic aioli, radish, jalapeno and snow pea slaw on ciabatta bread). It was very satisfying. The meat was well cooked with a savory combo. We also had the Turkey Slam, fairly basic but enjoyable as well. The pasta salad and kale sides were also refreshing and plentiful. The second time we saw the porchetta come out steaming and we ordered two sandwiches. The first bite was what I anticipated and expected. Nice fattiness and savory and juicy. Pairs nicely with the ciabatta. Delicious delicious sandwich. A must get if you're lucky enough to get before it runs out. The atmosphere and staff is also really relaxing and enjoyable. Great music. Attentive bus boys/girls and the kitchen staff holds the same integrity of their service as they do with the product. The coffee brewed is also Intelligentsia. They make a proper cappuccino/latte. Really looking forward to try the chicken parm sandwich next!

-Order up with a smile

I may have found my favorite place in the world. I wish I lived in Chicago now just so I can eat here every day and get insanely fat. 

Cute little meat and cheese deli with a restaurant in the back. Really brightly lit, and the staff are all very lively and friendly. They have meats in display like a usual butcher/deli, and sell them in bulk. Near the back is a fridge with refrigerated goods (frozen raw meat cuts, cold broth in soup takeout containers, and ice cream/yogurt/cold dairy products.

Little restaurant in the back is adorable - it looks like it came out of someone's pinterest. The menu is mouthwatering delicious and made me sad I couldn't eat everything. I ended up getting the 3 piece charcuterie set, which comes with three heaping portions of preselected meats, as well as pickles, picked red bell pepper, whole grain mustard, and olive oil coated bread slices. One complaint is that there wasn't really enough bread, but there is never enough bread so I guess I can't fault them for that.

I was too busy already eating to pay attention to when the server was describing the meats (shame on me). What I got though was a mild, thick sliced saucisson of some type, pork rillettes with fig jam, and some kind of spicy pate pressed with dried apricots, all in heaping portions. The sausage and rillettes were absolutely amazing. If I had to rank them the pate would probably come last, but that didn't stop me from eating it all and scraping the last bit off the board.

Would absolutely recommend.
The brisket sandwich was completely fine, but definitely overpriced and overhyped. Unnecessarily long wait, too.

After having a great lunch at Au Cheval, the bf and I wanted to try charcuterie plate at Publican Quality Meats. Since we were stuffed, we want to just have a quick snack. The shop is super adorable, with a huge selection of deli meats in the front, small shop with specialty goods, and a small sit down area in the back.

The Bf and I ordered the 3 item charcuterie plate, chef's choice. I believe he gave us a shredded duck piece with cranberry jam, head cheese, and another item i cant remember. The meats are served with a grainy mustard, sweet pickle, and a few pieces of toasted baguette.

I would definitely recommended this place for a quick bite or lunch. I saw some awesome sandwiches that other patrons ordered. A very chill place, nothing fancy smancy, great meat shop with lots of other specialty items to purchase. The staff are all very friendly. a 3 meat plate was around $20.

Tried the porchetta sandwich (available Saturday and Sunday after 11 from what I gathered). Very solid. Plenty of fatty, tender meat-- though some was a little too gristly for my taste. 

Loved the mustard on the sandwich-- and the bread was crispy yet light, so overall the sandwich was great. 

Nice ambience in the Fulton market area. Gentrifying warehouse area with lots of upmarket yet casual restaurants. It's worth a visit for their brunch for sure.

I was staying nearby next to the Publican, but didn't have the time to enjoy a sit down meal there. Enter Publican Quality Meats. When you enter the front door, you'll see a deli with a variety of specialty smoked or cured meats, and on the left, you'll see a small cafe with some communal tables and chairs. It's a fairly interesting offering they have, from soups, breakfast plates, to day-old cookies that they sell at a discount ($1).

The two times I visited on my trip were mainly for sausages and takeout sandwiches. I tried their "Da Grinder", which was a medley of salamis and cheese, on a French baguette. The meats were salty, toned down by the mildness of the cheese, all accented by the crustiness of the bread. Not too shabby. The sandwich came with a bag of Deep River chips and a pickle spear. 

I also recommend getting the duck prosciutto and the green chile sausage. I wasn't exactly sure how to prepare them, but the cashier/host gave some good recommendations, and it turned out great. One thing I will have to say is that you should avoid the chicken salad. The chicken was a a bit on the dry side, and while they do use quality ingredients (radishes, homemade buttermilk dressing, and black chickpeas), the portion is also pretty small for $15. 

Overall, the place is great for some specialty meats, or a high quality sandwich. I'll definitely be back to try some of the charcuterie or other toasted sandwiches they have to offer.

Thanks to Anthony Bourdain, we stumbled upon Publican quality meats during our trip to Chicago. Needless to say, we were not disappointed. We ordered the parm #2 and the big dipper with a strawberry Wisco pop and Dr. Brown's Black Cherry soda. 

The parm #2 had fresh breaded chicken with a rich tomato sauce and mozzarella cheese to add texture and mouth feel. I could definitely taste the difference.

The big dipper was out of this world. We got a sweet and spicy combination that paired perfectly with the delicious brisket inside the sandwich.

Both were expertly crafted with the perfect bread to complement each sandwich. I would also recommend their sides, the marinated kale and the cucumbers, which were tangy and flavorful. 

Our server Jessica was an absolute delight, ready with recommendations and showing us the lay of the land.

Good food. High prices. Less than stellar service, especially for takeout. The menu is great. The butcher options are plentiful. You can't really complain about the food. But, be warned, the service is painfully slow. As in 22 minutes for 2 sandwiches got takeout when there was no line. Also, the prices for basic things are crazy. $3 for a root beer that's $1.25 - $1.50 anywhere else. As to whether the value in the food outweighs the cost and slow service is a personal judgement call.

This place has been on my must-visit list for a while, but after a recent visit, I'm not sure I need to go back.

Being in the restaurant gave me anxiety. It was really crowded, people were coming and going, there was no place to stand to wait for our order, there was a baby making noise, just not my thing.

The sandwiches were fine but really not that much better than any I've had anywhere else, though the price was a lot more. The chicken parm sammy I had was the same as the one I get at the little Italian deli across from my office, plus a few bucks.

I think if you're gonna do it right, you get here when it's less crowded and order a cheese and meat board, plus a bottle of wine. Maybe I'll come back to try that.

This is truly meat heaven for a man like me. I love meat of all types and grades. I have also been playing with meat for about 15 years now. From bacons to sausages and now dry curing meats of my own. I walked in yesterday morning and immediately I was hit with a meat bat. Whop up side your head. There was a case of dry cured meat and one of bacon and sausages. The super nice young man behind the counter was very helpful as I stood there with my eyes bugging out of my head. Would you like to try some he asked? Why sure just start lining them up. I dug into the spicy coppa and the pancetta. The he showed me a prosciutto that was aged for 2 years in the huge chamber downstairs. We went though the process of how try do their meats and we compared notes till I was dragged living an screaming out the door. He did tell me that they aren't allowed to take folks down to their processing room but. If you happened to go to the bathroom it's right there. I did just that and got to take a look see. Oh My God that was a beautiful place. Now I did purchase a good handful of meat to share with some friends at home. So if you are one of those folks look forward to some tasty napkin meats in your future.
The duck inn vs Scofflaw Tuesday night.  Great food amazing service.  Outdoor patio was a amazing on a perfect Chicago summer night.

Let me just say first off, that the food was very good and the atmosphere was enjoyable. I am glad I gave this place a try!

I am a bit confused as a first time customer, however. When I came in with my children (who eat nearly everything), we looked at the deli meats and knew that we wanted roast beef sandwiches, mine without bread. When we talked to the girl at the counter, she seemed a bit confused and mentioned that we could sit in the dining area and order.

When we ordered in the dining area, I asked for roast beef only with horseradish sauce. She didn't seem very sure about it but then said she could bring a plate of it, no problem. When my daughter ordered a roast beef sandwich that was not on the menu, it seemed to cause some confusion. My daughter, the ever loving negotiator, simply asked that if she went to the deli and ordered a roast beef sandwich, if they could make it and asked why they wouldn't be able to make it for the dining area. Ugh. Eventually all was figured out and she had a plate of roast beef, cheddar wheeze, lettuce, salami, and sourdough bread for a DIY sandwich plate, but it was strange to not be able to order simple things that were clearly in the deli, in the dining area.

At this point, my son decided he wasn't going to eat...

All of that aside, I would definitely go back for the deli meats and some of the goodies in the refrigerator. Maybe we'll take it home. ;)

Great food, simple dishes, and not much of a wait time make PQM a great place to eat.

Came here for lunch w/ some friends on a Friday and we were able to get seated right away. I got:

-Pok pok gose: letherbee gin, pok pok thai basil, rhubarb, off color troublesome. This was a very refreshing drink that was tasty, too

-Return of the gyro: braised pork belly, raita, escalivada, pea shoots and calabrian chili vinaigrette. HOLY HELL THIS WAS AMAZING. I love pork belly and I love gyros, so when I read that PQM had married these 2 together, I knew I had to come here to try it and it definitely did not disappoint. The pork belly was amazingly flavorful and tender (they also didn't skimp on the portions, either!), and the vinaigrette tied it together very well. Definitely a must-get if you dine here

-Cold charcuterie plate: we all split this and we all loved it. There were about 5 different types of meat, and they all were phenomenal. Another must-get IMO.

Will definitely be coming back to try other items on the menu. They were out of the Roast Beef when we arrived, so hopefully the next time I'm back I'll be able to try that.

Did a quick breakfast here, and man, so good!  Had a cappuccino that was awesome, made with Intelligensia's Black Cat Espresso.  I ordered the bacon egg and cheese sandwich on their homemade biscuit,  also with some type of sauce that really pushed it over the top with savory flavor. Can't wait to go back!

I have been to the Publican thrice for brunch now and I thought it was the best thing since sliced bread... Until last Friday when my friends and I ended up at PQM after being quoted an hour and a half wait time at Little Goat. I say "ended up" but I really mean we're soooo lucky to walk in, sit down, and immediately begin stuffing our faces with some of the finest charcuterie I've had in Chicago aside from Hopleaf and Gather. It had big heaping portions so all three of us felt like we had plenty to taste. I started with the Pok Pok Gose cocktail which was a super refreshing summery gin drink. My boyfriend got the Bloody Mary which was similar to the one across the road at the Publican, with a Miller High Life beer back instead of a draft (champagne of beers--way classier). 

The guys got the pork belly gyros and they must have been amazing because I didn't even get offered a bite, and I'm usually able to steal one! I was able to taste the slaw that came with the gyro and it was amazing--light and vinegar based and crunchy. I ordered the smoked salmon plate which had ridiculously good salmon. The only weird thing was the charcuterie actually took longer than our main dishes to come out so we were awkwardly eating everything at once. But geez louise was it good!! Perfect way to start off a nice long day drinking session, and I will definitely be back asap... And probably bring everyone who visits me in Chicago here as well!

Came back for an early morning treat.   One of the bakers excited to meet me and introduce breads and cookies.  Outstanding quality -- probably the best in the city.   Salted chocolate chip cookie not to be missed.  Meat selection outstanding.  If you have not been, you must go.  Strive for excellence, scratch prepared meals and it shows.   Bravo!!!

This was quite the fun stop on the way out of the neighborhood, after having breakfast at the publican across the street.

Upon entering you are greeted by some very knowledgeable folks behind the counter, and some cases filled with absolute delicacies as far as me to go. They had a lot of porcine options, including a ton of different ways to serve sausage. The guys really knew their stuff, and it was fun to listen to the different types of sausage and how each one was made.

The cuts of beef looked excellent and there were also some lamb options.

The back wall contained tons of cooking supplies, spices, books, and plenty of other kitchen pleasantries that would make for great stocking stuffers. Absolutely worth checking out if you're in the area.

First stop in Chicago, and I was immediately impressed! I originally wanted to go to The Publican, but accidentally ended up at this location without knowing until I had sat down. Since I was already looking at the menu, I decided to stay here and see what Publican Quality Meats had to offer!! 

Because it is a meat shop, we decided to order the three types of charcuterie for an appetizer. We got the coppa di testa, duck rilette, and pate, and the dish came with different types of mustards, pickles, peppers, and bread. The rilette was surprisingly fantastic, and the bread was toasted and drizzled with olive oil. Preparation and care into their food is obviously seen, and this was the perfect start to our meal.

For my entree, I got the Butcher's breakfast which includes sausage, bacon, bread, two sunny side up eggs, and chorizo? hash. Everything was a little on the greasy side which is expected as it is bacon and a bunch of meats, but it was amazing. The sausage was so flavorful, and the chorizo hash had soft potatoes and crunchy bits with a hint of meat in the taste. So good. The plate was overall very well structured, and I surprisingly finished everything on there. I also tried my friend's chickpea soup which was good, but nothing extraordinary.

This location really does serve quality meats, and it surpassed my expectations! They had a ton of options to buy meat and spices at the front, and if I was a Chicago local, I would totally buy their meats to take home. If I do end up coming back to Chicago, Publican is next!

Paul Kahan, purveyor of such fine establishments like Big Star, Avec, and The Publican, can do no wrong in my book. Thus, I was already destined to enjoy Publican Quality Meats (PQM, for short), Kahan's salumi-slash-sandwich shop and Publican spin-off.

The closest proxy to PQM is Cochon Butcher in New Orleans, an ungodly good salumi-slash-sandwich shop that specializes in all things cured between two delicious slices of carb. Cochon Butcher is better than PQM, but I can't hardly think of another place I've liked better than the Butcher. In other words, putting PQM in a second-tier isn't an indictment.

My one issue with PQM is what appears to be a lack of communication between the two halves. PQM's sandwiches don't seem to take full advantage of the delightful charcuterie available to them. In fact, PQM's most well-known sandwich, the "Return of the Gyro," stuffs its pita with braised pork belly, something more associated with Publican proper rather than PQM. Again, I'm not hating. This wrap is damn good, ranking amongst the best "sandwiches" I've had in Chicago.

The remainder of its menu is highly rotational, and maybe I just keep coming at the wrong times, but I'd love to see a muffaletta, a pastrami on rye, an Italian grinder, anything that's just simple meat, cheese, bread, and a couple condiments. Sure, a chicken parm sounds darn good, but that's not why I'm drooling puddles staring at your meat case, PQM.

OK, mini-rant over. Everything else about PQM is fantastic. It's a little jarring first walking in, inundated with meat cases with hefty price tags. Here's the tips. If you're getting a sandwich or prepared foods to go, go to the middle cashier directly. If you're picking out sliced meats, head left. If you plan to sit and dine, head right (or to the far end, depending on the door you've entered). Once that moment of zen has passed, you'll feel more relaxed.

For salumi orderers, there's plenty to choose from, but try to pick the stuff (labeled with PQM) smoked in-house. PQM has variants of just about everything under the sun, and I've never been disappointed by anything I've taken home. For restaurant-goers, somebody should get the Return of the Gyro, but from there I leave it to you. Like I said, my preference would be to get something with meat available at the butcher, but that's just me. Whatever you get, it will not suck.

Quality meat indeed. I'm still here, wondering if that skirt steak I just devoured was all a dream.

The service was prime, cute butcher with prompt service who gave the life story of the charcuterie in house, got half a lb of skirt steak and a sample of blood mortadella from the meat counter. I would recommend the mortadella, it was such a yummy balance of zestyness and savory! Also got a piece of foie, from the freezer, looking forward to it.

The register clerk was super helpful as well, I ended up getting a chicken parm sandwich, but that was just ok. The roll had a nice chew but the chicken was kinda soggy, I liked the flavour of the sauce but the cheese was kinda uneven.

I would go back to try another sandwich though, and to cop more of them meatssssss!

I wish we had a place like this in MN!! It might be time for me to move...this place was that good!

The little restaurant is super cute, with a modern homey feel. There's community style seating which I loath. Half the time the people I'm next to are talking so loud it starts to sound like pigs squealing it's that annoying. However, I won't let that take away from the whole experience, it was that good. 

My boyfriend and I decided to split Gerry's Adobo Sausage, and the Cold Charcuterie plate. I will never forgot how f'ing delicious my first bites were of everything we ordered. 

The adobo sausage came on a lobster bun, some pickled cauliflower on the side. The sausage wasn't overpowering, it was a perfect balance with the bun and toppings. Intense flavors, but none were competing. 

Of the charcuterie, all 5 were phenomenal, but the lamb roulette, and pate were to die for. I could have eaten it all without a bread vehicle, just meat all in my mouth. 

I wish I remembered what our servers name was because she was amazing. She was friendly, quick, and helpful with the menu. Our waters were always topped off by the busboys. Everyone working there seemed to really enjoy it, that's always great to see. 

I also have to mention the bathrooms were in the basement, that usually creeps me out. These were not at all creepy. Bright, modern, and clean. Bonus, you see the kitchen at work downstairs, super cool.

Whenever I make a trip to Chicago again I will always make a stop here.

So I checked this place out because my foodie buddy told me to. I got the Big Dipper sandwitch and it a ginger beer. They Sammy was very flavorful and I liked the bread they used. I liked the ginger beer it was a brand I had never tried but it is one I would order again. The only downside was the sandwitch was a little small. The environment was really cool liked the deli/ open style seating. The staff is very friendly while still be professional.

This restaurant is fairly busy on the weekends! It feels super homey and you know it's going to be a delicious meal the moment you walk in. I ordered the Porchetta and it was DELICIOUS. I would love to come back here and try all the menu items here! Great place for families or friends.

I went here for lunch and breakfast on 2 different occasions.  First, the breakfast was phenomenal.  I wish I still worked nearby for that breakfast burrito with bacon and eggs.  I was truly in bliss when eating that sandwich amongst the noisy crowd in my office.  

And for lunch, I had the gyro.  The first thing I noticed about this establishment was that all their baked goods were excellent.  The chewy texture was just out of this world.  I want to marry the baker and live forever eating carbs and being fat.

Being that this was my first decent meal in Chicago I was pleasantly surprised. It's a meat market with an amazing menu selection and literally "quality meats."

The Return of the Gyro (I could eat five of these in one sitting.)
- pork belly heaven in a crisp wrap with coleslaw and a pickle. 

They also sell Mexican Coke which is always a nice treat. 

I'd want to try the Wagu Sandwich next. Like right-now-next.

PQM is the ultimate carnivore's paradise. Cases full of whole dry-aged ribeyes, racks of venison, legs of lamb, slabs of porchetta and guanciale, oddities like beef bacon and duck prosciutto, the best damn smoked turkey and roast beef in the world, and every kind of sausage under the sun. If your mouth isn't watering yet, you don't belong in here!

As far as sandwiches go, I've had the roast beef (kneel to zhoug), turkey (piri piri pavo) and the seriously kickass chicken parm. All excellent, to the point where I try my best to recreate those roast beef and turkey sandwiches at home. You can't go wrong with any of their meats or charcuterie, and the guys working the counter are really friendly and happy to accommodate whatever odd weights of meat you want. 

Side note: they also sell Avec dates and piquillo pepper sauce here ($1.50 apiece!) Definitely check out their fresh baked cookie selection as well...the $1 day old cookies are a steal. 

Pricey stuff, yes, but you really get what you pay for. This ain't no Boar's Head.

Had lunch from Publican QM today with some colleagues. We noted the creativity in trying to fuse some traditional concepts and different flavors, but we didn't think the result was worth the price. We had the Return of the Gyro sandwich (braised pork belly, raita, escalivada, pea shoots and calabrian chili vinaigrette on griddled flatbread--pickle and chips also), and it was good but not as great as the rating and reviews it has. I'll really ask what their top item is next time and order that.

Porchetta sandwich is amazing. Had the pork belly gyro and it was good, but after the porchetta  it paled in comparison. The texture, the mix of salty, sweet, tangy, and a touch of heat with the savory of the pork of the porcetta was unbeatable. Good service. Good Bloody Mary. Fair prices.

I have tried multiple sandwiches on their rotating menu. All have been wonderful. In fact, I find myself getting things to go after. 

To be more specific, I've been there multiple times on burger nights and tried their burger and other chefs that had created the burgers. My wife also refers to their Reuben as one the best she's ever had. It had beef tongue in it which was doubtful at first but melted in your mouth.

Would recommend any of Paul Kahans restaurants without any reservation. Some of best Chicago has to offer.

Great selections and they are so helpful for preparing certain offerings. I get my duck confit from there and I usually eat it with rice and it's tasty. I grocery shop there as well for specialty items.

This is the kind of place that will make you wish you had two stomachs...

We were visiting from Florida, and had done some research ahead of time for "must-try" places. This was on our list based on our research, and if we hadn't waited until the last day to try it, then we would have eaten here at least twice. 

I'll get the only complaint i had off my chest right away, the seating is limited - so when the line started to form at around 12:30pm, then the servers got a little more passive-agressive about getting rid of us, so they could turn the tables over. A little annoying, but not enough to outweigh the amazing food, so I'll give them a pass (Just try to show up outside of what you'd expect to be rush hours, and you shouldn't experience this anyway). 

We shared a chicken parm sandwich, and a charcuterie plate, which by the way, comes with seasonally recommended items by the chef, or you can sub in different items you'd like to try. 

The sandwich was ridiculously good, we only wish we had the space to try a gyro, and the pork belly too. 

The charcuterie was equally amazing - we actually didn't get to try as much as we wanted, so we stopped by the deli counter on the way out, and actually bought a few more nibbles for the road... Not that we left hungry by any means, but we have no way of knowing when we'll be back!

I wish there was somewhere as good as this closer to home. The staff are friendly, and will explain what things taste like / provide examples to help you understand before you buy. If you are foodies like us, be prepared to spend more and really try the things you heard about - they will be as good as you hoped they would, and you'll only leave disappointed if you don't try something!

We will absolutely be back here next time we visit Chicago. Our hosts had never been, so we felt like the cool kids recommending a place to them, in their own city that we know they will love.

Held a private event here and the food was delish!  An amazing avocado and asparagus salad with pistachios - yum!  Followed by super tender chicken (a bit salty) with the most addictive French fries drowning in the chicken juice.  I really just wanted a bite of the fruit cobbler, but scarfed it all down since it was so tasty.  A fun, different type of venue with great food for an intimate size event (less than 20 people).

Brunch = AMAZING. I live only a 10-minute walk from this place and have just now gotten around to trying it for their famous brunch. We arrived on a Saturday morning around 11AM and there was plenty of space for us. Inside, they are a meat and bread shop that also offers some tables and wait staff for dining in. Outside, they very nice sidewalk seating, which is what we opted for. 

Their brunch menu is small and simple, about 4 or 5 offerings, some sweet and some savory. After contemplating, my boyfriend and I both opted for the Farmers Breakfast, which includes two Sunnyside up eggs, two pieces of bacon, house made breakfast sausage, homemade fresh bread, and amazing breakfast potatoes. This breakfast blew me away. It was simple, but all incredibly fresh and homemade. The house made sausage was a huge highlight, as were the breakfast potatoes that come with a spicy aoili. We really enjoyed the fresh bread served with the eggs as well. 

I was definitely impressed with the quality of the ingredients here, and I'm excited to come back and use them as a meat and bread shop as well for cooking at home. Very fun to have this place in the neighborhood and I look forward to adding it as one of my go-to's!

This was my second time here and boy was it delicious. We ordered the charcuterie platter which came with chef's choice of 3/5/7 different meats. It came with head cheese, salami, thinly sliced pork belly?, shredded duck with some sort of comport and this delicious chorizo and garlic block. They gave us toasted bread on the side and when we requested more, we got two more additional plates! The service and the platter were awesome. I sampled my friend's hot apple cider and man was it good. I regretted not getting a cup of my won. For my own entree I ordered the return of the gyro which was a pork belly gyro served with coleslaw. The pork belly was delightful and probably deep fried. The coleslaw was cold and cut through the fattiness nicely. Definitely coming back.

Love this place. 

Whether brunch, lunch, or burger night on Tuesdays in the summer it is consistently awesome.

Recently had the porchetta sandwich special for brunch. It was outstanding. Like honestly a borderline perfect sandwich.

Also went to the first burger night this spring. Shake Shack versus Green River. The Green river burger was awesome. It came with this excellent aoili. The entire flavor profile was on point.

Also, everyone that works here is usually extremely pleasant and it's really just a great joint.

One thing I will say is I wish they would sit incomplete parties, if three people are waiting for their fourth or two are waiting for the their third just let them sit down and order for that person. 

Also, they seemingly run out of glass and silverware every time I come here and have to reuse glasses if different beers are ordered or serve them in plastic cups. 

Kinda weird but it's not going to stop me from coming back here. This place is a Chicago gem.

Great place to grab a sandwich or shop for gourmet ingredients. Definitely recommend this for lunch.

FOOD
Vinny's Turkey (5 stars): Soft and juicy meat. Loved the tomatoes on it! 

Kale salad on the side (4 stars): garlicky, good dressing. 

Spicy pickle (4 stars): Yum.

Cowboy Cookie (3 stars): Couldn't taste all the yummy ingredients listed in it like pretzels and potato chips. The cookie was still good though but it needed to be softer. 

SERVICE 
All of the workers here were extremely nice! We had to catch a flight soon so they asked what we wanted to order before we sat down and by the time our seats opened up our food was ready! They really care about your experience here. 

ATMOSPHERE:
If I lived here I'd probably buy all the meats, cheeses, pastas, and sauces here. It all looked and smelled so good! They have large long tables and basically sit everyone together. Surprisingly it wasn't weird at all to sit next to people you didn't know. You're too happy with your food to even pay attention to others, haha.

Amazing food!!!  I got the gyro and it was FANTASTIC.  They were super quick too.  The decor was super cute and I loved the tile on the floor and walls.  They have some condiments for purchase as well!

GREAT little neighborhood spot in the Fulton market district for foodies who are looking for a more casual brunch spot. The coffee is strong and delicious.  We split a sticky bun- a sweet cinnamon roll with roasted pecans (YUM!). For our main brunch dishes we got the lake street fish platter (an open faced smoked salmon baguette sandwich with greens, onion, soft boiled egg, and a light lemon vinaigrette-so so good!) and the fried chicken and biscuit sandwich which was also great. Love the patio, which almost always has room available to sit and eat breakfast :)

Stopped by for lunch.  I had the sausage plate.  It came with some caramelized onions and red peppers, along with some cucumber and cauliflower.  The sauasages were the freedom, cajun, and mett.  The freedom was my favorite.  Everything was great.  Service was very friendly.  I want to come back for burger night the next time I am in town.

Got delivery from here for an employee luncheon. I ordered the chicken parmesan sandwich and it was pretty good. Two large, breaded chicken breasts which were cooked well, some marinara sauce, a few leafs of basil, and a thick slice of some quality mozzarella cheese. The chicken was great, the cheese was delicious, the basil didn't seem super fresh and the marinara sauce was a bit on the bland side. The worst part is that the sauce made the bread completely soaked and soggy! By the time I got my food, the sandwich was lukewarm at best. However, I'm guessing if you ordered this in the restaurant it would be piping hot & not soggy at all. So, I'd recommend eating here, but not delivery. Clearly, the meats and cheeses they use on their sandwiches are very high quality! I'll be back.
You cannot top the meats. So delicious and custom. The sandwiches are a little small for the price, but the quality is top notch.

The food is great. Nothing you can take away on that front. It's so good for brunch too, as well as dinner. 

My issue is purely that the beverage program is seriously wine deficient. Like its missing a huge component. Beer is so-so, but for me I wanted more wine options. Better ones too. 

Wine program needs serious work. It's really lame, tame, and not anything exciting. 

With a place that has that much amazing pork, you need to have wine. Good wine. Not just stuff that everyone else has, or score hunting stuff from Spectator.

Leave it to me to come to a place with Quality Meats in the name to fall in love with a veggie sandwich. Well I did and I know it sounds weird, but in my opinion The BEET L.A.T. is better than anything here made with beef, chicken, or fish. And that's coming from a meat-a-tarian. 

It's the purple stuff, bibb lettuce, avocado, pickled green tomatoes, aioli, sprouts 
and smoked cheddar on multigrain toast. Paired with an amazing marinated kale salad and it could be one of the best vegetarian lunches in town. Of course living up to it's name anything made with meat is pretty quality here too. 

The ordering process is full table service which is kinda different for a small little sandwich spot, but I guess at over eleven bucks a pop it's worth sitting down and enjoying with one of the several beers they have to pair with.
I have eaten here probably a dozen times. It's good. But they always put way too much hipster in the food.

This place still has me in it's grasp. I've been favoring the Parm #2 and the most excellent Piri-Piri Pavo sandwiche of late. Yes it's still $14 for a sandwich but I was paying that in other cities for nothing remotely as good. I've been eyeing the bread and sweets cases but have thus far held strong...for how much longer who knows.

This is my happy place. We had been to The Publican (sister restaurant next door) for brunch and thought that was really nice. Think of Publican Quality Meats as the more casual option with just as delicious brunch options. Plus it's about half the cost. It feels like an every weekend option, compared to The Publican which is more of a special occasion brunch IMO. 

I haven't had anything here I didn't like. The pork belly gyro is awesome. We love their charcuterie and cheese boards too. Really fun selection of drinks, both alcoholic and not. There is a rotating specials menu that is worth taking advantage of. Lots of outside seating makes it a great pick on a sunny day.

Publican Quality Meats is a butcher shop and a restaurant with sit down ordering.  They also have outdoor patio seating when it's nice out.  

I went several months ago for burger club. They have a nice burger on Tuesday nights.  The night we went last June was a contest between leghorn and PQMs burger.  I had the PQM burger and it was delicious.  

Apparently the burger is only on Tuesday nights which we found out yesterday.  They stay open until 9pm on Tuesdays and close at 6 M, W-S.  

I had the chicken parm sandwich with a side of potato salad and both were beyond what you'd expect.  The potato salad was not creamy and mushy it was potatoes in an oily/herby mix.  I couldn't get enough.  The chicken parm was on a garlic toast baguette.  The cheese was amazing.  I have a feeling they made it.  

The store has milk, cheese, meats (obviously), burgers, sausages, and other cuts of meat you don't always see like pig cheeks and cowl. 

Two great experiences at PQM. Will be back.

I am reviewing the private dining/event experience.

Wow! We rented out the space for my brother's bachelor party. Our experience was nothing short of incredible. The staff was very warm and professional. We ate in the kitchen where we were able to watch the chefs prepare our food. The food was absolutely delicious. The PQM rib-eye was insanely good. Everyone could not stop raving about what a great experience they had.

I highly recommend PQM for your next private dining experience.
The wait is over 2 hours and they put their friends in first. If you're from out of town, forget it!

I was quite impressed with this place and very glad my wife and I made a stop here while visiting Chicago. 

The place is basically a deli with some tables and waiter service. We came here for a super early lunch -- I'm talking 10AM --  almost a late 2nd breakfast. There was hardly anyone here and we got seated right away. That's a good thing, because I hear this place gets pretty packed around noon.

We shared the pork belly gyro and the Cocido (mixed meat pot) for two. Both of these were very flavorful and unique from anything we ever had. The bread which they serve with the Cocido is so damn fresh and seems like they baked it in house, though I'm not sure about that part.

The atmosphere was really casual and, best of all, not pretentious at all. The waitress was very friendly and efficient. The food was delicious and had a "home cooked" feel to it.

If you come here, be sure to check out the downstairs kitchen. You can see the chefs grinding up meat and preparing sausages from scratch. They're extremely friendly and willing to explain what they're doing. So awesome!

Like the main restaurant, outstanding.

Cheese board is a bargain.  

Chicken parmesan in a lobster roll is delicioso.

My husband loves their creative sandwiches and beers. The restaurant is clean, including the restrooms. It was pleasant to eat on the outside patio. The service was great.
Personally, I prefer the Publican because they served more hot foods.

I don't think enough good things can be said about PQM, Food is always outstanding and love that the menu is always rotating. I swear it is cheaper to grab lunch here than it is to go to the store and make something decent for myself. 

GREEN CHILE SAUSAGE - Wow! That lobster roll though & Lime aioli ....

PARM #2 - Could have ran a marathon eating that thing. So delicious and surprisingly not to 
heavy.

RETURN OF THE GYRO - Usually I stick to Greek town for the real deal but this twist got me feeling some type of way.

PORCHETTA - After one of these I usually don't make plans for at least three to four hours and take an Uber home (I can see my building from here)

BUTCHERS BREAKFAST - Keep it simple stupid, nothing beats a basic breakfast! 

PQM, thank you for being you!

Went to this place after watching Andrew Zimmern's show - Bizarre Foods America: Chicago's Cutting Edge. We came here super early at 11:30AM, when they were just opened. There were a few others having their early lunch as well. This place had two sections: deli and cafe. They also prepared the meats downstairs. You would pass by if you went downstairs to use the restroom.

We had Return Of The Gyro: with braised pork belly, raita, escalivada, pea shoots and calabrian chili vinaigrette on griddled flatbread, and Cocido: smoked chorizo, braised beef, blood sausage, chickpeas, potatoes, cabbage, carrots and mojo picon.

I would like to try the cold-cuts and the Publican restaurant across street.

Publican. Since I moved form Chicago this is one of the places I miss the most. Their lunch is so creative and delicious. Even when there is a wait I love looking around their little store at all the awesome cooking specialities they have! It is great on a  cold rainy day to grab a seat inside, get the caramel creme tea and soup!
Brought my mom to lunch here one day. All of our food (and the wine) was delicious. Tight seating arrangement but it was never a problem for us.

So happy my hangry self ended up here. Outdoor seating and a wonderful selection of cheeses, salads, sandwiches, and charcuterie in a charming peaceful neighborhood made my afternoon. 

The cheese plate came with a nice range of 3 hard to soft cheeses and an array of condiments including honey drizzled over the blue, fresh and dried fruits, marcona almonds, cornichons, jam... So delicious.
