But to be honest, these things seem to be typical for Chicago - tight seating space, no fountain drinks and small portion sizes.

I'd go again - the food was great - but next time, I'll get takeout.

They have the coolest faucet/hand dryer! The phat noodles were amazing. Perfectly crisp and fatty pork bellay. The Vietnamese iced coffee and matcha mint tea are amazing. They have frozen beer! I would come here everyday if I could. I can't wait to try everything on the menu.

No, Urbanbelly!  Don't do it!  Don't move to Wicker Park and then become mediocre.  You have been so good in the West Loop, and Belly Shack on Western is just fantastic in terms of walking the line of fusion and comfort food.   I was so glad to see Penny's Noodles -- the standardbearer for mediocrity -- finally go, and Urban Belly move in.  But what the heck, man.  Where are the interesting dishes?  It was totally decent, serviceable fried rice.  Good.  But I had just hope for very good.  On par with your previous ventures.  So sad.

This was one of my go-to's when it was on California. And when that location closed I would head south when I needed my fix. Although everything was delicious my absolute favorites were the mango soup with fried chicken and the phat rice. I was living abroad for the last 8 months and was thrilled to see a new Urban Belly on Damen! I ordered my two favorite tonight for delivery and I have to say they were both really bad. Not at all like I remembered and so beneath what they were that i don't think I'll order again. The phat rice was greasy, the meat is no longer served on the bone, the meat chunks that were in the rice were really fatty. I don't know what was going on with the mango soup, but it was equally disappointing. The broth had hardly any flavor and there was only a tiny chunk of mango. As if all of that wasn't bad enough they didn't include the ginger candies in my delivery bag! I'm not sure if the chef changed or the owner, but this was nothing like the urban belly I fell in love with and I don't think there is much chance of anyone falling in love with the new and unimproved urban belly.
The lemongrass chicken made me an addict. Whatever you do, don't order it if you don't want to burn a hole in your wallet.

My one and only affordable ribeye taco joint.  Meats are evenly seasoned and cooked in perfect temp.  Good meat portions.  The Original location - Raymond's No. 1.

CHEESE ADD-IN -- in tacos, it is placed in between the tortillas.  My first.  Impressed.  Cheese choices are: white (the chihuahua) or yellow (American).

HORCHATA -- decent with a good price.

VENUE -- superbly clean.

SERVICE -- counter service.  The Guapos are busy, informative, good at what they do, in a chilax vibe.

I was in Chicago for only a couple days but this was near by Airbnb.

Raymond's has a slightly diner-like feel, and is small and cozy.

I am thoroughly impressed by how cheap the food is here, and for such a good meal! The hamburgers were fresh and juicy, and the service was quick. The servers here are extremely friendly too, and even recommended that we only get one order of fries instead of two, because it's a large portion.

Hamburgers are $2.50 each and fries are $1.50...this is truly a great deal. I would recommend this place to anyone who is in the neighborhood!

Bring cash if you come, because you can't tip if you use card, and you'll definitely want to tip them!

Great inexpensive Mexican food joint. I'm a taco gal so I ordered the al pastor and carne asada tacos, which were the perfect amount of food to fuel me for an afternoon of sightseeing in downtown. Mind, Raymond's Tacos (I don't know if it is alternatively known as Raymond's Hamburgers hence the Yelp name?) is by no means healthy--they saturate their taco tortillas with oil, making for no-nonsense, greasy grub that hits the spot. I think each taco was $2.25, so $5 for a filling lunch is a win in my book.
I'm from ATL been on this earth 30 years I never had tacos better than this! If you want taco go here you will not be let down TRUST ME I eat here 3x a week lol

I've been trying to get here for months, and I've finally made it!!!! I had 2 ribeye steak tacos w/lettuce, onion, & cilantro on corn shells. Food came out straight off the grill. So hot it was almost too hot to pick up, but that's exactly how I like my food!!! Service was fast & they were friendly. I'm going back for sure. I also wanna try their hamburgers. **** RED SALSA WAS THE BOMB****

Total hole in the wall

Been coming here for years since some family used to live in this hood. The food is good, the service is nice and the prices are unbeatable. 

Two things in the menu for me: burritos de asada y tacos de asada with american cheese. And if yes that is unusual and not as authentic as many would argue, it works for me. Chopped up steak and onions on two tortillas with a slice of melted american cheese in between, topped with lettuce and tomato. Weird? yes. Good? you bet.

Service always nice and chill. So don't expect them to bend backwards to serve you. Last time I was there waiter actually sat at the table with us to take the order. I thought that was super cool.
I Was Iffy About This Place At First When My Dad Took Me Here But Their Tacos Are BOMB!!!! So Much Meat & So Much Love OMG! You Must Try!!!!!

Located in little village and by faaaar some of THE best tacos in Chicago. I swear it's the tortillas. Luckily I live on the opposite side of town, otherwise my cravings for Raymond's tacos would be infinite. 

I forget if it regularly comes topped with queso, lettuce and tomato. If so, ALWAYS REQUEST for your tacos to be garnished with cilantro and onion Only! That's the ONLY way to eat a real taco!
Good tacos! Left the tomato and lettuce off of one (don't know why), but overall, really good. Prices are decent too. Fast service. Oh, and the salsa is terrific.

As a kid a remember my dad taking me to this place. I hated it, I wanted to go to  McDonalds's near the intersection of Kedzie and 26th. But now I love it and go at least twice a month. If it's been 2 weeks and no Raymond's, I become a crab ass.

I always get my usual. Steak burrito everything on it, no tomato, extra cheese (yes ladies and gentlemen 2 slices of American cheese), an RC, & a order of fries.

You want to know what is the weirdest part? Now I bring my daughter just like my dad took me an yes, she hates it. I have a gut feeling that history will indeed repeat itself with my grandchildren in the distant future.

The cooks know me, I always leave a tip and they hook it up with a little extra now and then.

I love their greasy, non healthy food. Every now and then it's not a bad thing to satisfy the cravings. The yellow American cheese in between the tortillas and the carne asada in middle with avocado and cheese. Their salsa and a large horchata. Yummmmm! 

The cooks make everyone feel as if you just walked into their kitchen and you feel welcome always. (You kinda did walk into the kitchen as you can watch them cook everything) 

Will always choose over any fast food franchise in area.

Tried Raymonds tacos tonight for the first time.Wasnt too crazy about the american cheese concept from the get go.Im sorry.Im Mexican.Im traditional.I dont even want lettuce and tomato on mine.Im a onions and cilantro guy.And if youre gonna put cheese in my tacos it BETTER BE MEXICAN CHEESE!!!! Dont want cheddar,munster,mozzarella and DEFINETELY not AMERICAN.Was it good???? It was ARRRIIIIIIGHT!!!! I dont want to eat it like that again.END OF REVIEW!!!!!!
I'm visiting from L.A. and omg! L.A. has nothing on these tacos! I'm coming back to this spot! Raymond's Tacos woohoo :-)

This is actually Raymond's Tacos and Hamburgers #1; #2 is the one on Blue Island.

I was here with a friend today and we both got some tacos and double cheeseburgers. The taco shells were a tad on the greasy side, but the char grilled steak was perfection! The cheeseburgers were excellent as well.

This place tends to be a little too small for comfort - there's a counter and four booths. We were lucky that we managed to get a booth just as a customer was about to leave.

Service was good given the crowd size and the number of employees working.

The one critique I have is regarding their beverage sizes - there seems to only be one size if you get the lemonade, fruit punch, or horchata, which seems to be somewhere between a small and a medium. You will get thirsty, so plan on ordering more beverages as your meal progresses.

If you're in the neighborhood, definitely check this place out - but plan on getting your food to go on the weekends.

EDIT 2/22: I stopped by here and it was a busy Friday night for them... I had to wait more than fifteen minutes for my order (there were several large orders including one guy who ordered 20 tacos for 'taco night'); still, they were efficient and moved as quickly as they could. Their hours are from 8AM to 12AM.
All I have to say is American cheese on tacos is not for me. I have had better tacos down the street.  There are the restaurants on California and Cermak that serve much better tacos. Just saying.

A friend told me about this spot and I went there for the first time on 11/7/12. Ordered the steak tacos with onions, which were really good! Nice neighborhood joint for Mexican food. I will go back when I'm in the area!

The food is not that good. If I wanted to eat grease then I would've gotten a spoon and ate from a grease can. There was no flavor, and they used american cheese. Where they do that at? I could've made a taco at home that tasted better than the ones at had there. But, the people were fast and friendly, and the area was comfortable.

While the morning rapidly grew colder and colder, as if Zeus suddenly summoned a mighty wind down California Avenue, only the quest to find a restaurant -any restaurant - open early for breakfast gave me any incentive to soldier on. 
Was there a hashhouse hidden along this gray/black stretch near the Cook County Courthouse? 
Perhaps a greasy spoon could give me something I didn't have to look at, but could easily swallow to stay fortified.
Maybe...just maybe, there was a friendly tacqueria that would welcome this Spanish-language-challenged stranger in his time of need.
OK, this may sound like a bit much but when you fall down the rabbithole and begin a day on jury duty with no lunch in hand and undetermined hours in court ahead, you want food fast and fulfilling.
After a fruitless walkdown down California, I head east on Cermak. Two guys walk out of Raymond's. It couldn't hurt for me to walk in.
Great call. As I enter, I can hear the sizzle of chicken and steak strips coming from the grill behind the counter along with the words "Kobe Bryant." It is the only English I hear for a minute. Smiling guys at the counter are getting that delicious sounding meat put into taco as I wait to order. The TV is on ESPN Deportes, but sports is a universal language, right. I order. No problem, of course. Everybody's bilingual but us native born gringos. 
I don't know if this is Raymond behind the counter making my pollo and al pastor tacos, but it wouldn't surprise me. He knows his requlars, possibly family, and in a second my food is ready to go.
Nice. I rationed those tacos over two days just in case. Raymond's came through at a time of need. I'll definitely be back to try the burgers.

Me and two of my coworkers have a New Years Day tradition. We hit Raymond's on Cermak for some steak tacos. If you made a New Year's resolution to eat healthy, these tacos will leave that resolution unconscious in an alley with its pants around its ankles and bleeding from its ass...they may be the most unhealthy thing on the planet. But they are ridiculously good! Plus, they have the ability to reach back thru time and erase past hangovers. Getting the cheese is a must! Putting a slice of pasteurized, processed, American cheese-like product on tacos might seem like a sacrilege to some, but they are the key to making the whole concoction work! They put the slice between the tortillas. This acts as a binding agent and holds everything in place. The only thing is, they put onions in with the meat. If you don't like onion, make sure to let them know when you order.

One of THE BEST places in the city to go for tacos. The place is always super crowded...especially at night, but that's what it's about. It's not really Mexican food - but who cares - it's a taco! Stay away from the chicken tacos - they lack flavor. BUT, the whole steak taco with EVERYTHING including American cheese totally rocks. THIS is some good eating! Trust me!

Really fresh ingredients and friendly service!

The inside is pretty small but they are still able to accommodate for many hungry guests. Upon being seated, we were instantly given hot warm towels to wipe our hands, which is a very authentic Japanese thing to do before eating. We ordered the Takoyaki and Oyster Shooters to start, the Zuke Sake and Truffle Tuna bites, the Miso Salmon Roll and lastly the Seared Salmon and Albacore Roll. 

The Takoyaki came in a small bowl with 4 pieces. I have had my share of Takoyaki in the Chicago area and this one has the best tasting batter. The batter was flavorful in itself and did not need to rely on the sauces and octopus pieces in side for flavor. With that being said, the octopus pieces were smaller than all the other places we have tried, where we could have eaten the whole order and still not have come across a piece of octopus. Still a great appetizer to try and share with the table!

The Oyster Shooters we had here were the best so far! The Oyster itself was so juicy and the shooter had such a delicious combination of flavors between sweet and salty. 

The Tuna Truffle was incredibly buttery and the texture was amazing! The fish just melted in our mouths and we were in heaven until the last swallow. 

The Zuke Sake was a sharp and refreshing bite in comparison to the Tuna Truffle. The pickle garnish on top have a great slightly crunchy texture. It served as a great palate refresher. The salmon was so fresh and we were back in heaven with each chew. 

The Miso Salmon Roll had generous pieces of salmon topped on each piece, and there was crunchy asparagus in the roll itself to give a nice crisp texture. This roll was a roller coaster or texture which we loved. 

The Seared Salmon and Albacore Roll had a delicious smoky flavor thanks to the torching of the fish on top and a bit on the sides of the rice. A piece of like was garnished on top of each piece so the smoky flavor paired with the sour was fantastic!

We really loved the food and will be back to try all of the other menu items!

I have been coming to Sushi Dokku since the place opened up and I couldn't get enough of it. The atmosphere, the highly knowledgeable staff (I am gluten intolerant and this was one of the few places where I felt truly safe eating), and sushi chefs who delivered artwork. 

However, now I am looking for a new place to enjoy sushi and to take important clients/guests to. The place has downgraded considerably in the last 6 months. For example, a "tuna microgreens" roll no longer has microgreens in it; they have been replaced by onions. With a hefty price tag of $14 for a roll that is 1/3 onions, you are better off ordering two tuna avocado rolls at your local neighborhood joint. I was also given sauces which previous waitstaff said I could not have because they contained gluten. Step up your game, Sushi Dokku!

In the meantime, I'll be enjoying my sushi elsewhere.

I don't get it! How can their sushi be so flavorless, un-inventive and BLAH, and how are they still in business in the uber competitive West Loop-Randolph area? 
They tout themselves to be "fancy sushi" place, not the $7 for 7 pieces of a basic dragon roll, but they did NOT deliver. 
Another pet peeve, they aren't listed on Open Table. You gotta call them or go through their crappy website interface to get a reservation. 

We desperately need more sushi options in the area. I'll make do with Tanoshii for now.
Amazing sushi. Staff was attentive and it's fun to sit at the bar and watch them prepare the sushi. Their attention to detail and dedication to a perfect presentation was Appreciated

Such a lovely time spent here with friends over the weekend. After reading many reviews I was dying to get to this place to try the sushi! And I'm glad I did because it was delicious. All of the rolls were really great, but there was a truffle tuna sashimi that really stood out. 

My boyfriend is allergic to seafood and mentioned he had heard great reviews of their spicy chicken wing starter. Even though they're traditionally only served in the downstairs restaurant, our server gladly brought up an order for us. The sauce was Sooo good...just the right amount of heat! They're also one of the only bars I've ever been to that has sake on draft! It was really good too--not too heavy, not too sweet. 

We ended up being one of the last tables in the restaurant and never felt rushed at all. Our service was excellent, and I look forward to returning to try more rolls!!
Authentic, artistic and alluring sushi. Creative in presentation and combining ingredients.

By chance, we stumbled on this cute sushi joint one night! Luckily for us, Girl and the Goat was way too packed and this lovely sushi bar was right down the street! 

We sat at the sushi bar, and watched the sushi chefs make beautiful rolls, sushi and sashimi. Everything was so delicious! There was a raw beef roll (I must apologize, the name escapes me), that was AMAZING! 
All the sushi chefs were amazing, but my personal favorites are the two in the pictures that I posted! They were so nice and helpful and watching them work was like magic! They even gave us a little sample of some dishes that we did not think of ordering!! 
Fish was fresh, food was fantastic and staff was AMAZING! 

Don't miss out on this place or you'll regret it! (And try to sit at the bar and talk to my new favorite sushi chefs :D)

Came here after a yoga class with a friend around 8:30PM. It's a classy place but no one was giving us weird look for being in yoga clothes :) Started with some drinks and edamame. The Japanese Old Fashioned made with Japanese whisky is a MUST TRY if you are an old fashioned addict like me. It's probably one of the best Old Fashioned I've tried in town. The Japanese whisky carries a woody, smokey taste which gives the cocktail a very deep flavor. 

We order three rows. The best one was the Spicy Miso. Tuna with arugula brings a fresh mix of flavor I've hadn't tried before. The other two rows were average. I'd say the rows were a bit pricy ($15-$17) for its worth.

But overall, I'd come back for the ambiance, cocktails and would try some items from the grill next time!
Expensive but amazing food! Every dish we had was an experience. Staff was wonderful. Atmosphere is nice.

This is definitely my favorite sushi place in Chicago. Always good quality, fresh products, great atmosphere and service. 

I'm not such a fan of the tuna tataki-- maybe it's the mustard sauce that I don't like. The dragon roll here is awesome, as is the octopus and the crab. Definitely a solid spot.

If a place has sushi that my husband tolerates then they get 5 stars. Sushi hating husband jokes aside, I do think that the quality of the food and the presentation are top notch here.

My friend suggested sushi dokku and went as far as saying is the best sushi she ever had. Whats left to do but waze it there, right? We called around 8 and they told us we would have a guaranteed table at 930. We didn't, but it didnt matter. We had drinks by the congested bar area. Later on we sat down and ordered, shishito pepers, miso soup, fire roll, dragon roll and godzilla. Typical and safe but very delicious.
Their drinks and their food prices are a big on the higher side. A drink that comes from a 4 inch can should not cost 19 dollars, but hey i was in a good mood and it was Friday. However if this place can convert my husband into a sushi eater than it deserves a plethora of stars in my book.

I finally decided to try this place out again after coming here a few years ago and I'm glad I did.  We ordered the special nigiri of the day, grilled hama kama, the ecuador maki and crispy maguro maki. The fish was very fresh and the hamachi collar portion was huuuuge. My favorite maki was the crispy maguro, mostly because there were bonito flakes galore (i love bonito flakes!!). I was happy about the food quality, however, I feel like it's a tad bit pricey. I'll stick to my go-to sushi spot and sneak this place in now and then when I need a little change in my routine.

Food is good.
 It was just okay for the service because thr server Stephanie doesn't know what's going on with my food cause she even asked me if I got my food alreadyfor both my salad and my udon ( in my mind it's her responsibility to know if I got the food or not and she could have checked from the kitchen after firing)... The managers tend to be my servers because they were the ones who were accommodating me and getting my order .
 I ordered the dessert from the manager because she's   somewhere else and 2 minutes after, she just came and just dropped the check quickly without asking if I'm interested with dessert then she just realized I'm still waiting for my dessert that I ordered.... She didn't have the presence of mind throughout the night...

Managers were attentive and helpful though....

Food is good here, though quite basic for the price. I thought the customer service could have been better, I had long wait times between being seated/ordering drinks/ordering food. It did not even seem too busy in there at the time so it was surprising. I ordered the Sake Flight which was a selection of 3 sake tasters, though there was no explanation of what each was or what they would be twinned well with. The bar downstairs is good to go for a couple of drinks before/after - lively vibe though quite small.

We didn't have reservations here. I had a Mexican joint lined up for dinner but my buddy called an audible for sushi. We headed to sushi dokku. I didn't expect to get seated at the main restaurant but rather their bar. It was about 9pm and they were able to seat us downstairs. Dark with low ceilings the space is largely taken up by the bar. The booth seating surrounds it. We were able to get seated immediately. There were plenty of rolls
to choose from and I don't think that it is worth me recommending the ones we ordered in particular. What is important is that all the rolls we ordered we really good, not blow your mind. Definitely order sake and enjoy the bar scene. If you are looking for classy get seated upstairs, if you are looking for a more party bar vibe with sushi head downstairs. Either way it doesn't seem you can go wrong. FYI great location too on Randolph street. Lots of people watching in the area.

3.5 stars rounded down to 3

I had really high hopes for Sushi Dokku.  I read several reviews and looked over the menu before trying it out last night with 4 other friends. 

We had a 5:15pm reservation (Chicago Restaurant Week + Saturday night?..makes it hard to get a later reservation).  The hostess was friendly enough when she got off the phone and addressed us (I was worried about bad service after reading the reviews).  We were seated in the corner booth.  It was extremely cold the entire night.  I noticed that one by one all of my friends and I started putting our coats back on.  

LOCATION
It might get hard to find parking, but they do offer valet.  You can even download the valet app. & have the driver bring your car through the app.  It's located by Little Goat and a whole bunch of other hot restaurants.  Inside, it seemed very dark and minimalistic/trendy.  It was hard to see what our food looked like without taking a flash photo of it.  As I reached over and took a picture of all of my friends' food, one of them jokingly thanked me for helping her see what she was eating.  

FOOD
I was really excited to try Sushi Dokky for 2 reasons: it is Chicago Restaurant Week and I really wanted to try their Tuna Truffle (I mean, seriously? I love raw fish and truffle, but the two together? I couldn't wait!).  Overall, they have fresh, beautifully presented dishes.  Some were better than others.
-Momotaro: Nigori Sake, Peach Nectar $11. This was really good. Light, refreshing, not too sweet. I refrained fro ordering another drink because nobody else ordered one.
-Gyu-negima: $11 Strip Steak, Green Onion, Garlic Soy Sauce. Very very salty! 
-Ramen: $15 Shoyu Miso Braised Pork Shoulder Broth, Star Anise, Spinach, Green Onion. Two of my friends split this and they both said it was very salty.
-Dragon: $15 Tempura Shrimp, Unagi, Avocado, Masago. Not bad. Not amazing. Just average.
-Fire: $17 Tempura Salmon, Avocado, Cucumber, Tobiko, Kaiware, Chili Mayo, Green Onion. This was my 2nd favorite roll.  I liked the sauce that it came with.
-Crispy Maguro: $13 Tuna, Red Onion, Fried Shallots, Maguro Flakes, Avocado, Togarashi Mayo. My favorite roll. I don't understand why it had to come out with a separate soy sauce dish...maybe to fill in some empty space?
-Tuna truffle: $11 Seared Big Eye Tuna,Truffle Sauce, Avocado. I was slightly disappointed with this one. It lacked flavor. They give you two generous portions of tuna with some truffle oil, but it wasn't very unique.  (Try the Tuna Truffle at Starfish Sushi in Lincolnshire instead!)

SERVICE
Our waitress, Aracely, was nice enough.  However, while talking to us, she leaned over and placed her hand on top of our water bottle. We were all slightly grossed out and taken aback, but nobody had the courage to ask for a new bottle in fear we might get our food spit on. My friends and I were talking the entire time, but I don't recall Aracely ever coming to ask if the food was ok. 

NOTES: 
-If you plan on coming during Chicago Restaurant Week, you might have to ask the waitress for the Chicago Restaurant Week menu.  We weren't given this menu until we asked.  Also, if someone orders from this menu, everyone else must order from it.  It's an "All or None" type of deal.  I must've made a face when Aracely mentioned this because she stated, "I don't make the rules."  
-If you bring a cake (we were celebrating 2 belated birthdays in our group), you will be charged $1.50 per person. Imagine coming with a large group.  I don't recall being forwarded about this charge.  

OVERALL
The food was pretty good overall.  The service was OK. I think you're really just paying for the location and vibe (which I can do without).
Wow is this place great. The food is way authentic and the chef from Argentina trained in Japan and is very authentic. One of the best places I have eaten at in chicago.

We had dinner at Sushi Dokku on a Friday night and enjoyed everything very much!

Décor: Outside it looks like a regular place, but as soon as you reach for the big wooden door you are immediately sucked into a sushi restaurant vibe. This place isn't massive but it has a decent number of tables and some seats along the bar as well. Since it's a corner lot it gets plenty of natural light from the windows along the wall and everything is nicely taken care of and clean (including the super heavy chairs!). I don't know that I'd recommend this place for a huge group; they could make it happen with enough notice but try to roll in no more than four deep if you don't have a reservation (they do take reservations, just NOT OpenTable).
Bathroom: unknown

Staff: The hostess was friendly and was very nice to squeeze us into a table for an hour and a half time slot (more than enough time for us). Our waitress was also very friendly and just the perfect amount of punctual. Also, our sushi came out relatively quickly (no huge wait).

Food: We kicked things off with a glass of champagne and then moved on to our standard starters: Edamame, Miso Soup, and Chicken Gyoza (all were good, but needed to be hotter temperature-wise - personal preference of course). We then moved onto the sushi: Dragon Roll (delicious!), Spicy Tuna (so tasty and SO FRESH!), Godzilla (yum, outstanding! our favorite roll of the meal), Ecuador (good, but the cilantro muted the taste of the other ingredients), Unagi nigiri (my favorite, so good), and Hamachi nigiri (good, but sliced a bit thin...).

Value: It's sushi, in the West Loop, so it's a bit pricey. However, nothing on the menu stands out as being "over" priced.

We had a great meal and already cannot wait to come back. This is our new favorite sushi place in West Loop and the city as a whole!

Dokku made me a happy guy on a 4-stars...

We entered on a jam packed weekend night.  Waited, sat at the bar.  It was thoroughly entertaining watching these guys slice fish, sushi like ninjas.  Further, reach into a bubbling vat of grease to pull out whatever tempura was going- crazy men.

The food, the sushi itself was quite good.  The flavors were nice, but nothing blew my mind for the prices.  I will go back time and time again.

Small restaurant and couldn't accommodate us so they sent us on their main floor downstairs to Booze Box. They allowed us to order off the menu, make up our own rolls! We love exploring the unknown so the flexibility is much appreciated!

Must get: truffle tuna nigiri! To die for good!

We made up our own roll of spicy salmon with avocado. They added sesame seeds to crust the rice. Such a great idea!

We also made up a second roll. Crab, spicy tuna, and eel. They made the most delicious roll ever! Crab meat wrapped on the inside with alternation spicy tuna chicks and grilled eel on top. 

Loved the experience!

Overall, another good sushi and Japanese-inspired restaurant now in the West Loop area. The interior decor and ambiance is really nice. The restaurant is big and more spacious than I expected. Good cocktails and generous sushi rolls.

Another happy hour thing going on here as they have $1oysters which is right up my alley.
I showed up at 5:30 on a Thurs afternoon and it wasn't too packed. I got a seat at the bar and ordered a glass of rose' which was really good. My girl showed up and met me at the bar so it was time for shit to get real in reference to ordering some goodies. There was a couple of regulars sitting on the other side of me letting me know what was good and what wasn't so that was helpful.

We got 8 oysters (4 each and what was on the happy hour menu) and the caviar which was very delicious. The Hot Daisy Roll (Albacore, spicy mayo, massage, cucumber, soy paper and lime) came highly recommended. Its reputation is well deserved as it was definitely the best roll we had. We also got the Dragon and the Tuna Microgreens rolls...very good as well. They have good sushi here...no doubt! The guy behind the bar, Kyle made us a special roll that was pretty good as well. The Chamomile Whiskey Sour drink was out of this world good...so good that we had 3 of them. 

I definitely recommend coming here for happy hour or dinner as its really a nice place with good food and good service!

This place is hit or miss. I have gotten food poisoning once.  Other times it has been great.  I have been about 5 times. Last time we sat by the kitchen, had awful service and left smelling like fried food..

This review is for the bar located beneath Sushi Dokku. (Booze Box) My friend was celebrating her 30th birthday and we went here this past weekend. Like most people said once you find the restaurant that's half of the battle. When I got there no one was standing outside in the alley so I just randomly found a door and went in. Thankfully it took me downstairs to Booze Box. The music was on point and the drinks were good. I would recommend the Momotaro. Very refreshing and not too sweet. My other friend raved about the Kurimi. There cocktails were all delicious! Loved the atmosphere. The bar is on the smaller side, but I would recommend it for an intimate birthday party.

Delicious! Attentive staff. Quick service. Clean restaurant. Sushi Chef Timmy (sp?) & the other chefs prepared art for us to eat.

Our waitress, Melissa, was professional & friendly - there when we needed her and gone when we did not

We sat at the bar to watch the culinary artists at work. It was entertainment & a meal!

The Maki rolls were beautiful & hit the spot. It appears that many of them are original rolls you won't find anywhere else. The Ecaudor was awesome! Chef Timmy recommended his favorite to us, the Onion Panko roll. He did not steer us wrong. I can't wait to go back & try more off the menu.

This review is for both what we had in the dining room upstairs and the drinks and snacks that we had in the speak easy bar downstairs, Booze Box.

For dinner appetizers, we started off with the usual: Edamame and Miso Soup, which uses White Miso, Tofu, Green Onion and Wakame

I know it's a little strange that we ordered mashed potatoes at a Japanese restaurant, but this is probably one of the best mashed potatoes I've had: Jagaimo, which is Whipped Potatoes with Cucumber, Carrot, Egg & Japanese Mayo. Pretty sure that Japanese mayo might have crack in it.

$1 oyster happy hour from 5-7pm: They have East and West Coast oysters. For me...it's West Coast all the way! They were these tiny little sweet morsels of delectable ocean-y goodness. Not too brine-y.

Oh, try the fried oysters too. It's deep fried in a light batter and some other good stuff. Just try it!

For those of you who know me, you know that I LOVE UNI!~ So, of course, I tried the Uni nigiri, which was phenomenal. I've missed uni so much...

Here are the rolls in order of favs:

Hot Daisy Roll: Albacore · Masago · Spicy Mayo · Cucumber · Soy Paper · Lime
Ecaudor Roll: Maguro · Hamachi · Flying Fish Roe · Cilantro · Wasabi Mayo · Jalapeño
Northern California Roll: Fresh and Soft Shell Crab · Onion · Masago · Avocado
Now, for the fun! The bar downstairs is super duper dark, and exactly what you would want in a speak-easy. There are no signs about any sort of bar downstairs, so you really have to know about it. They offer some GREAT snacks that go with your drinks, and the service is awesome. The manager, Linda, really wants to ensure that everyone has a great experience...thanks for taking care of us so well, Linda!

We got a few of the specials -- Shot and Beer: Evan Williams whiskey and your choice of beer. We chose Kirin Lite to chase our whiskey. That always equals fun times!
I also tried their whiskey sour, which was nice and sour. I love sour!

Here are the bites in order of favs:

Pork belly -- this comes with a poached egg on top, so when you break that yolk. OMG food egg porn!!~ This dish is rather savory, so make sure you maybe order something pickled on the side.
Drowning Tako -- Octopus, vinegar, olive oil, lime, garlic, pickles. This dish comes out with each portion separately, so it's actually a perfect dish to enjoy with your drink.
Chicken Karaage: Japanese fried chicken, rosemary & sage. This was very crispy but juicy on the inside. I think it might have had a little too much ginger for my taste. But for those of you who love ginger, go for it!
Okonomiyaki: Japanese pancake with cabbage, green onion, katsu sauce, and wasabi mayo. I like my pancakes pretty thin and crispy, and since this one wasn't as crispy as I would like, I would have to put this at the bottom of my list of favs. Altho the flavors were definitely there!

Tonight was the 1st time I tried Sushi Dokku!! I was completely surprised by how yummy the food was! There was amazing chef special nigiri's- could have had all of them! The Big Eye Tuna Truffle was outrageous! Tuna Poke was a special and really great.  My friend is gluten free and they were happy to accommodate almost everything on the menu.  I had an interesting drink of warm sake w/Chambord- really interesting! Looking forward to going back!

This review is just of their oyster happy hour. They have oysters shipped fresh daily from both the east and west coast. The west coast oysters are smaller, less brine-y, and more flavorful, and are $2 each naked. The east coast oysters are larger and $1 each naked. Any additional dressing or having the oysters fried is $1 more per oyster. Our waitress was very knowledgable about the oysters and when she didn't know, she went to find out for us. Good experience, very relaxed, and not too crowded.

Best sushi in the neighborhood. You know how there's fancy sushi and just lunch sushi? This is the fancy stuff. Everything we tried was awesome. The atmosphere would be good for a date night or just dinner with a friend. Not a comfy kick-back place but a place to focus on good food.

Since I live close by, Sushi Dokku has always been my go-to sushi joint when I don't want to travel far. Prices are high, but it's located in restaurant row, so that's not shocking, Plus, the food has always been at least 4 star worthy. During my last visit, however, the service was disappointing enough that I may not return. I'm not normally one to knock a restaurant down stars because of service, but the waitress was really rude! 

A group of four of us came in at 7:30pm for a reservation for my friend's birthday. They seated us right away, took our drink order...and then 20+ minutes passed. No drinks, nothing. Finally, we asked to order food and the waitress acted like we had asked her to strip down naked and dance for us. We all separately thought it was one of the more awkward moments we've had with a waiter/waitress. Not to mention the fact that she acted shocked and appalled by a few of our orders (we ordered four maki rolls, a few appetizers, a fish entree, and a small soup...besides sharing the soup between the four of us, it wasn't that crazy of an order). The night continued, our food came, we ate, they took away our dishes, etc. By the end of the meal, we had all decided that service was a two at best. And then to top it all off, they charged us for my friend's birthday dessert!! Sure, her boyfriend had asked for something to be sent out for her birthday, but that's normal! If they don't allow complementary desserts for birthdays, they should have said something! To charge us for a birthday dessert, which we did not choose (and was honestly pretty mediocre), was absolutely unprofessional! 

I am typically very forgiving of bad service, but the audacity of the waitress to make us feel awkward and then to CHARGE US FOR THE BIRTHDAY DESSERT was pretty unforgiving. I'm getting angry just thinking about it.

Went there on a busy Thursday evening without a reservation. Luckily for me and my friend we were able to sit on a booth where you can observe how the food is being prepared and if you pay close attention you can learn how to make a sushi roll. I suggest you go there dress to impress cause that's how the atmosphere felt ,which was quite intimidating for my friend since we both wore shorts and didn't know what to expect from the place. Overall the food and the service was superb wouldn't mind going to Sushi Dokku again.

Prime spot for an awesome sushi experience. Fresh fish, sumptuous sauces, and friendly service. Highly recommend the makis. 
During happy hour, the oysters are $1.

Never disappoints. 

Great sushi and great atmosphere. 

I've visited multiple times and always leave satisfied. Try the fried mochi for dessert.
It's upscale, but overpriced. Portions were small and expensive, but only came for appetizers. If your really hungry probably not the place to fill up on. Service was 2 thumbs up!

Okay, so I've been to the old Sushi Wabi and always thought it was just okay so when this place opened we've wanted to go for quite a while just to see if it would entice us in the Randolph foodie zone and well, it didn't really entice us too much. I have to say, the atmosphere is sexy, its dark, dim lit, has that intimate trendy feel to it so I definitely think it's great for a date night, however we sat by the windows where their long wooden booth is and I have to say that I felt like I was right on top of my neighbors which kinda isn't ideal in my opinion. I don't like to hear other people's convos since I'm a little ADD so  it's hard for me to focus, especially when different kinds of sushi is being served.

We didn't have reservations on a Saturday night so I definitely recommend you make them, but you can always grab some sake at their cute bar. The service was good as the hostess was able to sit us by a window which I asked for and our server was pleasant throughout our meal. They do have happy hour oysters every day for like $1 and they were delicious and $2 with the fixings so that's as cheap as it gets and I definitely had some east and west coast ones. Now onto the sushi, the rolls in my opinion are very few and a little too much for me with their over the top ingredients. You can't go wrong with some spicy tuna and spicy salmon rolls and I absolutely loved their dragon roll but for $16 it isn't cheap but definitely delicious. My hubby got some tuna roll that was also on the pricey side and it didn't have rice in it which I wish it said that since it left him hungry for a lot more. 

So overall, Sushi Dokku is eh, I can't see how it can compare to it's neighbors like Girl and the Goat and Au Cheval but I guess if you want a sexy night out with your girlfriend and you want some basic sushi in a trendy environment then you can check it out. But I wouldn't come here if I was so hungry, because you will end up spending a pretty penny and may leave a little hungry, or at least we did. Get the drinks though!

Pretty good sushi but not the best service.

We had pork gyoza, unagi nigiri, spicy tuna and the dragon roll.

Unagi nigiri - really really fresh unagi - prob our fave dish of this lunch.

Spicy tuna - a close second. We really liked the big cuts of tuna in this.

Dragon - really good pieces of shrimp. I always Order the dragon rolls.  Liked it but it was overshadowed by the other two rolls.

Overall really fresh sushi but service could be better.

Came here around brunch time with a friend. Upon entering the small door, you will find that this restaurant is actually spacious. There wasn't that many decorates and had a dark theme (black on black), but I'm sure I wouldn't have mind if we went during dinner time. 

On a bright note, great service and good quality sushi. Was satisifed. Would come here again. We ordered 2 nigri nama sake (salmon), hamachi (yellow tail), and 2 rows: ecuador and fire. I recommend getting the fire over ecuador.

I got the Dragon & Godzilla rolls. Both were absolutely delicious. I have been trying to get here since they opened. I would have given a 5 star but the service was not that great. I think the waitress forgot about of several times. The food and ambiance made up for it. I will be going back.

My friends and I went to Sushi Dokku on a Friday night. I got there early and sat at the bar. What I liked about this place from the moment I walked in was how intimate and tiny the space was. I spoke to a very friendly and helpful bartender, and she suggested the perfect cocktail based on my preference. 

Even with reservations we had to wait a bit for a table, which was fine because of how small the place is. The drinks and food didn't disappoint, and neither did the service. We started the meal with Udon, Vegetable Tempura, and Pork Gyoza. The Udon had the most delicate and delicious broth ever and I could eat bowls and bowls of it! The tempura and gyoza were good as well.

We ordered a variety of rolls and they even made specially vegetarian rolls for one of my friends. They came with special sauces as well, including a truffle sauce. We also ordered raw and fried oysters ($1 each!) and they were delicious. The fried oysters were overpowered by the presence of too much wasabi, but good nonetheless.  We ended the meal with fried green tea ice cream and an apple cake of some sort. I loved the ice cream -- it was not too sweet and a perfect way to end the meal.

I would recommend Sushi Dokku for a fantastic sushi/udon/oyster experience. I will definitely be back for more Udon!

Cocktail on point - chamomile whiskey sour. 

Service? Phenomenal. Attentive, not pretentious, genuine. 

Fish is great quality, rolls were tight, presentation is beautiful and clean. 

We will definitely come back again!

This place is small but I recommend sitting at the bar. The food is amazing, you cannot go wrong. Definitely our future go-to sushi joint around west Loop. Good japanese whiskey selection as well. After dinner, go downstairs and grab drinks in the speakeasy!

Wow! On business trip in this beautiful city in mid August, and a warm evening. A friend recommended this very hip spot. Atmosphere and staff are awesome and feel neighborly. The food even more amazing. You must try it yourself!!

Unexpectedly, ended up eating here because of the crazy thunder storm on Saturday. My wife, baby daughter and I got caught in the crazy thunder storm this past weekend walking to another diner for dinner (mind you, we are out-of-towners). The thunder did not let up for a long time so we decided to just dine here since having a baby always a ticking time bomb. The ambiance was definitely not baby friendly but more a cool/hip spot for a tinder date. The host downstairs, (forget the gentleman's name, Ruben?) but was extremely kind and provide excellent customer service. He moved our table to a bigger seat so our baby daughter can sit comfortably.  The 2 waitresses who waited us were more than eager to accommodate to our needs. What could've been a disastrous evening was saved by the awesome host and generous waitress. Plus the food was delicious. Good food always taste better around good people. Thank you

Sushi cravings kick in with the weather finally warming up and sushi dokku is always a great choice... This trip included: dressed oysters ( happy hour special) which were good but a little on the salty side; very fresh seared tuna with a kicky miso mustard sauce (tuna tataki); agedashi tofu which was one of my favorites -perfect meld of salty/crunchy/umami; crispy maguro maki (delish); northern california maki (yay soft shell crab!).... Perfect summer evening meal with built in entertainment ( always fun to watch sushi chefs at work)
Good not great sushi with a nice decor and solid bar. There are better japanese restaurants around but this is my favorite among the $$ price point and the west loop location is terrific.

I love that there's a great place in the heart of the West Loop where you don't have to make a reservation MONTHS in advance to get a reservation at a decent time. We called only like a week ahead of time!

The service here is super friendly. I love sitting at the sushi bar and chatting with the chefs. The rolls are great -- they'll even be happy to make you something by request that's not on the menu!

For those non-sushi lovers, there's also some other Japanese selections on the menu as well. 

Another highlight- this is one of the few Asian places I've been to in the city that has made decent cocktails!

My sister in law recommended this place to me  and praised this place like anything. Ever since then I wanted to go here. The first time I went here, there was a wait for two hours...so we ended up going to some other place. This time I made sure I reserve a table beforehand. 
Now the food- being a vegetarian, it's difficult to really enjoy a sushi place but sushi dokku lived up to my expectations. They had only four vegetarian sushi (don't remember the names)and I ordered all four of them. They were simply awesome. Omg, I really have no words to describe how good they were. It's definitely a plc to try :)
I'm giving four stars n not five as the appetizers disappointed me...fewer vegetarian options n not worth ordering at all :/

Very happy with my experience overall. We received our food fairly quick, which is kind of worrisome at a sushi joint, however, it was very fresh and tasty. The presentation was phenomenal I must say! They even had a kids menu which is always a plus. The Miso Soup was the best I've tasted in Chicago, by far, and it was the biggest bowl ever. I had the Fire role with fresh Salmon instead of Tempura Salmon and it was fantastic. My only complaint was our roles were extremely spicy and we ran out of water early on, having to go most of the dinner without water. But as I said, overall it was a happy experience!

What a sad excuse for a sushi restaurant.

I stumbled across this place right when it opened at 5pm and sat down at the sushi bar. Wildly over priced nigiri and PRE CUT...... I watched the sushi "chef" pull the fish out of a container and stick it on my disgusting, hard, unflavorful sushi rice. All wrong. I feel like I was robbed, esp for the price I paid.

What made my experience worse was the chefs just standing there not doing anything. They just took their time, drinking whatever they were drinking and shooting the shit while I was sitting there starving.

I watched the guy make my micro greens sushi roll, set it down behind him...and there it sat...for 5 minutes. Finally the other chef cut it and served it to me. By that point I was fuming and the roll itself didn't even taste fresh at all. 

Do yourself a favor and avoid Sushi Dokku at all costs.

The only decent sushi in the hood.  Good quality ingredients.  Price is $1-2 higher but Sushi Dokku tries to give you value for $$.

You come here for the Happy Hour!  M-F from 5pm till 7pm.

Oysters -- $1 with 4 kinds.  3 ways to enjoy them: 
(1) undressed with lemon only for the adventurous;
(2) dressed with soy, wasabi etc for the semi-adventurous; and
(3) dressed that is fried with scallions for the less adventurous.

Drinks/Cocktail -- well balanced with standard pricing of $12-13.

Venue -- clean, just right table spacing.  The best seat is the sushi bar (without the sushi fish staring at you).  A great view to inspire making sushi at home.

Service -- great and informative.  Quick clean ups.

1-star less because of a seemingly standardized menu.  Nothing stands out to me.

I love this place. This is the only place in Chicago where I can have good sushi. Their sushi is not only tasty but also beautiful. All the staffs are friendly, and it's inexpensive compare to other popular, pricy restaurants with worse sushi.

Anyone remember Sushi Wabi on Randolph? So sad when that closed down, but a few years later.....the same people behind Wabi opened up this amazing place. Had a phenomenal dinner here last night with our group of 6. Had a 7:30 reservation not in the actual restaurant, but in the speakeasy bar located downstairs (to enter you have to find the door hidden in the alley). The bar has about 8 tables for diners, & we were seated right away in the big one in the back.
Sushi Dokku brought over some of our favorite rolls from Wabi's menu. These were (and also our favorites are) the hot daisy roll and the equador roll. We had tons of apps, favorites were the tuna tataki and hamachi. Besides those two rolls we had a couple more, some nigiri, and steak. Couldn't pass up on the sake, had a couple bottles- one is my absolute favorite sake called Red Snapper by Narutotai. Yes it's almost $100 but it's THE BEST! Finished the meal with vanilla, green tea & passion fruit mochi. Gotta get the passion fruit- amazing. 
Overall, amazing sushi that you will pay a lot of $$$ on, but worth it.

Came here for the oyster happy hour and was pleasantly surprised.  Very good quality oysters for a great price.  The iwashimizu special was also very tasty and honestly I forgot what cocktail I had but it tasted great.  Clearly I only have good things to say about this place so if you're looking for some quick eats and drinks, this is your place.

Sadly, if you're starving and looking for a wholesome meal, try looking for AYCE sushi places instead.

Unique, creative sushi/Japanese dishes that don't mask the fish but compliment it very well. My gf and I split everything: the hot sake carafe(s), edamame, hamachi cold starter, sea bass bites, fire roll and the hot daisy. The service was nice and not overwhelming. Food comes out pretty fast. Space is pretty dark and finely light.

I called because for some reason open table showed them completely booked but they put me down for a reservation easily same day, and when I showed up they sat me at a nice, large booth.

FYI, they have oysters happy hour 5-7PM, $1-2. I was too late but maybe you can check it out!

I want to come back and try more stuff!

Just stopped in for a bit. Were lucky to find two seats available at the sushi bar. Service was spot on. We shared a spicy tuna roll and it was fantastic; very fresh with a lot of flavor. I look forward to going back and having more sushi off their menu.

This sushi spot on restaurant row certainly stands out. Strategically placed next to a primary pig joint it would have to be a standout. No fake crab here. The prices reflect quality ingredients and preparation.

Drinks
Whiskey and cider; great fall drinks, sweet & tart
Bourbon Bomb; lemongrass syrup and basil
Wish I would have went with a sake concoction in hind sight

Apps
Mini filet; wasabi butter, whipped potatoes, mushrooms
This is a great warm up to prepare for fresh fish -- don't miss it

Rolls
Northern California; fresh crab really makes a difference
Fire Roll; nice and spicy with great sauce to boot

I would suggest getting a seat at the bar. Bench seating for two is a cool twist. Sit back and watch the chefs go to work and sip a drink. It's definitely entertaining to watch the detailed knife work. 

We waited about 30 mins on a Saturday night which isn't bad without a reservation. Friendly and attentive service. The small plates are worth the trip. They offer up unique dishes and nigiri bites that cannot be rivaled in the area.

Tuna Truffle. 

It's like a blend of the very best best tuna nigiri and fanciest French fry you'll ever eat. I could have eaten 1,000 of 'em... if they weren't $9.50 for two. But it's absolutely a work of art and totally worth it. Basically my dream food. 

Get that. Get that and don't share it and savor every freaking moment of it. 

Also, they have a weekday happy hour that runs 5-7 with $1 oysters ($2 if you get them with the dressings). We went with a mixture of a dozen oysters, 4 different types of oysters, and then of those 4 we got 3 different types dressed and one plain. They weren't on par with GT Fish & Oyster, but that's a tough measure. These were still damn good and much friendlier on the wallet. 

We came here on whim, without a reservation and were sat after a small limbo period where they told us we needed to be out before 8pm, which was 100% fine. The front podium staff wasn't the friendliest and when thanked they just went with the too cool method of ignoring me completely, but that's okay, I'm used to it. Something about me just turns people stone cold. 

Inside was pretty swanky, ultra modern, and I was definitely expecting to see some $20+ rolls on the menu, but that wasn't the case. I think the priciest roll was $15 and very generously portioned. I was especially impressed with their spice levels - right on point for me. 

Their miso was meh. Not a ton of flavor but it was still only $3 and again, generously portioned. 

Event their drinks were mighty impressive, though my bourbon basil was by far the least favorite of the three we ordered. A tad too tart, sweet, sour... just too much at once. The Sakerita was light and airy and perhaps the least sweet margarita-type drink I've ever had -- so good! The pineapple drink looked like pure puree, but had just a tinge of a booze in the taste and couldn't have been more perfect. Def a dangerous drink duo. 

Our server was fine. Not overly friendly, no smiles, but efficient and still worlds more welcoming than the front stand staff. 

I'll absolutely be back. Introducing everyone I know (who's worthy) to that Tuna Truffle.

Food is good but the service is not up to standards. Server took forever. She got lost a lot of times. We waited for oysters for 40 minutes, by the time we got them they were sitting on ice water. Seared salmon is amazing. Take out its better, I'll keep on doing that for now on. Also when we were done and waiting for the server once again, the plates were cleared and the amaebi sweet shrimp heads came, they asked us if we would be interested in them?! Uhhh yeah, we were wondering where they were.
Super delicious, fresh sushi. Steamed chicken dumplings light and tasty. Ramen is amazing. Can't go wrong! Great service too!

Unexpectedly  Excellent.

Any restaurant with the name Sushi in their name is an instant turn off. The first thing that word brings to the mind is all the generic basic sushi places you see in the suburbs. One's that make the most basics of sushi with absolutely very little to absolutely no creativity and heart. I am happy to confirm Sushi Dokku is not one of those places. It is a good example of what great sushi can be. 

On my quest to find the best ramen in Chicago, my next stop was high-five sushi. Inside high-five looking downstairs were many people sitting on the steps with drink in hand looking like they were waiting to use the restroom at a crowded bar/club or a concert like venue. As I jumped and hopped across these lovely looking people I discovered a extremely cozy bar that serves ramen that seats a capacity of at most 15 to 20 people and was told by a lady the wait was an hour. Being as hungry as I was, even my most favorite food in the world was not worth a minute wait so I left and walked around the corner and looked up, there was Sushi Dokku in front of my eyes. I asked if they had ramen and they said YES! 

seared salmon roll = awesome. The layer of rice was perfectly thin and the masago was perfectly small, fresh and flavorful. the combination of all he ingredients was absolutely perfect.

ramen = awesome. Broth was perfectly flavored with a hint of sweetness. The pork shoulder was tender and carries a nice meaty flavor. This could have been the perfect ramen. The only things missing was maybe some bamboo shoots and a nice soft boild egg and a few slices of Berkshire Pork Belly.... droolz.

They have kizami which is excellent for nigiris and sashimi. Basic sushi places wouldn't have.

Great oysters! Excellent sushi! Everything was great. The cocktails were "meh" (but we drank them without complaining). In hindsight we should have gotten wine or beer. Definitely my new go-to sushi place!

Delicious as always. I first visited Sushi Dokku due to the overwhelming 5 star reviews on Yelp and they sure lived up to the hype!

This was our 3rd visit to Sushi Dokku and everytime we have tried different cocktails, maki rolls, and desserts.

This visit we had the calamari appetizer and edemame. Calamari was cooked the perfection and virtually no excess oil on them, they also came with a delicious dipped sauce.

We split 4 rolls: Dragon, Northern California, Fire, and Smoked Salmon. They were all wonderful! My only issue with the rolls was that although the fire roll was said to be spicy I did not think it was at all.

I tried their seasonal Chili Mojito which had a chili infused gin, mint, and homemade sour. I highly recommend it if you are one who enjoys a nice bite with their meal.

For dessert we had the green tea cheesecake with brownie crust, espresso mochi, tirimasu mochi, lychee sorbet, and some sort of apple cake with a homemade caramel sauce and ginger ice cream. Their lychee sorbet was spot on. It was sweet and refreshing after such a saucy and delicious meal. The other desserts were almost just as delicious but my heart goes out to the lychee sorbet!

Wonderful experience and will be returning on our next trip to the big city!

Went here for Valentine's day dinner and was extremely impressed!

The place is small and cozy. The service is fast and helpful.
The prices are very competitive, much cheaper than I expected. especially for the quality and taste you get!

The Ecuador roll is incredible! Don't be intimidated by the jalapeño you can't feel it at all. Soooo gooood

The scallops and tofu are also delicious.

They have a variety of fancy drinks to everyone's flavor liking, from dark to clear liquors, from herbal to sweeter tastes.

Great spot for an intimate dinner, especially if you want to impress someone with great sushi, my bf definetely impressed me ;-)

I love this West Loop spot.  

Great sushi and great small plates.

The mini filet mignon with whipped potatoes is excellently prepared every time.  

I would love to see a bit more change in the cocktail menu, but the Bourbon Basil is my go to drink.

Check out Booze Box below Sushi Dokku for after dinner drinks.
Not sure how this place ranked at 4 stars. I was actually disappointed. Over priced and not exactly the best quality sushi aside from the super white tuna. Which were $6 each! Ridiculous.

Very good. Sushi was filling and extremely delicious. However music was a little too loud and place has low lighting. Definitely will go again to this very trendy, restaurant. Hopefully waitress will be a tad more attentive.

This place had a nice atmosphere and decent music. Never got to try the food because the customer service was pretty terrible. The place was crowded with about a projected 25 to 30 min wait. When the hostess took our name she suggested we go downstairs to their new bar area to wait. We said great we'll get drinks while we wait. Downstairs was darker and moody, with a DJ and people sitting at the bar, booths and standing along the walls. We stood at the bar for 25 mins waiting for the bar tender to acknowledge us, only for her to say "one moment" then serve more than one patron who clearly just walked up after we had been waiting.

When we finally got a drink - they didn't have my choice of liquor - the drink was weak and simply nasty. We went back upstairs to wait, only to see a new crop of people waiting and being sat at tables ahead of us. When we asked about our seating we were told we were next, but a different couple was sat instead of us. The hostess gave us an "oh shit" look then whispered to the other hostess. Needless to say after a total of 50 mins waiting, plus being overlooked at the bar and for seating, we left and went elsewhere. We won't be back...too many choices to put up with bad customer service.
I have this place on my to do list! Thanks for the clear up!

One word...phenomenal! Mariano must be the best sushi chef out there!

What we ordered: 
tuna truffle...mouth watering
Ecuador...orgasmic
King crab bites...husband said great
Allergic to shellfish therefore chef made dragon with salmon instead of shrimp...wow

My new favorite sushi place - possibly.

Let's acknowledge that West Loop has an amazing roster of restaurants that offer unique and great dining experiences. Getting that out of the way - Sushi Dokku is a star player on said roster. 

Hidden off the menu (or at least I couldn't find it) the spicy tuna and spicy shrimp rolls are fantastic. Major thanks to the other useful reviews that referenced to it. They were so good that a friend who tagged along on the visit ordered a spicy tuna for himself after trying mine. The drink menu is pretty interesting and I went with the bourbon basil which had a nice twist thanks to the fresh basil leaf. Granted I only had one drink, I'd like to say the drinks are made on point and are very strong 

The service here is a great but note that like every restaurant on the Randolph strip the seating availability fills up quick so plan accordingly. The real gem to this spot is the basement which is hidden off to the right when you walk in. The more relaxed atmosphere and groovy tunes make the dining experience all the more better. I highly recommend trying to get a seat down there if at all possible. 

If you're in the mood for sushi and are in West Loop, this is your winner!

Good sushi. Cool vibe. Slow service. We ordered a lot of different rolls, some unique others standard. Nothing stood out as being amazing though. Had a few drinks that I remember being pretty good. Good sushi in general but way overpriced. Ended up leaving still hungry and having spent way too much money. There are definitely better places that are cheaper as well.
Awesome sushi! These weren't your typical sushi rolls. The menu was inventive and fun, and everything was delicious. I absolutely loved the cilantro in the sushi....so delish!

Pleasantly surprised by the food here as I've always considered myself as a sushi purist and avoided  trendy sushi joint with crazy cream cheese rolls. We were taken through the kitchen to the secret bar downstairs, felt very exciting. A less hectic route would be going through the back alley. They serve the same menu and some Japanese snacks. I'm  pleased to find takoyaki, okonomiyaki, karaage  & grilled yellowtail collar on the menu. All were delicious, though the collar was rather difficult to eat in the dark. Also had the hot daisy (meh) and the seared salmon & albacore roll (yum!). Bartender was very friendly and took great care of us throughout the night. Recommended!

Classy, trendy sushi restaurant. Went with my husband and sat at the bar. It was fun to observe all the prep action right behind the bar. Sushi was delicious and drinks were cool, the menu (while on the smaller side) could certainly be grouped with places like Momotaro in the sense that you find unusual items. The service was a bit slow, not because it was so busy but rather because of what felt like a pretty blasé attitude. Felt a little like we weren't trendy/chic/sleek enough. It's of course very possible that we really aren't ;) but a little more engagement wouldn't have hurt.

Went back because the ramen was just that good.  We sat at the bar upstairs, and the noise level was more reasonable, we could easily hold a conversation.  Also sitting at the bar, we could see all the food as it comes out, and we impulsively ordered the Northern California roll.  It looked and tasted great!  The green tea cheesecake tasted exactly like you think it would, a heavy cheesecake that was green tea flavored.  I personally did not care for it, but the girlfriend enjoyed it very much.  Lastly their customer service is excellent.  There was an error with the receipt that I didn't catch until a few days later, and it was easily fixed after contacting the restaurant.

This was a really great dinner. I got the chef's choice of sushi and thrown off by how creative and exact the meal that I received was. I was craving a really random meal and got something unexpected but really clean. The agedashi tofu on the side was a bit small but delicious, really liked eggy center. The atmosphere is enjoyable, it feels typical of a high end sushi place. Service was great, toned down but attentive. Can't say enough good things.
Great restaurant...definitely try the Hamachi and the Hot Daisy.  The service is okay.
One of the best sushi places here in Chicago !

I had been wanting to eat at this sushi spot for months now. I walked past it many times as I was on my way to other spots in the west loop. 

Finally made it to the restaurant last weekend and the place was really full. Only had to wait about 30minutes to get a table and was excited to try it out. 

After getting sat we were greeted by our server who said she would be right back with waters. After she returned at least 5 minutes later we ordered two drinks. Those drinks which were actually pretty good took over 10 minutes to be delivered to us. This was repeated when we ordered a second round of drinks with our rolls. 

Not sure why the service from the bar was so slow but it definitely took away from the experience. The sushi was a little above average but nothing special. 

Overall, I would say this is a little above average sushi spot that has some service issues. The staff was at least apologetic to the slow service but that is definitely something to consider when choosing this restaurant.

Came for the oysters, stayed for the sushi. Happy hour oysters ($1) were not that good, east coast oysters way too briny (2 kinds) west coast were ok (1 kind).
Dressed oysters ($2) are much tastier.
Choice of rolls seemed pretty basic, but very fresh. Seared salmon roll was good, with a bit too much citrus.
Good takoyaki appetizer.
Delicious drinks!

If you were looking for that cool place with unbelievable sushi! You found it. The appetizers and drinks are fun and they also great Roman!  The staff are some of the most friendly people you'll ever meet! My wife and I and four kids love the place or having them delivered.

I'm not a big fan of sushi but this place was great and very accommodating. I don't like the seaweed so I always get my roll made with soy paper, this isn't available at all sushi restaurants so I was glad they had it. The udon soup is delicious. I love this place and will definitely be back!

Great Sushi, Horrible Service!!! The girl at the downstairs bar is obviously not use to handling multiple tables and is very inattentive. Not a place you want to come and treat yourself because a treat is NOT what you will get! Blaaaah!!! Other great places in the area!

We picked Sushi Dokku on a whim around 8:30 on a Thursday evening...given how packed the neighborhood was at that time of night, we appreciated the hostess's second and third look around before announcing a 20 minute wait.  She was very accommodating, and we ended up getting a table about 10 minutes later.  

The menu is stuffed with delicious sounding hot and cold small plates, rolls, chefs choice nigiri, and standard sashimi/nigiri choices.  

In the end we chose the tuna poke special, a salmon collar (amazing), and two rolls.  

The fish was delicious and fresh in each dish, which is arguably most important, but the other components of each dish didn't add much--maybe even detracted from the full flavor experience.  
The avocado that came with the poke was cut about a day too soon and the sauces on the rolls overpowered the veggies and seafood inside.  

Nothing bad, just not as awesome as I was imagining while reading the menu.

Tasty rolls, a bit overpriced, weird atmosphere downstairs.

Sat downstairs in what they call the 'booze box.' There's a live DJ at 9:30 and I can see it getting more cozy and swanky as the night progresses, but for a 8pm dinner it was a little off so would suggest sitting upstairs if all you want is dinner and drinks.

Had the Tako Yaki (octopus dumplings) to start, which were delicious and then two rolls - the crunchy maguro and the Ecuador. The Ecuador was worth every penny- stuffed full with freshness.

Overall a decent experience but nothing to write home about.

Poor service,Bad coordinate.Very slow. And waitress not really know their food that well.Food quality very poor. Sashimi are not quality fish. soy sauce no flavor rice is not taste like sushi rice. The worst part is they are extremely expensive for the low quality food. Feels like they serve 
All you can eat cheap bad quality sushi for Fancy restaurant price.They charge $9 for two piece of salmon sashimi... Is even more expensive than the fancy Japanese restaurant. Also very limited menu Will never go back.

The only disappointment I have is that living just blocks away, I didn't try this spot sooner!  We started off with some tuna truffle thing...not very large size-wise but very tasty.  Then we moved on to some rolls and my favorite was the Godzilla.  Lovely presentation and lots of flavor.  Was a little bit pricey but definitely a good go-to sushi spot if you're looking for a nice night out.

My only complaint is that I discovered this place while new to the city and between jobs -- there's no way I can afford to eat here as often as I'd like to. Which is at least once a week. 

Up to a point, sushi is sushi is sushi. The fish is wonderfully fresh, and that's great, or it's not, and you never go back. Rolls can be nice, I suppose, but I tend to favor sashimi, nigiri, and other more flavorful (and less cream-cheese infested) options. Which, truth be told, are more or less the same across any good sushi restaurant.

All this to say-- not so with Sushi Dokku. Every single bite was an adventure of awesomeness. Among many, many other items, the one that sticks out is the yellowtail belly with jalapeno? Yes please. Check this place out.

You know that phrase "let's go on that ride again?" that's exactly how I felt after leaving Sushi Dokku for the first time.  It was absolutely mind blowing how delicious and creative the sushi rolls were.  

After a long day , I wanted to get sushi and a drink.  After seeing many positive Yelp reviews for Sushi Dokku I thought, "why not, let's give it a whirl."  On the outside, it is an unassuming place on a busy and bustling street.  The inside is an intimate candlelight atmosphere.  

I started with a sake-tini cocktail which was the Japanese cousin of a dirty martini.  It was delicious and the ginger-stuffed olive was a lovely finishing touch.  

Onto the serious stuff! For appetizers we got the tempura and the agadashi tofu.  All of which were delicious and I found myself being "that person" and eating every last crumb.  For dinner, my husband and I shared a variety of rolls:  Ecuador, Northern California, Fire, and the seared salmon.  Needless to say we were hungry. 

Everything exceeded expectations.  From the quality of food, portion, to even the platter they were presented on, everything was delightful.  The Ecuador was by far the favorite and I don't plan on sharing it next time.  

If you're around, swing on in.  It won't disappoint.  I cannot wait to go back and I also plan on going for a happy hour too!

Friday night my friends Candice G., Ericka A. and I were stumbling around Fulton Market looking for a place to grab some dinner. In actuality none of us were stumbling, Candice was practically running, Ericka hobbling on her one workable foot and I'd like to think I was walking a normal human being type of way. We came upon Sushi Dokku which is right next door to Girl & A Goat. If I ever have to choose between sushi and anything else, I'm going to pick raw fish. And in we went!

We were dressed in varying fashions and honestly I felt under dressed for such a classy establishment. It was kind of funny walking in because we got the hostess treatment you would expect when walking into a classy place. Indifferent, acted like we were wasting their time by inquiring about the wait/availability, and when we left they didn't acknowledge our departure. Even when super friendly Candice said bye, we got a zippo in return. I scolded Candice for being too friendly but it just can't be helped with that one! :P

I have to say that our waitress was super nice and sweet which was a nice change from the hostesses. They had some amazing oyster special that my buddies really enjoyed. Prices are a bit higher than other sushi joints but it's a bit more fancy and things are done a bit better here, thus justifying the prices.

The cocktails at Sushi Dokku were friggin amazing. Sake cocktails to be precise! After practicing the name like three times, I said the name of the one I got 'Sakerita' wrong to the waitress. I brought shame on my entire family. I tried a couple of the other cocktails which were also very good but hands down liked mine the best. I really don't think you can go wrong with any of their sake offerings though. Sushi Dokku has some nice tables but you can also just chill out at the bar and grab some of these fabulous cocktails sans fishies.

Sushi Dokku doesn't play around with their spice. Spice is my kryptonite and I crumble under it's powers. I keep trying to order & eat it more and more hoping I'll build up an immunity but let's look at this realistically, Superman never built up an immunity. It got him every time. In a hope to over come the green glow, I ordered the Spicy Tuna Roll which aside from the fresh fish has chili sauce, masago & mayo. My mouth was on FIRE! What I did get of the flavors was delicious though, excellent spicy tuna roll and nothing knocked against the spot for their spice level. Just know when you get any of their spicy rolls here, they mean spicy! 

Best thing of the night - the Tuna Truffle. You read that right. Tuna. And truffle. Seared yellowfin tuna, truffle oil and avocado. And let it be known, it was some of the most beautiful knife work I've ever seen on an avocado. Truly art on a plate and delicious in my belly. I've never had anything quite like it and would go back to Sushi Dokku for these bites alone. There were 4 pieces. 3 of us. Who ate that last one?!

The head sushi chef understands that people who have lived in Japan don't want all the bells and whistles and mayo and avocado and makes sashimi and nigiri to order. Ask for a crab hand roll. Now my go-to for Japanese meals.

Seriously impressed by this new randolph, old sushi wabi spot

Apps: Miso soup, seaweed salad, ginger salad, gomae and sashito peppers. All SO GOOD. The ginger dressing was delicious and the seaweed salad had a very interesting texture.

Sushi: Truffle tuna bite ---this BLEW everything out of the water. It is better than Union and Sunda's tuna truffle. So fresh and well balanced. 

Rolls: Godzilla, fire, hot daisy. Our favorite was the Hot Daisy and the Godzilla. The hot daisy is SERIOUSLY spicy. The fire is good, but we were taken aback that the salmon was cooked which was a bit disappointing. 

Service is a bit lacking, but I will absolutely be coming back here!

Definitely the best Sushi restaurant I've been to in Chicago. Very cool vibe, great location and excellent food. I'd recommend the Gyu Negima to start and you really can't go wrong with any of their roles.

I was sad when Sushi Wabi closed on Randolph as it was always a great place to get fresh sushi in a contemporary environment.  So imagine my delight when some of the owners of the old Sushi Wabi and opened Sushi Dokku at the corner of Randolph and Green.

Located in what used to be an old "greasy spoon", you will love the contemporary interior with the high ceiling, the large sushi bar, the small cocktail bar up front, and plenty of tables both inside and out.

I had made a reservation but somehow it had gotten misplaced.  But the hostess was great, saying that she would get us seated as soon as possible and she kept apologizing for the error.  Within 5 minutes of the time of our "lost" reservation, she came over and got us from the bar and had a perfect table for two located along the wall.

The menu is full of wonderful things- from raw oysters (we started with the west coast ones and they were terrific!) to miso soup and the expected edamame, plenty of rolls, nigiri and sashimi.  They also have a wide range of sakes and beers.

I asked if I could get some vegetables steamed and our server came back and said that they couldn't steam them but that they could boil some asparagus.  Works for me!

The veggies came up as the 2nd course and then the sushi followed.  The winner of the night was the "Tuna Truffle" which was two pieces of tuna over rice with avocado and truffle oil.  Yes it was $9.50 for two pieces but it was amazing!

They also were able to make us a plain tuna and avocado roll which wasn't on the menu but came perfectly made to the table.

I did think that the sashimi was a little skimpy.  They sell it in orders of 2 pieces each (about $8.00) but instead of the meaty "chunks" I expected, I got some thin slices.  Good tasting- but a bit on the light side.

If you drive- while there is a valet sign on Green Street- you will probably more readily find the valet on the Randolph side.  Valet will run you about $11.
