Some of my favorites include: Spicy Tuna, Halloween roll, Cherry Blossom roll, Sweet 16 roll, Sexy Mama roll, Sandwich roll, Mexican roll, Dynamite roll, Spicy Crab Cucumber roll, and Boston roll. 

The veggie tempura is also delicious, you get quite a few pieces for only $5 bucks. 

This is my favorite place to order from and I'm so glad my neighborhood sushi joint is this amazing; thanks South Kawa!! 

.... now I'm off to review the menu for the 200th time to order something new!!! Happy sushi eating!!! :)

Apologies for not updating since my last review!

I came in here last spring around April 2013 with a girlfriend to indulge on mercury. Yay salmon and delicious fishes! This place definitely changed since my previous review. It is no longer a sushi buffet that it once was. 

However, they went onto bento boxes and lunch specials along with the Japanese basics. Streer clear if you were expecting the high end awabi.

The prices are average and portions are good. Definitely try this sushi joint since it also comes with a romantic ambience. 

I had to say, I came in several more times prior to April and the chef had an oopsie with the miso soup. They  mistaken vinegar for the seasoning. Lol. The waiter and host was very apologetic and did not hesitate to replace when a fresh pot was made. Awesome service and smiles can be found in here.

I was going to order Ramen, but they only have fried soba today. So we ordered shrimp fried soba and beef soba. Beef was just ok.
The IIT roll is worth trying....
Best thing here is the red bean mochi ice cream!!!! Try it!

I came here with a friend last week. I've been meaning to try this place out for a while since I live across the street from it. I don't think there has ever been a successful restaurant on this block for a really long time. Other than George's of course. But its predecessor and the stores on the same block have straight up STRUGGLED for so long. There used to be a pho place, a Chinese restaurant, a toy store, etc. 

Therefore, I'm happy that this place is getting some recognition and breathing some well deserved LIFE into Bridgeport. It's always so stodgy and rigid. I've lived here all my life and although this probably wouldn't be my first place for Japanese food, I would definitely go here for something casual.

The decor is very nice. It is a nice upgrade from the stereotypical Chinese restaurant with white walls and Chinese lettering on the wall. Instead, there are leather seats and attention to detail. The service was friendly. They didn't have shot glasses, so they gave us tea cups instead. We ordered the Fallen Angel and the Yakuza. I enjoyed both. I was surprised by the Fallen Angel because I've never seen a restaurant create a roll with seaweed inside. 

Some things to point out, they need to work on maintaining a professional and courteous environment. They were speaking Mandarin from across the restaurant. Also, their AYCE sushi is a bit overpriced. I'd rather go to Wasabi Cafe since it's cheaper. Plus, why don't they have in-house menus? Why are we ordering from the same menu as the menus they put on people's doors? Now this is me being nit picky, but I don't like their plates. The plates they use are found in other Chinese restaurants like Chi Cafe and others in Chinatown. I've lived in Bridgeport all of my life and I'm Chinese, I recognize plates. I would recommend that they keep things simple and use white plates to let the colors of the food stand out, rather than having sushi that is wrapped in a dark green seaweed, sit on a green plate. 

Thanks for contributing to the neighborhood, but there are still some things that need to be fixed to accommodate the local area.

Excellent low key sushi place with amazing prices and artistic menu. If your looking for great sushi without the horse and pony show (aka jacked up prices) come here and support a Bridgeport spot. The menu has great fish and unique rolls with something for everyone (yakatori, udon, teriyaki). The fish is fresh and the white tuna melts in your mouth (like it is suppose too).

I came here on a Friday evening with friends for dinner.  It was packed upon arrival so I would recommend that you make reservations if you want to eat here with more than 3+ ppl.  The wait was not that long for me as it was just for a party of 3 ppl.

Food:
All you can eat Sushi Buffet for $24.88-the presentation and sushi were both good!

Salmon (order 1 pieces) - comes with a piece of salmon on top a ball of rice..tastes good..yum!!

Spicy Lover Roll (5 pieces)- comes with spicy tuna, avocado inside, & fried tempura..delicious, and not really too spicy (for ppl who can't handle spicy food)

Volcano (6 pieces) - comes with shrimp tempura, avocado with spicy tuna on top...yum and it actually looks like a volcano when it comes out with fire! :) 

Fuji Roll (8 pieces) - seared pepper tuna, avocado top w/ white tuna and 3 different sauces..tastes good!

Yakuza (8 pieces) - spicy assorted raw fish, topped with marinated salmon & wasabi mayo..yum

Edamame - comes out warm!! :)

Snow Shirmp Tempura (10 pieces) - tastes good and the shrimp pieces are not huge so don't worry it won't fill you up!

*I would recommend ordering the Sushi Buffet because prices are costly if you are just planning on ordering multiple rolls.

Atmosphere: nice decor, and clean!..not really big though..which is why the wait might be longer if you come with a group..

Parking: street parking with meters.. didn't have issues finding parking though!

I would definitely come back again if I was craving a sushi buffet.. better than Sushi Para..

It has good lunch specials. You can get two sushi rolls 9 dollars or three sushi rolls for 12 dollar. Every lunch special order comes with miso soup. It's pretty filling. The sushi rolls for mixing and matching are plentiful. My favorite is the crunchy crab. Lunch takes forever though. If order online, good luck. If you order at restaurant, good luck. There have times when there are only two couples in the restaurant, and it still takes a while for the food to come. They are slow either way. I've tried ordering for dinner and they are faster in the nighttime than in the afternoon.

Sunday at 5pm. One other table. One waitress.

The restaurant has a great setup and looks nice.

I ordered gyoza as an appetizer, which came at the same time as my food. I also ordered a Avocado roll and a Crunch Philly roll (see photo) and a sweet potato roll (not pictured). The Philly roll came out of the kitchen without the crunch and I sent it back and that's when they dusted it with crunch. I also intended on ordering fried rice which they were all out of. I've never heard before but ok.

Went for dinner yesterday with the husband. Were seated right away, for a saturday night it was pretty empty. Its BYOB and the prices are very reasonable. Place is not big which makes for a cozy and intimate setting. Service was great. Ordered the spicy udon noodles, the edamame, the Mexican roll, chicago fire roll and dragon roll. The noodles were not spicy but were tasty, husband appreciated the bacon in them, im not a bacon fan but they were still tasty. Edamame was good, its pretty hard to screw that one up. Now on to the rolls...they were all good but the mexican roll was life changing! We ended up ordering another one because we couldnt stop thinking about the first. Its exactly what you would imagine if you ever wondered what a Mexican sushi roll would taste like, absolutely divine. Cant wait to go back!

I usually LOVE this place and it's our favorite date night spot, but we visited last night and things really seemed to have changed for the worst. 

The food was still good--I want to make that clear. The service, on the other hand, left a LOT to be desired. The usual waitress (Olivia) wasn't there, and while we ordered 4-5 separate menu items from the waitress taking our order, two of them just never came out. Additionally, we sat for 10 minutes without anyone approaching the table (it's a really tiny place) and even after the sushi was served, we were still missing plates and silverware. At the end of the meal, we were the last table in the place, and it took us forever to flag down the waitress for our bill. 

I love the sushi, and I love the place--especially the proximity to where we live--but they definitely need to improve upon the service.
Having tried many different sushi spots in Chicago, this is one of the better ones! Nice ambience, cozy and small, sushi was great for the price. Definitely coming back with my little one.

I'll give it about 3.5 stars. I came with a Groupon and surprisingly they let us use it with the buffet. We went during lunch and only one other person was in there. Waitress did inform us we had to pay for any food that's uneaten.

Chicken Yakitori - We ended up getting 2 orders of these. It wasn't bad, but we wouldn't order it if it wasn't for the buffet. 

Snow Shrimp Tempura - Not bad, but it's like walnut shrimp without the walnut. 

Spider Roll - We ordered 2 of these too. This was really good.

Crazy Salmon - This one is fried. It was ok, but I probably wouldn't order it again.

Eel with Avocado Roll - We ordered the eel with cucumber, but they gave us this. I liked it, but my sister isn't a big avocado fan so she only ate one.

Sweet Potato Roll - Lately, I've been seeing a lot of people rave about this. I had to try it. I liked that it had a crunch to it, but not sure if I would order it again as the sweet potato flavor was light.
 
2 Piece Masago - My sister ate this.

Overall, I think the food was very fresh and I enjoyed most of it. I believe they are a bit overpriced. Buffet options didn't even have unagi pieces or any of their signature rolls as options. For the price they charge, I think they should maybe offer a little more.

Fresh and tasty sashimi and rolls tucked away in a quiet, small restaurant.

The salmon sashimi was very buttery tasting and cut in nice thick pieces.  The fallen angel roll had just the right amount of spice and the addition of the seaweed salad inside gave it a nice crunch texture.  Spicy tuna handroll was also very good and had a hearty fish to rice ratio.  If you check in on yelp, they give you a free order of edamame (pretty decent portion too!).  Anaconda roll was good too.  

Overall, its a good place for a quick sushi fix with decent prices and BYOB!  Nothing fancy or frou frou.

This place was okay. We came here with a livingsocial that I needed to use up before it expired.

We didn't get the buffet since we normally don't eat too much, but we did order 5 rolls for 2 people. The sushi was okay. Nothing special about this place. I would put it as average.

This place caught my eye as I was driving to a different restaurant for lunch and I am glad a turned around. Sort of caught me by surprise (in a good way) once I got inside. Cool, simple dining room / atmosphere with nice music playing. The waitress was very nice and personable, and helped me find the best bang for my buck between the lunch menu and the full menu. She made sure to point out that their lunch menu hadn't been updated, as they have since reduced the price of their 2/3 sushi rolls, which is great. Sushi was excellent. The bathroom was nice and clean, which is a huge plus for me. 

The ONLY thing I wish they could've provided us with is the wi-fi password. The restaurant is in a service 'dead zone' and it was tough to get a decent connection. A gentleman who sat a couple tables down from me had the same problem and asked the waitress for the password, but she didn't know it and that was that. Obviously, this wasn't a huge deal and I wasn't going to have her go find out, but hopefully management will see this and be able to provide customers with their password in the future because people love wi-fi, amirite!?!? :)

Anyway, It was a nice, relaxing, delicious experience and I'd go back in a heartbeat.

What a charming little place with gracious service, a pleasant atmosphere, and delicious food. Who'd have thought such a place existed in Bridgeport, a place better known for eating establishments like Ricobene's and Fabulous Freddie's?

I dined here with a friend and we shared gyoza (ohm nom nom), yellow tail jalapeño (spicy goodness), and chicken yaki udon (noodles from heaven). We also were fortunate enough to be here during maki lunch special hours. Two rolls for $10!

Everything was fresh and tasty! The timing of the food was spot on, and the waitstaff was friendly and offered great suggestions.  

I will definitely be back if I'm in the area and am looking for good quality sushi, great service, and an environment that is relaxed and pleasant. 

All in all, a very good experience.

Decided to take a chance on this local sushi place that just opened a month ago, and I'm glad I did. The service is outstanding and the owner Leo was incredibly helpful in making a few selections for a customized party platter I was getting for my wife's birthday.

My favorite roll? The Fallen Angel - spicy crab meat w/seaweed salad, crunch, and avocado topped with seared scallops and tobiko. Tell me that doesn't sound delicious.

All my party guests thoroughly enjoyed all the rolls, and loved the quality (TASTY!) Loved that the sushi wasn't loaded with rice like other places. I will definitely be coming back to try the ramen which I was told is made with homemade noodles!

First timer. Pretty much yelped it in search of a sushi place.when I first walked in it smelled funny.The waitress was nice but the food was OK not thee best.The waitress was nice and she recommended the shrimp with spicy sauce and that was good as an appetizer.too bad they don't offer desserts!

This is my second time going here and my husband first time. The restaurant is not to big but a nice size to dine in. The restaurant had great service and the food was delicious and fresh. We had the rock shrimp tempura with the spicy aioli sauce and the sushi/sashimi deluxe combo. It is located in the heart of the Brideport neighborhood. One thing about sushi is you never find it much on the south side since it's usually downtown or up north. I would come back to this place since it's not that far from where I live at. I would recommend this place to others.

The food is good. The service is pretty inconsistent. Don't bother giving them the free edamame coupon they put on here if you are not dining in. Petty. Last time I ordered take out, they honored it. Not this time.
Typical Chinese joint making sushi. The quality of preparation of the sushi and sashimi isn't impressive. It's a pretty good place to get a quick bite.
Sushi is decent, BYOB and it's also close to my home. My go to spot when I don't want to drive to any other neighborhood!

I do NOT recommend ordering the edamame unless you like devouring massive amounts of salt. Even though we wiped off the salt, the residue of sodium was still INTENSE.

We ordered the shrimp tempura, spicy salmon, spicy tuna and Mexican rolls. All were pretty good even though some of the rolls were falling apart as we picked them up. 

All-in-all "A-OK". Extra star for being so close to home!
Great food and great service.

One of the best places for sushi on the south side.  The service is friendly and helpful.  The fish is fresh and the ramen soups were tasty.  We went early and got some nice street parking.  The server gave us some fried oreos.  I hated it but others loved it.  it was complimentary.   I will go again.

I was there with my daughter and I had ramen my daughter had the stir fry udon. My bowl of ramen felt like a joke. Big bowl less than half was ramen with 3 pieces of pork chop, and the flavor was very bland. Wasn't worth the $13 for a bowl of ramen...my daughter's udon was ok, more tastier than my ramen.

I have had the WORST experience I've ever had ordering delivery in my entire life from this place. Estimated delivery time was "Within the hour" - the food took an hour and 45 minutes. (I literally live 4 blocks away. ) I called the restaurant and they said it'd be here in 2 mins.. 15 more minutes so by and I call again. This time, they tell me they're sincerely sorry and I will be receiving 15% off. I thank them.. I'm not trying to be a bitch-- I'm just hungry! Finally, when the food arrives the driver tells us he doesn't know anything about us getting a discount -- he's just the driver -- And we end up paying full, price, cash for cold soup, soggy rock shrimp, and not enough soy sauce. Thanks for nothing!

I'll never eat here again.  Our server was so rude that she completely ruined our dinner experience.

First off, this place is BYOB so my husband brought some quality German beer.  Our server gave us a PLASTIC cup.  Seated right next to us were rows and rows of nice wine glasses, and she gives us a plastic cup?! WTF? When he asked if he could have a wine glass instead, the server looked annoyed and said they're not supposed to give wine glasses to those who bring in beer.  However, after we insisted on a wine glass, she begrudgingly let us have one and said she'd inform the manager.

For those who don't know, SK has a $25 AYCE sushi special all day, everyday.  Our server initially informed us that we have to eat every piece of fish or else they charge $1 for every piece of sushi not consumed.  No problem, that's how it usually is in most AYCE sushi places.

My husband and I can eat A LOT of sushi, and we were both starving.  We initially ordered 6 rolls and a handful of nigiri.  When the server came to get our order, she told us that 6 rolls was too much and she was crossing off two of them to start with. Um, okay... shouldn't that be for us to decide? Whatever.  Anyways, we got our rolls and nigiri and finished EVERYTHING, except for some of the rice from the nigiri.  I feel that many of the nigiri pieces we ordered had too much rice, so I pushed about a third of each piece aside.

When the server came back, she explained that she should charge us for the rice we didn't finish, but she was going to let it slide this time.  I stated she told us that they charge for each piece of FISH we didn't finish, NOT rice.  She said that nigiri rice is special, and that if we ordered a second round, she would charge us for not finishing the rice as well.  Again, WTF?

Although we probably could have eaten another roll and a couple more nigiri, we were so turned off by service at that point that we just wanted to leave.  In addition, the quality of sushi seems to have gone down since the last time I came here, or maybe I just didn't enjoy it as much because of the rude service.  Anyways, sad to say, but I'm never coming back here.  I'll just go to Hing Kee in Chinatown when I want my cheap sushi fix.

Bridgeport.  All-you-can-eat sushi.  'Nuff said.  5 stars.  Go there.

Oh, you want an actual review as well?  Okay, I'll oblige.

I'd heard a rumor that there was a sushi place opening in Bridgeport.  I am initially skeptical (because as much as I love my B-port digs, I've been burned in the past by 'southside sushi').  This rumor then became that there was a sushi place opening in Bridgeport with a Buffet option.  I am officially intrigued enough to investigate.

I looked into it further.  Definitely sushi.  Definitely Bridgeport.  Definitely not yet Buffet-available.  Everyone talking about great sushi (still skeptical), but constant delay of the Buffet option.  I place a phone call and find out through some very broken English that the buffet will be open on Tuesday.  Others have claimed the same piece of news many Tuesdays prior, but I have faith.  I called that following Wednesday.  The Sushi Buffet is alive, and it costs $24.88.  A price well-worth investing if the legends are true.

That following Saturday, we make the quick trip over and at about 5pm, we're pretty much the only ones there.  Not a good sign.  But it does mean excellent service.  Ah, a classic sheet of paper to check off the things we want.  "Let's take 'em to school," I fictitiously stated to my girlfriend Char O. as I picked up the pen.

Miso Soup - Good.  Hard to ruin miso soup, and they didn't.

Rock Shrimp Tempura (with creamy spicy aioli) - Holy appetizers, Batman!!  This came as about a dozen fried jewels coated with a ziggy-zaggy drizzle of reddish aioli sauce.  Lovely amount of spice, perfectly-cooked shrimpies; ecstasy on a plate.

Snow Shrimp Tempura (with special coconut cream sauce) - What the hell - it gets even BETTER than those other shrimp???  If the rock shrimp are ecstasy on a plate, then these represent Food Nirvana.  I recall noting that if I were given the option to eat one food item all day, every day - these would likely be near the (if not THE) top of the list.

We ordered them both, Rounds 1 AND 2.  The spicy yang of the rock shrimp.  The cooling yin of the snow shrimp.  It's just... PERFECTION.

Oh, and there's sushi here, too???

For nigiri, I didn't see eel, but I did see Tamago (disguised as "egg omelet") and Maguro (tuna).  Both pieces were HUGE.  And not overloaded with rice, either.  Good tamago, and the maguro was quite tasty as well.  I can't tell what "good quality" is, but it tasted good to me and that's all I care about.

Then come the rolls.  Now their AYCE menu doesn't include many of the "Special Rolls", but it did include some and we tried the Dynamite, the Volcano, and the Yakuza.  [Insert "sleeping with the fishes" joke here, because I know I did at the restaurant (much to Char O.'s dismay).]  We also wound up trying their Spider roll, Dragon, Philadelphia, and the like.

I have to note: they have an Eel Avocado roll.  One of the best combinations of things I love in a roll, with no filler cucumber or carrot crap.  Just two delicious items wrapped up in a bit of rice and some nori.  Yes, please.  Keep 'em coming.

Oh, Round 3?  Char O.'s too full?  Nah, I'm gonna get more miso soup and ANOTHER ORDER OF THOSE SNOW SHRIMP!

We're going to go back.  There will be shrimps a-poppin'.  I think we ate about $28 apiece on those shrimp (the a la carte menu features those shrimp appetizers at $9/$10, but not sure how many more you get a la carte) - let alone digging in on the sushi.

Other pros:
- It wasn't very crowded, so service was fast (good refilling of water) and food came out pretty quick.
- The music selection (when we could hear it over the TV) wasn't bad.
- Rock shrimp / Snow shrimp.
- Washroom was pretty spiffy (although the lighted mirror was creepy and the men's room was painted Mango)

Some negatives:
- They asked us to share one order card.  That meant having to pay attention when they brought stuff out to figure out who had which rolls.
- When bringing out rolls, they rushed and didn't speak too loudly/clearly, though we did eventually figure it out on our own.
- It was dark.  Creepy-levels of dark.  But I could still see my shrimp, so it's okay.
- I fear that if we came here during a crowded time, the service would not have been so great.  There was not a huge staff on-site that we saw.

I really do feel bad when a sushi place's non-sushi items overtake the sushi items in noteworthiness, but I feel good that the sushi was still damned excellent and that just means those appetizers were THAT MUCH BETTER than "damned excellent".

Oh, and they're in Bridgeport!  Seriously!  And all-you-can-eat!!  Go there.  NOW.

You won't be disappointed.  But you WILL have a chance to enter Food Nirvana via the Yin and Yang of shrimp appetizers...

Sushi and Bridgeport do not belong together in the same sentence but the owners of South Kawa take a rusty tire iron and smash it right in there. 

Understand why most of you hear crickets when you enter this establishment: I'm from the neighborhood but after being here and reading the reviews, I can absolutely tell you the barnacles of welfare (can't afford it) and hipsters (too cheap to afford it) we have here won't give the proper business this place deserves. Thus, the emptiness you encounter when you arrive. But I digress. 

The RICE: Decently great. Not overcooked and had an almost flawless amount of salt and vinegar.

FISH: Pretty good. If it was frozen, I couldn't detect it. I occasionally dabble "my meat" (double entendre fun!) in soy sauce/fresh wasabi, it was not necessary here. I forgot to ask the chef where he buys his stock - I will be updating this review after I go again.

BYOB: Oh yeah, we brought a bottle of Pinot noir - but I didn't use a glass. No cork fee, either - because I used my teeth.

ATMOSPHERE: Clean, simple, nice. Where is everyone? Read my first paragraph.

SERVICE: Couldn't be happier with our waitress. She was very helpful and even threw in a free side dish. I generally tip well, but this time I tipped wellx2.

PRICE: Expensive? A little, but this is good sushi. Some places near Wicker Park have more expensive items for less the amount (and quality, for that matter) but still manage to get by. If their sushi wasn't at least "good" I'd be on board with the too expensive train. People bash this place because it's in Bridgeport and they expect cheap prices.

In short, I'm so happy we finally obtained a good sushi restaurant in Bridgeport but I'm sad that it may not last.

A sushi joint... in Bridgeport? It's true, & worth a visit; especially if you live in the neighborhood. 

I just tried South Kawa out last night after seeing it pop open a few weeks ago. I was wary... I did not expect a sushi spot to open up on South Halsted. However, I was hoping that South Kawa would add a little more diversity to our neighborhood dining selection, & it has. 

I was greeted & seated immediately upon entering by a friendly staff person. 

I was very happy to see how nicely South Kawa refurbished the former establishment that haunted this store-front space; it has a nice feel, decor, & an open kitchen/sushi bar area. 

I stopped in for a "light" meal last night, & ordered two rolls - their special Fallen Angel roll & a California roll (sans avocado!) The rolls were huge! Tasty, generous cuts of fresh fish, no over-doing it on the sauce or rice, & the coup de grace being... they did not mistakenly put any avocado in my sushi. Hooray! No allergic reaction = extra points, South Kawa!

I took a menu home with me & noticed that South Kawa has lunch specials... & South Kawa is just a few blocks walk from my apartment. Houston, we have a problem. Or should I say, Bridgeport, we have a problem. I might just satisfy my sushi cravings with ease & carry out more often that I realistically should. 

I enjoyed my first visit, & I look forward to visiting again. It is nice that there is a sushi place of decent quality in Bridgeport now, & I hope you will join me in giving this spot a try.

P.S. BOYB!!

UPDATE: I have frequented South Kawa so many times now... for lunch, dinner, & take out, & each experience has been lovely. I have never had a bad piece of fish, & the presentation is always beautiful (I went home with a gorgeous purple orchid from last weekend's dinner plate!) 

The servers are attentive & accommodating. I am so thrilled that South Kawa is here in Bridgeport... no need to travel out of the neighborhood for excellent sushi, atmosphere, service, & a BYOB treat.

Don't get me wrong, I love sushi and I LOVE my neighborhood.  I just don't really consider Bridgeport to be a sushi destination in Chicago. When this place popped up I had very mixed emotions.  I was excited to see a sushi place I could walk to but also extremely nervous about the quality and execution.  Well I finally tried South Kawa last night and I can say that it blew my expectations out of the water and made me drunk with pure bliss.

I had the spicy tuna roll, spicy scallop roll and fallen angel.  Each of them was fantastic.  Not only were they fresh and flavorful but as another reviewer mentioned they definitely come heavy on the fish and light on the rice which is the opposite of just about every other sushi experience I've had.  The fallen angel roll made me giddy to try the rest of the specialty rolls on the menu.  And try them I will!  I will definitely be a repeat customer (and repeat, and repeat, and repeat ...).

I also got the spicy udon which was just ok. I probably would not get it again.  The noodle itself was excellent but the dish consisted mainly of peppers and onion and was pretty one dimensional as far as flavor goes.

Last night I carried out but I'm excited to dine in with friends now that I know it's BYOB.  I like to drink sake.  It can get expensive.  BYOB sushi joints are where it's at people!

The prices were great as well.  I'm not sure what one of the reviewers was talking about when they said the prices were too high. All of the regular rolls range from $4-$6 each, the specialty rolls go from $9-$15, and both are a total steal for the amount of fish you get in them.

Now that I've been to South Kawa I still have mixed emotions.  I couldn't be happier to have a quality sushi spot in Bridgeport with the BYOB and price point bonuses but I'm also severely depressed by the potential damage this could do to my waist line.

After enjoying some take out from Kawa a few nights prior, a friend of mind wanted to  check out what the fuss was about. I too, wanted to see if my dining-in experience would live up the take-out I had. I had been to this location once before when it was Noodles-Pho-You. Now under new ownership and name this gem may be my new Bridgeport go to. 

My friend and I rolled up to Kawa about 3:45 today and were surprised to see that the open sign was not on. After investigating the menu in the window, we realized they take an hour break between lunch and dinner service (3-4). This would normally be no big deal, but my friend had to work down the street at 4:30. We decided to wait it out and hopefully get some quick sushi in. No more than five minutes later the owner strolls up to the door keys in hand and says, "do you guys want to come in?" We replied excitedly in the affirmative and enter into the restaurant. 

The owner, Kwok, showed us to a table. I felt kinda bad because the staff was in the dinning hall resting during their break which we had cut about 10 mins short. I was impressed in how quickly they all got up and began to prepare for us and the rest of the dinner service to come. Our server quickly came to take our drink and appetizer orders. Our food was served quickly and they were very understanding of our time constraint. 

Right away Kawa passes my number one indicator of a solid Japanese restaurant, their edamame was amazing! Steamed and salted to perfection. Wow, I'm an addict for this stuff. Vegetable and prawn tempura was fried nice and crispy and the vegatables were both varried (sweet potatoes, bell peppers, broccoli) and fresh.
For sushi we had the Volcano Roll (my pick) and Spicy Spider roll. Both were excellently crafted, fresh, and all to easy to whoof down in a hurry.

If you're in the area (Chinatown included) this is some of the best sushi I've had anywhere in the city. Service was impeccable, and the owner seem smart and dedicated to quality food.

Our waitress Colleen is pretty awesome. Came here with my brother and she was really nice and attentive. The food was decent and the prices were okay. A tad pricey for lunch but it was fun. The green tea was a little cold when it was served, but I drank it anyway. The chirashi is different since it's not in a bowl but in a fancy platter with a ball of rice on the side.

Took over an hour but I was told it would take longer so that's a plus. I ordered fried calamari and a few rolls. It was all great! Except for the calamari-it was cold AND had very little flavor. But we have ordered from her before by delivery and we loved it each time. It's our go to sushi delivery place.

Really, really great service here and excellent, fresh sushi. We had edamame, Fallen Angel, Salmon Skin, Spicy Yellow Tail, and Dragon rolls. All were delicious and reasonably priced. I will for sure be back.

Plus, I heard the server tell the table next to us that they are byo. Booyah.

This place is really convenient from where I live and is considered decent because there's not much sushi restaurants around the neighborhood. Everything is good and has a reasonable price. Lacking 1 star for the consistency of the rice. I guess it's because there's different chefs every time but overall it's decent. Could be better but it satisfies your sushi cravings! Overall pretty good.

best sushi in Bridgeport. go with the deep fried maki roll.... sashimi is on point. don't forget, you could get great noodles here. deep fried cheesecake for dessert is one hell of a ride for your palette..... have fun

This particular jaunt was on a Friday night in mid-June. The area was a little bit interesting, but we found parking practically right outside the door. The dining room had a candlelight vibe going on, and the hostess was warm and friendly.
What we had:
Vegetable Yaki Udon: Tasty, large portion, with good, fresh veggies!
Snow Shrimp Tempura: Very good! Only, it wasn't like described on the menu, it was like Honey Walnut Shrimp...
Fallen Angel: Crab, avocado, scallops, and tobiko. Yum!
Sweet Sixteen: The mango just made this roll POP!
Halloween Roll: This one was actually free! The server brought it to me mistakenly, so she told me to keep it and enjoy it on the house. It wasn't half bad either, even though I'm not the biggest tuna fan...

Everything was plated and presented beautifully that I almost didn't want to mar the artistry! Our server was patient, helpful, and even cracked a few jokes, making for a very enjoyable meal! I intend to return.

I regret not giving South Kawa a little Yelp love before as I have enjoyed dining there in the past.  We've lived in Bridgeport for 15 years and were excited to be able to walk to a restaurant where we could get a nice sushi experience for a fair price and BYOB.  Last night after failing to make dinner in a timely fashion my husband and I decided to walk on over.  It was about 9:00 pm so we checked their hours online and they were open until 10:00.  We grabbed our wine and walked over.  We arrived before 9:30 and were told they were only doing take out.  WTF?!  Why even have hours?  Not cool.  We walked north on Halsted to the Potsticker House.  They've never let us down in 15 years!

I love this spot. Its a great Bridgeport gem! Its about time we got a sushi spot in the neighborhood and now that we do I'm a regular. 

Everything they serve here is great! I know I have ordered one or two things that they were out of, I was not disappointed because I can taste their dedication to good, fresh quality food.  The All American Roll is one of my favorite dishes there. They give you a good portion of tuna. It's fresh and spicy. 

The unfortunate thing is that it doesn't get that busy which is great for immediate seating but no so great for my hopes of seeing this place stick around a while. I hope more people catch on to this hidden gem so that me and my new found love can continue to get to know each other better.

Come on people - go eat sushi at South Kawa!!

I think it's a great addition to Halsted Street.. The Sushi was good and the portions were large.  We tried a few of their specialty rolls and they were delicious.  The service was fast and friendly.  I would recommend if you are in the area.  There is street parking.

Edamame (free with Yelp check-in)-
Big bowl, hot, yummy!

Rock shrimp tempura-
Amazing!

Halloween roll-
Tuna on tuna...heaven!

Grayslake roll-
Crunchy goodness!

BYOB however they have complimentary hot tea for the cold bodies.

The server was awesome as well!

I love having this gem right down the road!

Food is usually good here (altho it may still vary sometimes) but the new waitress is what drives things down.  The old waiters/waitresses were so much friendlier. Easy with kids and always had a big smile to welcome guests. The new one knows nothing about the menu.  She took the wrong order for us but still said thats what we said and ordered.  Didnt want to make a big deal by that time bc we just wanted to finish and leave.  Our sushi plate was sitting by the chef for at least 10-15 mins b4 we asked if thats our food then she brought it over (not like she was super busy).  Totally not doing the right thing at the right time.  This whole experience really turned us down.
This place it's amazing  very fresh food cozy  spot .. I love the rock shrimp miso soup it's really good

Sigh.. I hate writing bad reviews for small business but hopefully this will help some people save their money.  I decided to try this place based on yelp reviews and came to a conclusion that these reviewers don't know sushi. 

Their sushi is mediocre at best.  I ordered the spicy scallop (almost no scallop) and they were tiny specs of scallop, a couple pieces of salmon nigiri (tasted like it was frozen before and tough), yellowtail/scallion roll (decent), tuna apple salad (the best thing I had there), and chicken teriyaki (horrible), overcooked chicken and bland sauce. 

Try it out yourself.

Food that i ordered tasted pretty good. Miso soup, spicy scallop HR were good. Shrimp tem roll was bit bland and salmon was not really fresh. I'd give 4 stars overall about the restaurant and customer service (a waitress called to clarify something) but delivery guy asked me to go outside to pick up my order. If i needed to go outside i would do a take-out or pick-up, instead of delivery which in this case wants me to go outside to get it.

Groupon brought me here.  I know if you want really fresh sushi in Chicago, you have to pay a bunch (seeing as how we're nowhere near any ocean).  I get that the fish comes in frozen and that they thaw it out in a refrigerator.  

However, the sake (salmon) sashimi i received was still frozen in the middle.  I just kind of thawed it out a little on top of the rice, not a huge deal for me.  Then again, I'm not that high maintenance.  If you are you'd probably not like that.

The fired rice was tasty and the gyoza was too.  And, once it thawed out a little more, the salmon was tasty too.

Wow I'm so happy that this place exists seriously!! Because of this place I can afford to eat sushi every week!!! Monday thru Saturday 10- pm ,3 sushi rolls for $9 and they are delicious! Come on now you can't beat that. !! I get sweet potato maki, shrimp tempura and spicy crab!! Ps the miso soup is perfect and an instant hangover remedy! The service is absolutely amazing!! The main guy , early 20s is usually our server he is one of the nicest people you will ever meet!! And I saved the best for last!!!!! It is BYOB!!!!!!!!!

I and two of my friends come here the first time. It has a great environment, and the service is very nice too. I might bring my other friends here next time. 

However, I think that the price is a little high since each of us spend 24 dollars and still didn't feel full at the end. I believe i will come again when they start their sushi buffet which is 25 dollars per person. 

As from the food, I liked Fallen Angel, it's very flavorful.  my friend liked Dynamite because it has cheese in it. The other friend liked Sweet sixteen which has mango in it. 

After 3 orders of specialty rolls, we are still not very full, so we ordered udon with shrimp. But like the other yelper said. The quality of noodle was great, they are chewy but the flavor of it is blah and i dont think I will order it again. 

Over all it was a good dining experience and I will recommend it.

i gave 4 star because it's a little pricy for me . :(
Groupon took me is there & loved it! Great food & service... The best part us that its only 5min away from home! Congrats on the success!

It cost me $80 for 6 rolls of sushi and a small assortment of sashimi. They were small rolls of sushi at that,  the menu is limited for sushi and unlike other restaurants, they don't have a book filled with pictures of their sushi creations. The waitress was very nice,  but I'm not rating her, just the restaurant and the food. Would I go back?  probably not. For that kind of money, I would rather go to the north side for some real Japanese food.

We keep coming back here since it's sooo good. I finally felt brave enough to get the sea urchin 'roe' - Uni. I've had it once and it was amazing - the sweet, savory, fishy delishiousness. I since have forgotten where we got it and couldn't find it again... 

Until now. Ok so you are eating something called "sea urchin gonads" if you try to find this online - but ignore that for a second.... It tastes amazing, kinda sweet, like mushed up roe but different. 
All the sushi is amazing, the fish has always been fresh, melt in your mouth kind of thing. 
The Fallen Angel roll tastes decadent and very good. We usually go for the raw fish and every time it has been flavorful and fresh. 
We also had hand rolls and either salmon or spicy tuna have been delicious. Their fried cheese cake desert thing is decadent and amazing if you have space. Yes, in this place you can actually get full on sushi! 
Don't worry about it being in Bridgeport - (i don't think anyone thinks about Bridgeport and sushi at the same time) - they totally know what they are doing, the staff is very friendly and it's BYOB so you can some money!

I tend to only write a review when a place stands out- either good or bad. Today, South Kawa pleasantly surprised my fiancé and I. 

We had the Tiger roll, Volcano, Grayslake roll and a salmon and cucumber roll. 

ALL were delicious. 

We've become sushi become sushi snobs over the years with 2-3 regular spots. We've happily added another place to our list!

I'm so pleased that there is a sushi restaurant in the neighborhood (Bridgeport) that has fresh fish and great service!  I could go here any day of the week for lunch or dinner. Great spot and definitely worth giving it a shot.

I am so glad that Bridgeport has a sushi spot!
I decided to give it a try with a Groupon ($15 for $30).
I went to Kawa with my mom on a Friday night, and the place was empty with like two tables. I love the atmosphere and the service was superb too!!!
We were served with hot tea and cold water at the same time!!! Our waitress was very attentive. We ordered the fallen angel, grayslake, and another special role (all were 8 pieces). The rolls were mediocre because it doesnt taste fresh at all. 
We couldn't even finish the three rolls and they were that bad. 
The total amount for the three roles + taxes was 45 something. I rather go eat sushi buffet!!!!
Anyway, i gave this place a try and i dont think i will go back to it.

Sushi in Bridgeport? Not gonna lie, I was pretty nervous. Luckily, my nerves have been calmed and my cravings, sated. 

I love my neighborhood and can't really imagine living elsewhere, but I've always known that there would be sacrifices made in order to keep my insanely affordable 2 bedroom apt with central air. Most notably would be pub trans and food options. Luckily, the latter has improved significantly over the past few years. 

Kawa took over the space that was previously Noodles Pho U, Thank God! That place was super gross. Enter, Kawa. They revamped the place and it looks like any other casual sushi joint, albeit maybe a bit darker. The service is a bit weird, but I'd rather have too much, than not enough attention. Same same in non dining situations ;)  Anywho - the rolls here a great. Everything I've had is super fresh, creative, and well rolled. No sloppy, falling apart sushi here, kids. I'll have to come back for the $25 AYCE. They won't know what hit 'em!

Also, delivery is super duper fast! 


*I know that I'm gushing about my hood, but you won't like it here. Seriously, there are no available apartments so you should probably just stay put. Stupid gentrification, leave my rent alone!

Wow, what a find in the Bridgeport area. When you think of bridgeport you really don't think about a great sushi place. I was really impressed with their all you cna eat deal. However, be warned, if you over order, they will charge you per piece and you can not take anything to go off that menu. 

So be careful.

The sushi was great, the soup was great, salad was ok and the service was excellent.

We got the Sushi Buffet for $24.88. If you're like me, there are sporadic days throughout the year when sushi feels like a necessity. It was time to knock off this new AYCE to the city.

The fish was bland (the salmon was not glossy/fatty, the squid was flavorless, and the white tuna/escolar was watered down - pretty standard blocks of meat that had been thawed/frozen/thawed/refrozen).

At least they could cover up the shortcomings of their fish in some good old American makis? Nope, they didn't do too well in that front either. Everything was doused in mayo. They actually used four different colors of mayo to draw a big mayo grid on top of half of their rolls. I recall a deep-fried roll that should be aptly named "The Mozz Stick Roll." It's a mozz stick crust holding back a few grains of rice and a lot more cream cheese. Yes, it sounds like it's taxing your arteries enough to taste good - but it ended up just making us queasy. 

Also, the tempura batter on everything (the vegetables, the "rock shrimps") was heavy, a sad shortcut for the more expensive, but lighter batter. Finally, the rice was the worst part. It's hard, salty, and lacked vinegar. 

Our waitresses were actually very attentive and the ambiance was decent (you could probably guess that means the food must have been pretty bad). Well, back to the ho-hum status quo: Sushi Para and House of Sushi - at least the rolls taste like sushi.

I went here today with a friend on a Groupon deal. The service was wonderful especially since it was a bit crowded. For an appetizer we ordered the Shumai which came pretty fast but was piping hot and very tasty.

As far as the sushi goes, I thought 3 of the 4 rolls we ordered were amazing. We had the spicy tune, shrimp tempura, Grayslake, and the Sweet Sixteen. I thought the Grayslake roll was a little bland which was a bit disappointing because it was said to be the most popular.

Overall, the service here is great. The servers are very attentive and welcoming. The food was tasty for the most part and came almost as quickly as the appetizer. I will definitely be visiting again.

First off, I want to say that I put great value on consistency. Having said that, I would have given Kawa a better rating but they were not consistent with their food.

My boyfriend and I first ordered kawa from grubhub. We were excited since they had such good yelp ratings. I had the tempura udon which was very bland. My boyfriend ordered a few rolls: salmon skin and crunchy spicy tuna. He also got the yaki soba. He really enjoyed the yaki soba, but the rolls were what stood out, specifically the salmon skin. My boyfriend even said it might have been the best he's ever had. The rice was still warm and the salmon skin was crispy and fresh! So delish!

So a few days later, I told my boyfriend I was craving for the salmon skin roll (I never even eat sushi, let alone crave for it). I also got the mexican roll as well. I was so excited for the salmon skin roll, but the first bite was disapppointing. The salmon skin had a stale texture, not crispy like the first time and it was cold. The Mexican roll was good. The jalepenos were crunchy and spicy, just how I liked it. All in all, I feel a little put off from ordering again because I don't know if it's going to be fresh or not.

bookmarked south kawa for awhile now and since i was craving for sushi, i decided to come and give this place a try.. it's street parking so make sure you pay the meter! when we went in.. we were the only people there... service was nice and friendly and our waitress was attentive...

we got the sushi buffet which was around 25 dollars without tips and tax yet.. so yes.. it was a little on the pricey side compare to other sushi buffets in the northside..

i like their appetizers.. the misu soup was good.. the bufflao shrimp and rock shrimp was not bad..

the sushi on the other hand was ehh... most of the sushi is covered with too much sauce which ruins the taste in my opinion... also a lot of the sushi was fried... it just wasnt my cup of tea.. 

dont think i will be coming back here again.. but for the people that is not into that much raw stuff and like saucey and fried food.. give this place a try...

A groupon brought us here & I had a weird "this is not going to be good" vibe walking in.  Well my vibe was off because we ended up having a very decent meal.  We tried many different rolls & all were good.  
I look forward to our next visit.

I came in here for the first time and made a phone order for pick up. I tried the california roll and shrimp tempura and they were awesome!!! I am definitely going back plus is close to my house so i dont have to go far. Cam't wait for next time!!

Anyone that eats sushi knows,  the RICE is a very big factor to the taste of the sushi. The rice was too plain, not enough rice vinegar.  The spicy salmon roll was also tasteless.  Although they do have some nice rolls like grayslake but not really worth it. I only went cause its so close to home and the groupon was worth it.  But I would never go back unless there was a groupon deal,  not worth it.

My friend had a bought a group on coupon so we decided to try it last Saturday. We got seated immediately. Yay for no wait!

The menu had a lot of great options particularly with their special rolls. For 4 girls we ordered about 5 rolls and 2 desserts. We ordered:

Sexy Mama Roll - This was a really unique roll. Its ingredients was wrapped around with a cucumber. However, I barely tasted anything. It was my least fave roll.
Volcano Roll- This was our fave! If you love spicy tuna, you will love this!
Cherry Blossom- I don't recall much of this roll. My friend stated it had a sweeter taste compare to the others.
Fallen Angel- This was recommended by our waitress. It was great. Def. recommended. 
Yakuza- Nothing too special about this roll. It was okay.

All rolls were well proportion, I did not notice there was more rice or more mayo like some reviewers had stated. I felt most rolls taste about the same and nothing really stood out. Over all, they were okay. 

As for desserts, we got mochi and cheesecake. The manager (I believe who he was) kept pushing us to order the cheesecake that came along with a mochi. The mochi was good, however, the cheesecake was not so great. I felt it wasn't done. The texture was still too mushy that it tasted more like a mousse cake to me. It also came with a red sauce that just didn't complement well with the cheesecake.

Presentation of food and ambiance of the restaurant was great! Service was also great. Never had to flag down a waiter/waitress to refill our teas, which I appreciate a lot.

I would come here again only if I had a coupon. I felt the bill was pretty steep even with our coupon. The sushi was good, but it was not worth the cost for its quality of fish/sushi. 

Side note: This sushi restaurant are own by Chinese people.

Check in on Yelp and get free Edamame. Yay, I'm a fan.

Menu is great with lots of options. Ordered 4 rolls for 2 people. Plenty of food! The spicy salmon roll was not spicy at all, a little disappointing, but still good. The roll had a crunch, as if there was a tempura element in it, liked that. The dragon roll was good, as I'd expect. The other rolls were good too, but can't remember which they were. One had mango, which I hoped to be A-mazing, but was a disappointment as the amount of mango made it nearly impossible to taste.

Ordered hot tea. Tasted like hot water with zilch flavor. Skip that.

Seating is good, atmosphere is quiet. Overall I like this place. If you live in the neighborhood they've probably put a door hanger on your front door. Be sure to bring that!  It has a 20% off coupon!

Awesome awesome awesome wraps. Called to place an order for delivery and was originally turned off because whoever picked up told us to place an order on Grub Hub or Chow Now because it would be faster. (Um I'm talking to you this very second so wouldn't it be faster for you to take my order? But whatever) 

Cut to the actual delivery and the food was great. We had a cheese panner wrap, chicken reshmi wrap, beef kabob, potato tava wrap, and sweet potato fries. The wraps were a little on the small side so 2 each and a side of fries was PERFECT. Definitely give this place a shot. Tons of flavor at a great price!

I was leaving from Chicago and wanted to pick something to eat for the journey. Most of the places were closed for 4th of July holiday. I went to Bombay wraps; they had a discount also (3Pm-6pm). I ordered chicken tikka wrap; it was authentic and amazing, exactly like you find in India. 
I got two wraps and 1 soda in less than $10.
Great combos available too!

Cool take on Indian street fast food, but a little greasy and messy.

I love Indian street food and I love it even more when people think of new ways to make Indian food a "grab'n'go" style of food. This was my first time visiting Bombay Wraps and overall I was pretty satisfied. My sister and I a samosa wrap and the channa wrap and then we split them. 

Overall, the food wasn't bad. We ordered the wraps "spicy" but i wish they were a little more spicy. The wraps were also pretty messy so it was kind of hard to eat and easier to eat with knife and fork. But, the lady preparing our food did warn us of that. I liked that the wraps were made of paratha, which was a nice nostalgic thing for me from my childhood. We also ordered the sweet potato masala fries which were cooked to perfection: crispy on the outside, slightly soft inside and incredibly seasoned.

I would recommend this place to someone who wanted something on the go and were downtown. Not sure if there are comparable places (I'm sure there are), but overall, I was pretty satisfied with my first visit there!

This was really good! They were in the lobby of our building handing out fee samples and coupons. Last night I just couldn't bring myself to cook so I figured I would give this a try. The food was so good! I got the Chicken Tikka in a wrap and some samosas on the side. I was so full! The people were really nice and the food is cheap but delicious!

I was really excited about the concept of Bombay Wraps because I love Indian food. I ordered the Tikka chicken wrap but unfortunately, the chicken was rather dry and the flavors weren't very good. Despite being drenched in sauce, the food was somehow bland. The sweet potato fries were redeeming but really, how do you screw those up?

The workers also somehow managed to make me feel rushed for my order even though the restaurant was empty. It must be a gift.

I'll probably give it a second chance considering it's a good price point, but if I'd rather go to somewhere like Naansense if I'm craving quick Indian food.
First time here and the food was ok. It's light and very plain. It would be better if the wrap had some lettuce and veggies. Service was fast though.

Was pretty excited to try this place. I have been to the infamous "Kati Roll" in NYC, and loved it, so I had high expectations for this place. Came here for lunch on a quiet Monday afternoon. The rolls seemed kind of small so I got 2, the chicken tikka and the panner. I would not consider this chicken tikka at all. There was very little flavor to the chicken. It tasted like the oven baked chicken breast from subway with added psuedo tikka masala. The "Paneer" doesn't have the cheese like flavor real paneer does, its more of a tofu blocks with the same 
"psuedo masala'. I added onions and spicy sauce which wasn't spicy at all. Although its called "Bombay Wraps' it doesnt really have the exotic spice/flavor profile indian food has, its very Bland/Americanized. Its about as indian, as Taco bell is Mexican. The food isn't bad, just expected more from this good concept.

Pros: Tasty bites, quick service, friendly staff, clean restaurant
Cons: Price, small portions, inconsistent sizing

Came here to grab dinner the other night. Clean set up and super friendly staff even with the store coming close to closing time. The ordering and prep works pretty similar to a Chipotle line, where you can choose between a wrap or salad bowl and then pick from a variety of traditional Indian fillings. Being a bit on the hungrier side, I opted for 2 wraps and tried the chicken tikka and lamb curry wraps. I have so say both were pretty tasty, however I noticed the chicken tikka wrap had considerably less meat than my curry lamb wrap. At just under $12, I have to say I expected a good amount of food, but my togo bag definitely felt a bit on the lighter side. And after inhaling both, I definitely was still hungry. 

Maybe portion control is a good thing, but I must say I expected more for what I paid. Also, I forgot to add that both came with options for spicy or mild. Mild is really mild, I'll give the spicy a chance the next time I'm in. I really hope they adjust their portions and pricing accordingly, because other than that the food is really good!

'Til next time!

Rosa J. loves the Chicago "neighborhoods."  Customers at work often ask her for recommendations on local "quick bite" places in downtown/loop/Streeterville areas, but she freezes and feels a bit embarrassed since she's a self-proclaimed "Chicago foodie."  

Well, that's about to change.  She has started broadening her horizon in the downtown Chicago area.  

Back to the usage of first-person pronoun, I purchased a groupon on Bombay Wraps since it's a place that hubby can partake since many items on the menu are vegetarian-friendly.  Apparently, it's a fairly new joint, with chic-looking furniture, bright lights, and clean facilities.  

The groupon basically provided $10-worth of credit to spend on food and beverages.  I chose the unwrapped version of lamb curry, while hubby picked the two (2) wraps meal combo special.

If you have chosen the "unwrapped" option, it would be presented on a plate with a cup of spiced lime vinaigrette dressing (similar to a salad bowl...in an Indian style).  I personally thought the meal combo deal was right on the money.  The "wrapped" style would cost less than the "unwrapped" version.  If you were to choose two (2) wraps, you could get a fountain pop for $0.99 extra.  For instance, hubby's potato tava wrap ($3.99), samosa wrap ($3.99), and a fountain drink ($0.99) would make the entire meal under $10.  

We paid approximately $10-difference since the lamb curry was one of the most expensive items on the menu ($8.99).  I wouldn't consider the portions as generous, yet they were enough for individuals with healthy appetites.  

My lamb curry "salad" was average.  Although I requested "spicy," it wasn't anything strong that would cause a burning sensation.  Hubby enjoyed his wraps, but he did agree with me that the entire meal was on a "pricer" side.  

Nevertheless, I would prefer Bombay Wraps over other "fast-foodie" commercial chains nearby in a heartbeat!  The dining room was very comfortable, with Indian music videos constantly playing.  Who wouldn't like synchronized dance moves and syncopated music beats?

This location is pretty close to the Navy Pier and Lake Shore Drive.  If you ever end up staying or visiting in the downtown/Magnificent Mile part of town, Bombay Wraps would be a good alternative if you are trying to steer away from the Mc*ona*d's.

My first time here, though I've meant to check it out for the last year. The strong institutional cleaning fluid smell turned me off and I almost left but decided to get lunch to go. Food (lamb curry wrap with whole wheat roti and a side of soup) was good and tasted fresh but a little bland, though it was supposed to be spicy. I'd probably visit again though only for take-out.
unfortunately too salty.  wraps are small, reasonably priced, and assembled Chipotle style, but failed to impress.

Been here a few more times and the food is growing on me.  My usual is the Chickpea Chana unwrapped on a salad, vegetarian and healthy, while also tasting really good.  It's not quite enough all on its own to fill me up, but nothing some sweet potato fries can't fix.  Those are good, and well seasoned so they don't even need the spicy ketchup sauce they come with.  The Chicken Tikka wrap is also very tasty, the chicken still moist and the sauce just delicious.  The menu now includes some breakfast items, various wraps involving eggs, so we tried one of them.  Can't remember the name (and their website doesn't have them up yet), but it was eggs, peppers, and tomatoes cooked with Indian seasoning.  Substantial size for a cheaper wrap, but it was a bit oily (see pic).  Enjoyed the flavor, but the amount of oil was a bit of a turn off (nothing that can't be corrected though).

FYI - I had the unwrapped portion and it's ridiculously small if you compare it to other establishments for the price. There are just way better choices out there. Not for me.
To the owner: I was clear enough in my review. Instead of sticking your head in the sand, how about developing your listening/ reading skills, unless you want to be out of Business in a year. Your response was canned and really speaks volumes about your idea of customer service.

Got takeaway about 20 minutes before close - their rice supply had been exhausted for the day, so I opted to order just the chicken tikka and sauce sans the wrap or salad.   

I didn't know how well Indian could be prepared in this fast casual model, but I have to say that I was pleasantly surprised.  The chicken breast was super fresh and cooked to near perfection - the sauce is not necessary, but have some anyway because it's way too good to waste.  

I'll be going back

This place is nothing like Indian food. It's a mere mediocre version of Indian food. The blend of spices was just okay. Plus, one guy behind the food line was very rude to my dad. My dad asked if he could use the male restroom, to which he didn't give a proper response. The second time my dad asked, he said "It's out of service" in a very rude dismissive tone. Only after that, did another saleslady behind the counter volunteer that my dad could use the ladies' restroom since it's just a single stall. She was sweet, but the other dude was not helpful and disrespectful. I absolutely did not like how he was disrespectful to my dad. I'm not going here again. The food was not worth it, nor the customer service.

Great concept, making Indian food easy to take on the go. Tried the tikka masala wrap and sweet potato fries with a side of yogurt sauce. 
The fries came with a spicy sweet sauce that was pretty good, the heat creeps up on you.
The wraps are the perfect size made from nan and lightly toasted
Very good for the price 
Will venture here again

Stopped in for a quick lunch last week, and was definitely a fan! It's quick, the flavors are good (had the chicken tikka masala wrap), and there's free wi-fi. Definitely a great option if you want to venture from the normal soup/salad/sandwich lunch options. I'll definitely be back, and here's hoping they eventually add more locations.

First time I tried this place I enjoyed my meal. Flavorful, great everything (well I thought the samosas were tiny but they still tasted good). But I forgot to leave a review, I went back earlier this week and could not finish what I bought. EVERYTHING I got the 2 wraps and fries all tasted over the top salty! I took a few bites of each just so I had some food to take some painkillers to coat my stomach and that's all I could tolerate.
The place is exceptionally clean and the folks are nice, good customer service. Idk what happened with the food so I'm giving the benefit of the doubt that maybe was an odd day...I know il go one more time but if it's not good in changing my rating.

Was not expecting this place to be so great. Having moved from the UK where Indian food has become a country favorite , Chicago had a lot to live up to. Bombay Wraps is a quick place to get a taste of well flavored chicken , lamb or paneer. My favorites are chicken reshmi or lamb curry. The wraps are actually really tasty Indian parathas which makes these a more substantial snack/ meal than similar I have had at other places ( where a chapati is used). 
Too it off with a cool mango lassi which is a nice compliment to the spiced (med or high options) wraps. Defo worth a try when you fancy a quick bite.
Quick and delicious Indian food. Small menu that's a bit pricey but it's a great spot for lunch. Would definitely come back here

Delicious fast Indian food. Divine aroma walking in. Fast service. We had vegetarian wraps and rice bowls, all yum & full of goodness. Nice service and fun music videos. Mango Lassi also good. Walkup counter w restaurant seating.  Address is 340 I think, not 400 we saw listed somewhere. We'd definitely go back. Location within easy walk of the pier.
Over-rated. Super salty chicken over rice, beef wrap, and sweet potato fries. Loved the concept but food didn't meet expectations. Chicken was juicy. Won't come again unless the salt issue is solved.

Oh my yum...Indian fast food?! LOVE IT! 
I got the Beef Kebab, sweet potato fries, dessert AND a drink for $10. Everything is spiced perfectly-I can't believe this is fast food! I need this place close to home!

I love me some Bombay Wraps. A newer fast food entrant to the Streeterville area, Bombay Wraps provides wraps and plates of popular Indian street food at reasonable prices in a well lit, modern and funky dining space.

Get your wrap ($3-$7) in flaky buttery paratha bread or whole wheat roti. I prefer paratha. Wrap fillings run from spicy potatoes or paneer cheese for vegetarian options, to savory lamb curry or probably the most popular, tender chicken tikka for meat options. Samosas (Indian veggie rangoons, essentially) are excellent. Haven't tried desserts. You can build your own fountain drink, buy familiar bottled favorites, or be adventurous like me and try the goofy foreign drinks. The mango juice box was sweet but had spices in it. Not good. The aloe/honey drink from Thailand, however, was a hit.

An ultra-suave British/Indian looking bloke must be the proprietor of this spot. He's there a lot. Other than that, employees are cheery and helpful.

A TV plays Bollywood stuff over the dining room, which is funny to watch. Look up "Bollywood Boss video" for a laugh.

I love loyalty/rewards programs but BW may just have too many. From Spring Rewards to a loyalty punch card to AAdvantage Dining miles, methinks they're giving away too much for marketing.

Horrible. Had the Chana masala Frankie. It had no masala. Super bland. The wrap was not even cooked properly. Neither was the Chana. I would have generally ordered a paneer thing but the guy over there insisted Chana masala Frankie is the best..it was bland and tasteless.
Cant wait to be here again. Loved it to every bit :)
Amazing and authentic Indian food! A real gem of a place. Love the wraps and sweet potato fries. My daughter loves the mango lassi and asks for it every time.

Service was great. The food was alright. I had the chicken tikka wrap with a side of samosas and sweet potato fries.

The wrap was so much better than what I was expecting. It was flaky and the chicken was cooked just right and went well with the sauces. 

I don't recommend ordering the sides. The samosas were very small but generously stuffed. They were overcooked and pretty hard. The fries were near burnt. Don't get me wrong, the fries were good but they just had a burnt taste to them. 

They offered me a cup for water without me asking and threw away my trash once I was done. It's a fast food place, something I don't expect the workers to do. 

Overall, I'd return to try their other wraps!
Amazing chicken boti wraps !! Great environment with friendly employees and people around you will stop back soon.

Great place for a quick meal or snack. I've tried their Chana and their paneer wraps. Both are really good especially with the spicy sauce. The pickled onions are key- so load up on those! 


Surprisingly, you can also pick up spices from Swad from here

I live and work in Streeterville and rarely leave my downtown bubble. My sense of adventure involves trying the new restaurants that pop up around my hood.

So I was power walking home for lunch one day with my blinders on when I decided to take an early left turn directly into this newly opened establishment. I walked straight up to the menu, decided on the Beef Kabob Wrap and only the Beef Kabob Wrap, paid, received my food, and beelined for my living room couch. There could have been a mutant monkey sitting at a table and I wouldn't have noticed it. If you'd ask me about the color of the floors, walls, tables or chairs, I would have no idea.

Anyway, my first impression when I opened the foil was, damn, this is sort of small. But it was tasty! And - surprisingly filling. Oh - and they gave me a $5 coupon! Okay, I like you guys. 

Today I ordered the "make-me-whatever-you-desire" off of GrubHub for takeout. Pick up was quick and easy, the staff was friendly. I took a moment to take a look at the aesthetics of the place. It's a pretty typical fast-casual venue: simple, clean, crisp and modern. 

My meal, which I, again, ate on my living room couch, was more elaborate than the first, and just as delicious. The staff at Bombay had bestowed upon me a Chicken Tikka Wrap, three Samosas, a side of cilantro chutney, and some super odd, bright orange fudge-looking thing. To be honest I really had no idea what I was eating, as my experience with Indian food is minimal and I didn't even think I liked it - but I am now a fan. 

I took an itty bitty nibble of the dessert and had to pass. I've received plenty of rejection when I try to share my Polish sweets with people, so deep down I knew the people of Bombay would understand. 

If you're in the area, check this place out for some unique, quick dishes at a bargain. You won't regret it.

It was fast and good, but I thought the wrap would be more of a naan type bread which it is not.   At least not quality naan.   I would get the bowl next time.  The samosas I would not get again despite the fact that I love samosas
Wrap is fine, no surprise, but lamp curry unwrapped is not worthy of the price, and the beef kebabs unwrapped as well, not good value for mon
Had a potato wrap and tea. Both were barely acceptable at best.

I was very excited trying this place. Flavors are great. Food portions are so tiny . The wrap was only 5.50 . I ordered a mango lassi smoothie and received a watered down yogurt mess. So let down. Ill probably stick to columbus curry or rajun cajun.

My experience here left a bitter taste in my mouth. Mind you, I've eaten here before and I was expecting an overall good experience with food and customer service. I came in today, 6/7/16, at around 5:20 pm, and clearly ordered for an unwrapped Chicken Tikka. The line server put it on a wrap, which I politely reminded him that I ordered it "unwrapped." Right after being reminded, he gave me the stankiest stanky face his face can handle, then slapped the chicken pieces back into the container. Why do you treat customers that way? I hope management reads this and puts you in your place because this Yelper does not love what he saw today. Horrible service! I ended up leaving shocked, cancelling my order because I don't support servers with bad behavior who aren't hospitable in this field. What a contradiction.

Eh. It's a salty dumbed down version of Indian food. I was looking for a cheaper alternative to the great Indian buffets in the area. Sadly I should have paid the extra money and eaten the real deal.

Chana wrap on roti - loaded with salt and just okay, a little smaller than I hoped (but for $4, it was a fair size); glad I ordered the combo

Samosa - room temperature but flavorful

Spicy mint chutney - star of the show and saved this from being a 1 star experience

And for a serious pet peeve unrelated to the food: SUPER LOUD VENTING SYSTEM. I came in to relax and listen to a podcast during my lunch break. The vent would shake and rattle so loudly every 10 seconds I finally got fed up and left with 30 minutes left on my break.

Don't think I will be back.

NYC has Kati Roll, and Chicago has... Bombay Wraps? OK, honestly, I wouldn't necessary say it's on the same caliber as Kati Roll in NYC, but oh my, is Bombay wraps tasty!! It's fast food, so very convenient for those needing a quick bite while shopping on Mich Ave, doing touristy things and needing something to hold them over until dinner, or just looking for something quick and tasty! 

My favorite at Kati Roll is the Paneer wrap, so naturally that's what I gravitated to at Bombay wraps - and it was tasty! The guy asked if I wanted it mild or spicy and I asked how spicy spicy was - he said about a 7, so I said mild and that was still kind of spicy for me! So, if you're not a huge fan of too much spice, opt for the mild knowing that you'll still need a water chaser! But, it's delicious enough that you won't care! 

Yelp's check in offer is 10% off wraps! And, as I was ordering, my phone died! As I was checking out, the cashier told me that she put in the happy hour deal for me which is 20% off wraps! So, definitely try this place around the late afternoon to get this deal! Worth it!

They even have a little section with indian spices, snacks, condiments, etc - so if you're living downtown and don't want to hike to the nearest indian store, this is a quick place to grab a few things (likely overpriced, I didn't look too closely).

Overall, very good - and if I'm staying at the Intercontinental again like I was this time (and do on every trip to the city), I'll be back :)

PS they have free wifi!

The paneer wrap is incredible! The paneer is so soft and the spices are perfect. The service was fast and the staff was friendly. We got two wraps and a drink for under $10. The samosas are not authentic but my friend got the samosa wrap and said it was delicious. The flavors are exactly what you expect from good Indian food. They also sell Indian drinks, cookies, pickles, chips, etc. I'd definitely go back the next time I'm in Chicago!

This is a hidden gem in streeterville the food is wonderful the staff espically HUGO goes above and beyond for the customers helping, answering questions even giving out great suggestions. i had the chicken tikka which was like a party in my mouth i really loved it. I am going to recommend bo
This location is nicer than the one in the loop. Better hours and it has a little grocery area too to buy Maggi products and they have 2 flavors of badam milk.
This place is basically an Indian-style Chipotle. Food and price is decent for an Indian fast casual restaurant.
Decent place for a quick bite in Streeterville. Nothing to write home about but quick, clean, and reasonably tasty.

Had two wraps and a salad delivered to our hotel room. The convenience was great, but the wraps were cold and they forgot to give us a fork for the salad. 

Husband had the chicken tikka- was spicy-ish and had good flavors
I had the chicken reshima wrap- good flavors and not spicy. 

The paranthas they were wrapped in were good (a bit thicker than authentic ones, but held the roll together)- just wish they were warm!
They were out of the menu choice I wanted (chicken tikka). The wrap I got was good but I was disappointed they were out of a main menu item in the middle of the day.

First of all, when I ordered on Yelp's Eat24 I was extremely hungry and considering I'm new to the neighborhood, I decided to give them a try. I placed my order and it was received by the restaurant at 8:30pm (received email confirmation). After about 40 minutes, I decided to check the status of my order to see how much longer it would be and then guess what?! THEY CLOSED at 9pm!!! Without notifying me or anything...so, they just decided to take my money and not give me my food...mind you, I live directly across the street....NO EXCUSE AND EXTREMELY WRONG. I will never support them since they don't find the need to provide decent customer service. UNPROFESSIONAL.

Taking into account as others have stated that the wraps are quite small for what you get, i'm basing my review on flavor alone. I recently bought a lamb wrap and some samosas-the lamb was alright, the samosas very dry. I tried bombay wraps again today and ordered the chicken tikka and paneer cheese wraps, and a mango lassi. The wraps were both overwhelmingly salty- inedible. I ordered medium spicy as I was recovering from stomach upset already, and there was a nice spice but no flavor to my food. The lassi was good, but I chugged it with all that salt in my body. I'll stick to my known Indian fast food spots on the west side.

My mom and I were in the area and happened to see this place! It was fast and the food was sooooo good. I got a paneer wrap and it was pretty good for "fast food". It was fresh and didn't taste like something out of a freezer. The staff they hire need to be professional. The girl at the register was pretty pissed and answered her cell phone complaining about her job lol. Other than that i liked the food

Stayed in Chicago for 3 days and ate here every single day! It was 30 seconds walk from Hilton's double tree hotel and we found ourselves having our brunch here everyday.

I am vegetarian so can only speak for the vegetarian wraps. Chickpea chana and potato tava both are pretty nice - but the 5 stars that I gave them are mainly for the Cheese Paneer wrap.
mixed it up with chutney and pickled onions - and it tasted heavenly.
They also have a collection of lassis - Mango lassi is where you simply cannot go wrong.
The other one - coconut + pineapple lassi was something I tried for the first time - very unique! It was something you should try at least once. I personally found it too sweet - but then I am not much of a fan of sweets anyway!

They also give you a choice between roti and parantha based wraps. I tried both and I will go for the parantha based wraps any day but if you are big on avoiding too many calories- then the roti wrap is for you.

If i go back to Chicago - I am definitely going back here !

Ohhh it's okay. I probably wouldn't come back with all of the great food around every corner in Chicago. 

I stopped by right after opening at 11am on a weekday, and of course there were no other customers. The place is clean, bright and open. The staff are okay - not all that friendly, but not rude. They just get the job done.

I read the reviews about wraps being small, so I got two...in reality, it was too much food. They aren't THAT small. I got one for my wife and she was happy only getting one, and was full along with the sweet potato fries. 

We had the chicken tikka wrap which was good (my wife got one also, and liked it), and the potato tava which was only okay. The sweet potato fries were the highlight - quite tasty.

So yeah, it's okay, but...I'm not lovin' it by any means. Overall disappointing.

Wowwww was that good! SO GOOD!  And inexpensive!  Went with my mom and nephew, and we got the lamb wrap, chicken tikka wrap, and the chickpea wrap. Oh, and the sweet potato fries, which came with hot and sweet ketchup!  YUM!  I can't wait to come back to Chicago and eat here again! MmmmmmmMMMMMMmmmmmmmmm!!!!

Everything you need to know about this place is in the name: they're bomb, Indian wraps.

I got the potato and chana masala wraps for lunch but honestly the potato wrap was enough.
