We got here around 7:30pm and were seated immediately.  Our waiter was friendly and brought our drinks out right away.  We ordered our stuffed pizza and were told it was going to take about 30-35 minutes.  In about that time, the pizza came out and he served up our plates.  As I took my first bite, I knew that pizza would never be the same for me again..No other pizza could ever compare!  Lol. There were 4 of us and the large fed us all with a slice or two left over. 

I cannot wait to make my next trip to Chicago, even if it's just for an hour to stop at Giordano's.  Hey-- maybe that's why they have this location practically on Midway Airport's runway.

Love the pizza. Ordered on Valentine's Day, as we do every year. Waited 1 hour, 45 minutes. Called to check on our pizza and were told it could take up to 3 hours. Cancelled order. Called back (phones busy) about 2 minutes later to ask if we could pick it up. Girl didn't check, just said if the order was cancelled it's not in the system. But, I'm assuming the pizza and calamari platter were made. So, no deep dish for us this year. Unhappy family.
Great spot for deep dish pizza. We ate at the one next to Midway, so I wasn't sure it would be up to par. It was! Attentive service and great food, don't hesitate to eat here.

This was our first time in Chicago. We were there for a week. We had lots of pizza while we were there, hey, it's Chicago! Giordano's was our favorite. Of every place we tried this was definately the best of our week long Chicago style deep dish pizza adventure. Highly recommended!!
The pizza is great. The service is wonderful.

This was the last food stop before heading to the airport and it was awesome!

Be prepared to wait at least 45-50 minutes for your pizza but it is well worth the wait.  We ordered some wings so we could eat something while we waited.

For the pizza we got the small which is still 6 slices.  We didn't want to overstuff ourselves before getting on the plane so it was just right.

I liked this better than Lou Malnati's and Gino's East, but this is purely personal preference.  I gave Giordanos the edge because I like their sauce slightly better.

I will definitely return.

Stay sexy fellow Yelpers!
Fantastic, I love pizza and travel a lot. Finding this place close to my hotel was a great find. Great atmosphere and great service.
Not impressed. Pizza wasn't really special and the service was slow. Clean place, but next time i'll go to have pizza somewhere else.

Cockroaches crawling on walls in dining room and on table next to ours. Horrible management and cleanliness. And a crabby old lady with at the front counter looks and sounds like she would be right at home at a truck stop. She was very rude when we left arguing with a server about something

Calling in your order ahead of time is a must! Otherwise you will wait up till one hour for your stuffed pizza.
We had the sausage and spinach stuffed pizza. Was delicious as usual :)
A Chicago favorite!
We braved the thunder, lightning and rain to grab this pizza. It was good. In the Bay Area, Zachary's Pizza is really close to theirs.

I love Giordano's Stuffed pizza... It's my favorite stuffed pizza.

If somebody comes from out of town and they want Chicago Pizza, this is where I would take them.  Not that I eat here all that often, but because this is the staple stuffed pizza when I think of stuffed.

This location is a little small, so it's good to call ahead.

Also a little tip is to call about 30 minutes before you want to eat and order a pizza to be eaten when you get there...  It kinda puts in a reservation for you.

Besides, who wants to sit around and wait 30 minutes for there pizza to be ready?  Not me.

Also, their thin crust is very traditional and although not my favorite thin crust it'll due in a pinch.

Can't go wrong here even the crust is fantastic. Had a veggie that was fantabulous !
Servers are friendly and the surroundings are special.  This one of many locations in Chicago is close to Midway airport.

Great indoor spot to sit. Way overrated! I had better thin crust and deep dish many other locations. I do enjoy their appetizers or pamesan sandwich but... Giordanos is just overrated.  Do I still eat there pizza? If someone orders Giordanos I'll eat it. It's edible but I rather go somewhere else or eat a frozen pizza at home.
Consistently poor service.Pizza is adequate but nothing special.

Customer service was poor my boyfriend and I got sat uncomfortably close to another group and no one approached us at all to take our order or to even say hi after about 10 minutes I got up and asked the hostess if we could be moved to another section she didn't answer just looked at me like she was confused so I decided to move anyway after I was settled in the new area I asked if they could change the channel because there was a Bulls game on they said no finally when I was leaving I asked for a couple of boxes to have the leftover pizza split they said sure yet still came out with one box pizza obviously not split , food was delicious though .

Excellent food.  Don't waste your time with the thin crust, deep dish is the way to go.  I ordered from here last night with my family.  I came to pick up the order and it wasn't ready.  The girl working the counter was nice but I had to remind her about my salad.  Other then that great experience, although kinda expensive.

This hasn't been my favorite pizza location in the past preferring either the Giordano's in Willowbrook or any Lou Malnati's location. 

This visit was again a disappointment. There was a wait for a table and when I requested a menu so we could order a deep dish pizza prior to being seated the hostess told me that they weren't able to do that right now as the kitchen was backed up. 

Turn to the part of the visit where we had to ask multiple times for soda refills and the calamari was soggy with oil and cold. The pizza was OK but why bother to deal with a lack of parking, poor service, and marginal food? Go elsewhere.

I was desperate. My flight was delayed, and I was coming to Chicago with the express purpose of satisfying my deep dish craving. The places I'd hand-selected closed at 11 and 11:30, and it was almost 11:20 by the time I got my rental car. I was thinking dark thoughts of starvation. As I headed south from MDW, something caught my eye. It was a flashing light-up sign that clearly said "PIZZERIA" beneath. The place was open. My needs were fulfilled. I was at Giordano's.
Disclaimer: I'm from NJ. My expertise is NY-style pizza. But here's what Giordano's offers:
* Their pizza is unquestionably the thickest around. It was harder to eat their small than it was to eat other places' mediums.
* A lot of toppings, some of which you won't find most places
* Very nice beer selection.

It's a bit pricey here, and the sauce is barely on the plus side of average. That's about all I can say against them. They're open past midnight, critical for the late-night delayed traveler, and for a local chain (about 2 dozen restaurants total) the quality is as good as I can hope for. Very friendly, attentive service. They changed the channel at the bar for me so I could watch Sportscenter. If I were stranded in the middle of a desolate Chicago neighborhood, I would absolutely flee to the nearest Giordano's for salvation if that were my best information. Heck, if I fly into MDW again, I would very likely come right back here. It's a bit more money than other places, but you get more than a bit more pizza.

This was the third time I've been here and I keep coming back.  The deep dish pizza is really thick and delicious.  The cost of a medium pizza was a little pricey which was about $27 for a medium but worth it.  What I really like is that they put meat inside the pizza so that there is flavor all over.  This is one pizza that will be hard to eat with your hands and it is messy.  I would recommend this place but make sure you come hungry! There are several different locations, I went to the one by the airport.  If you want to pick up an order it will take about 45 mins to get, just so you know.

October 15, 2015 11:20 I'm calling the Giordanos and the lady puts me on hold, after about two minutes she hangs up on me. I called immediately back and she said if she could put me on hold and I said no you hung up on me the first time. She still proceeded to put me on hold. I hung up after 4 min on being on hold for the second time. Worst service ever.

Called today to make a reservation for a party of 13, 4 of which would be on a layover at Midway.  We were on a limited time schedule so our family could make it back for their connecting flight. We chose this restaurant so that our out of town family could enjoy some Chicago style pizza which they can't get in Seattle. I was told they didn't take reservations on a Sunday after 3:00. I explained the circumstances to the manager and asked if they could make an exception and accomodate us. She said no. She said they were usually busy on Sunday nights and could not guarantee a table nor estimate the average wait time. When I suggested half our party would arrive early to secure a table she was concerned about us taking up a table waiting for our traveling family to arrive. The pies take 45 minutes to cook. It didn't have to be so complicated. Now instead of me posting a wonderful, accommodating experience I am posting how rigid and unflexible they were. Yes there are rules but a truly customer focused organization would have handled this better.

Wanted to experience authentic Chicago Pizza. Ordered their Chicago Pizza, with their famous Stuffed Crust. Was very Delicious. Like eating a lasagna pizza almost. 

The staff was pretty friendly, I will agree that it takes a long time for the food, took about 45 minutes for our large pizza, but reading he reviews we were prepared. Just go into it knowing it will be fresh and delicious. Worth the wait.

My first time in Chicago I decided to give this place a try and loved the pizza.  I did not go into the restaurant I had it delivered only.  The pizza was great and delivery guy was really nice.  The person on the phone was really nice as well.  I will definitely go back when I go back to Chicago.

This is a dishonest business. I would not be supportive of it.

On 9/4 around 10pm, I was charged about 5% more on my total bill. The last four digits of my card was about 4841 (If they want to verify).

I am not implying that the restaurant systemically cheats customers in order to boost profits, but it is what I saw on my charges in this case.

Greek salad came with a CHUNK of feta cheese. Wasn't mixed in as it should be. A solid block. Manager was a little standoffish and said its like that for appearance. Can't eat appearance. Waitress was great. So if you want appearance give this place 5 stars.

On a work trip to Chicago and was told by many to try this place. It was definitely delightful, I had the house salad with deep dish pepperoni pizza both were so yummy. Salad was fresh and pizza very cheesy :)

Ordered Gluten-free pizza.  Horrible.  Crust was grey and was like cutting cardboard.  Tasted like cardboard.  Cheese had no flavor at all.  Was going to have a beer, but they've got their beer on a 500% markup- $5 for a so-so Miller Lite that cost them something like 50¢ - that's not even beer!  Settled for a coffee.  That was $2.75 (2x Starbucks) and tasted like it was made the previous shift- burned and bitter.  Server was good, but everything else was bad.  Most people were having deep dish although most also looked like they could have skipped a meal and not have missed it.

Yeah... Giordano's is my favorite pizza with out a doubt.

This location did  not let me down a bit. Our service was very good and our pizza was top notch. 

What more can I say?

PS - Be careful in the parking lot. People fly through this lot mainly to avoid the stop light. So watch out and proceed with caution..
Giordano's is our absolute favorite Chicago deep dish pizza, we go here every year when we are in town right before we head out for vacation.  I would say try anything from here and you'll love it.

We just flew into Chicago today!! Our front desk lady said if you girls are starving go down the street. The pizza place has to die for Chicago style pizza. So we walked the block from our hotel walked right in and got sat in what looked like a small section for out server. We didn't get greeted for about 7 minutes. Our waitress also seemed bugged we wanted to order off the lunch menu. After she took our drink order she walked to another table and discussed the entire menu to this older couple. 
     Now I'm a server also so I get sometimes you run into that guest who forgets he or she isn't the other one in the restaurant. After about 10 minutes discussing pizza and how it's made and how to order she walks away and I thought she left to put our order in. At the top of the menu it claims it takes 45 minutes to make the pizza. So I'm not complaining about how long the food takes. The food was wonderful!! But our waitress could care less about our experience and how things tasted. 
      We finally get out sodas after 15 minutes of waiting. Then she comes back to the able to let us know they only have two lunch portion pizzas left. So the three of decide to order an appetizer and split the pizzas. Again we have plenty of food so that's fine. 
        Once our salads arrive I finally get my beer that took 25 minutes. No apology for how long it took. My friends drinks were empty at the time. Our appetizer makes it in a record time. And finally the pizzas make it. She doesn't offer them another drink and we don't see here again for about 25 minutes. We are done eating now and my friend still wants a drink refill. So I walked up to the front desk I assume I talked with a manager and I asked if I could get a Sierra Mist. The lady told me to ask my waitress. I said I would be we haven't seen her in a while. She then asked where I was sitting I walked back to the table which was in eye view of her and other co workers who were gathered around a computer. She brings me a Sierra mist I pass it to my friend and she takes some empty plates. This is where the manager should probably ask how everything was. But she didn't. Our check comes and then our waitress asks if we would like a refill. Needless to say if we do go back I'll ask for an experienced server. 
     I've worked in the restaurant business for over 10 years. All you have to do is be honest with your table and say sorry for forgetting to put the order in or your mistakes. This lady didn't care at all about our drinks or what we ordered. And she never said sorry for the extremely slow service.

I've had Pizza here before.  That's the 2 Stars.  Actually their pizza is amazing!  It's just that you'll need a lot of time.  They tell you up front,"it's going to be 45 mins for your pizza".  The prob is after 1:15 I had to get up and leave.  Then had to make sure I only paid for the salad and drink.  I think they're understaffed and should tell you how long it'll actually take.

Glad I stopped at this fine truck in the AM walking through the loop. It's hard to find a nice basic breakfast sandwich in the city. I always find breakfast items are often times over the top and over loaded. While I had the simplest item on the breakfast menu (bacon, egg, and cheese on an English muffin) I was really satisfied. The service was friendly and the wait time was not long at all like a lot of food trucks can be. Also, the price, very reasonable not only for a food truck but for a brick and mortar restaurant. Looking forward to trying the lunch items.

Order with a smile!

Like normal I aimlessly wandered over to Daley Plaza during my lunch on Wednesday and there were food trucks galore at the Plaza. Blue Street Market was the first truck I saw and the Fire Cracker Chicken description sounded yummy (Sweet Chili chicken...and I love Sriracha)! The flavor of this sandwich was amazing!!

For $8.50 you get the sandwich and one side. I went with the Vegetarian Jambalaya. I'll be honest I could have used a little meat in it, but it was still pretty good. I just ate mouthfuls of the jambalaya between bites of the Chicken Sandwich. I will not be a stranger the next time I see this food truck. Looking forward to placing my next order. 

For more pics follow me on instagram @chiataglance

I need to preface that I only ate from the food truck and not from the physical location on the east side.

It was early morning and I had not had breakfast yet. The idea of Dunkin Donuts or Panera just wasn't cutting the mustard. As I headed into the office the notion of chewing on my fingers till noon was being ever more attractive.  Then, out of the fog, or possibly food truck pollution, I'm not sure which as I hadn't had coffee yet, I saw this giant blue truck with food in it.

The truck said Blue Street on it which confirmed my suspicion that I knew what the color blue looked like. Having one win under my belt prior to 8am meant today was going to be a good day!  As I approached a little white board on the side of the truck had a menu of 6 things I could order... all under 8 dollars. This would be win number two!

I got a breakfast burrito because those happen to be two of my most favorite worlds outside of "all you can eat". They offered my choice of meat from bacon, sausage, or chorizo. It took a few minutes to make and a nice young man handed me a sizable burrito.

As far as breakfast burritos go, it was exactly what I needed. It could have been better with some refried beans in it, but now I'm just being picky. Will I eat from this food truck again? Maybe. When the conditions are right and the fog/pollution parts and color blindness hasn't stricken me... yeah I'd like to try their biscuits and gravy.

Really solid food with nice healthy sides at a good price. The fire cracker chicken was more sweet then hot, so the name doesn't really match, but I like. Also a touch too much dark meat for me. I liked it and will be back to try some other things.

Sometimes but not all the time you get a fair shake at food trucks : money v quantity.  However these guys give you a heap of food and it's damn good.  I had the steak and egg skillet and it comes with a big biscuit.  You have them top it off with the brown gravy they have for biscuits and gravy - forget the salsa.  The steak is nice and tender and it stays hot til you get into the office.  Excellent on on cool and windy morning.  Should last me til I hit some liquidos after work!!

Got the food truck today and was a little disappointed. Ordered the turkey avocado wrap which was actually more of a hoagie and The avocado is more like guacamole you would get at a subway. For my side, I got jambalaya which was fair. Overall I would try this place again but would never order what I had today again

Was happy to try them at the food truck food court this gorgeous Friday.   Had the Andouille Meatloaf entree with roasted red potatoes and vegetable jumbalya as the sides.   The food was delicious and plentiful.   Only ate half and keeping rest for dinner.   Great value!  I'm a fan !

Blue Street Market is a decent place for a sandwich and the price was very reasonable compared to other food trucks on Wacker drive. The truck was clean and looked professional. Blue Street doesn't skimp on the size and weight of the sandwich. 

I ordered the Turkey Guacamole roll with Jumbalaya. It was a big sandwich and there was a lot of turkey on the roll. It was passable, but....... I am pretty sure the guacamole wasn't homemade. The guac was the consistency of mayonnaise or ketchup something you would squirt out of a bottle. I prefer some chunkiness to my guac. Also the sandwich was kind of bland, although I think the tomatoes were fresh. The Jumbalaya had okra in it, I like that, but it also wasn't very spicy.

All in all, a decent lunch, but not exciting.

Firecracker. Chicken. OMG, it is my favorite thing on the menu. Sweet chili chicken topped with crunchy Sriracha slaw. Need I say more?! 

I've been lucky enough to have Blue Street a few times and I gotta say I'm a huge fan. I love their food and I love that they're so fast! Their kale is the first and only kale I've ever enjoyed. Ever. 

Keep it up ya'll! Can't wait to visit again!

Holy Moly Cow FIRE CRACKER CHICKEN!!!! The food is amazing!!! Quality, Delicious and amazing people working!! It's a great combo and I can't wait to hit them up again. Just a tip I follow them on facebook and they are really great about posting where they are at for the day.. just saying 
If they are close by you need to get there. FOOD TRUCK LOVE!!!

Another piece of evidence in support of the proposition that straightforward food trucks might be the best food trucks in Chicago -- two entrees, a chicken and a pork loin that both have nice sauces and lots of flavor, while also being relatively foolproof; and a choice of three sides, including green beans and potatoes with cheese.  Quite spicy and substantial and most importantly, it seems to hold up well in the truck environment.

Great Breakfast Burrito and I'm I normally don't like them.  It was the bomb.  So filling I don't need lunch although I can't wait to stop there another day and get the Andouille meatloaf.  Sounds yummy.

I work in the Loop, and my entire team eats lunch and breakfast here multiple times a week.  The food is the best.  6 of us just ate their breakfast and unanimously decided this is the best food truck in the city.  The sausage biscuits, burrito, and breakfast sandwich were all amazing.  Thanks, Blue Street!

I freaking love this place. The guy who owns this truck is a master. If you're a regular he'll treat you like royalty. People always ask me what type of food he serves and it's not an easy question to answer.. maybe bistro style comfort food? All I know is I'm 7 months pregnant and Blue Street Market is all I'm craving right now.

I ordered the hot turkey and avocado sandwich. It was delicious. Most places just melt the cheese on top, but not blue street! They make sure it's intertwined with the turkey so that every bite has cheesy goodness in it. This was my first food truck experience and it did not disappoint!

Hyde Park is better for having cemita puebla. Can you expect to have southern cali quality tacos here? No. but your in the south side of Chicago, and given that, I think they do a quality job. The carnitas (sandwiches) are especially good. The most popular is the Milanesa (breaded pork loin). This is not my favorite, but I think the chicken and steak are both good. For tacos I recommend the government (chorizo and steak). The quesadillas were an especially nice surprise. Great cheese, great with chicken added. Good hot sauces too. And, it's byob. Bring a bottle of wine or a few cold beers and this place is great. It's not cheap, but also not expensive for a great lunch or dinner. The also have breakfast, which I haven't tried but am excited to. 

In summary, match your expectations to where you are and you'll be happy with cemitas Puebla!!!! Most importantly, lets support yet another great establishment in Hyde park.

Quick Mexican casual

This recently opened Hyde Park location, one of three in Chicago, is already attracting a student clientele which likes the reasonable prices and flavors of cemitas, essentially a taco sandwich. Others in the group went the sandwich route, while I stayed with more traditional tacos, also on the menu, because I think the bread somewhat overwhelms the filling. Service is casual and quick, which also suits the young clientele.

I ordered guacamole with chips, a taco veggie, taco pollo, and taco pescado.  It was about $15 which isn't awful, but not cheap. Service was pretty fast. 

The guacamole and chips were pretty good. I ate all of the guacamole.

I sadly could not finish any of my 3 tacos because they just didn't taste good. I tried putting all 3 different sauces on them and it was still unpleasant. 

Maybe their other menu items are better. I love tacos and these were disappointing.

Just got their food to go, this was a new place that we decided to go and check out. And all I can say is that I will definitely be back! The carne esada cemita I had was delicious and so was the chocolate sweet bread. I'm glad there are more Mexican food options now available to Hyde Park, good for this new business! Can't wait to come back again.

Overview: fun option in an area that doesn't have a ton of fast casual places like this, but food is just okay. 

Food: had their atomica cemita, which was just too much meat and not enough of everything else. The meat was good but not enough to be the sole star of the sandwich. The atomica was about $12, so not cheap either. The best part about my meal was the horchata (milk based drink)...incredible cinnamon flavor.

Service: no complaints. You get a number and they bring it to your table fairly quickly. 

Verdict: Probably won't be back, but not a bad option for students at UChicago.

Recently opened place so I'm willing to give the benefit of the doubt and overlook small issues here or there, but there were none of these.  Employees are smiling, service was quick, responsive, space is clean and decorated nicely.  But one goes to eat at a restaurant in order to eat food, and thus so much depends on the food itself, which just didn't stand well for me.  I got the Taco Cecina (cured steak) and the Cemita Al Pastor.  Both suffered from a lack of flavor, and the 3 sauces on each table can only do so much to save it.  The Cecina was a slightly moist beef jerky texture (but without marinade), and the Al Pastor was dry (no sauce?) while the guac and cheese smooth out any remaining flavor.  Perhaps I just chose the wrong items, heard the Cemita Jamon was good and piled high with ham.

This is a welcome addition to 57th St, but their food left me wanting more... I appreciate the trendiness of the restaurant, quick service, and variety of meats. However, my tacos were small and covered in raw onions that overtook the taste of the meat (though the salsas helped kick them up a notch). I'd like to come back and give this place another shot, but will pass on the tacos next time.

It's a nice and clean restaurant, and the servers were nice. I have to think that something might have went wrong with the food... I ordered the Al Pastor cemita, I don't remember if there were onions on it. But I do remember a few other things.The pork was pretty bland, and a little dry, and the bun was (very good) but way too big that it drowns everything else out. There was some nice cheese, but too much of it relative to the other stuff on there. Some kind of green paste was applied to the cemita but it just seeped into and made the insides of the buns a little soggy. It cost almost $10, so that added to the disappointment. Someone I sat with had the pico + chips which was good, and another person mentioned their milanesa being good.

Also, none of the salsas went well with that cemita in particular. I'd probably give this place another try with the tacos.
If you dine in you have to request for chip ,sad had order 5 steak 1 chicken steak was like rubber chicken was good then 30 tab for mini tacos noooooot

This is a good fast spot to get food in Hyde Park.  The service is friendly and quick.  Food is fresh but comes out fast.  

I had a cemita pollo and large chips & guacamole.  I thought they were both good.  I still prefer going to Pilsen for great Mexican food, but this was decent.  The sandwich ($8) is large, but it's just bread, chicken, and cheese.  They have 3 salsas on the table, and I put a lot of salsa on the sandwich.  This made it very good, but I thought it was on the bland side without the salsa.  The chips and guacamole ($7) were both delicious.  I think the chips, guacamole, and salsas were my favorite part.

Definitely the best sandwich in Hyde Park, leaving behind Z&H, the previous champion. The cemita roll is a great vehicle, the fillings are a nice array of satisfying and interesting meat, cheese, etc.  And while it seems that the seasoning of the meat has been a little inconsistent in the early days, you should be eating this sandwich with a squeeze bottle of salsa in your other hand anyway, so keep that in mind. Yes, I would like more vegetables on my sandwich, but salsa is a vegetable, right?

Weird as it is to say, this might even be the best *restaurant* in Hyde Park, though I realize it can be hard to compare to places like A10 and Promontory and (my favorite) Yusho. I mean, here's how I think of the Fulton Market location -- it's not so great that I regularly make trips to Fulton Market JUST to eat there, but it's good enough that if I have any reason to be over in the West Loop I will often time my trip so that I can grab lunch there. And if that was true of the West Loop, with an intense density of amazingly tasty restaurants, just imagine how this place rates in Hyde Park, the culinary land left behind.

Five stars for Hyde Park. Looking forward to trying the breakfasts, tacos, etc. This place should be here for a while.

I think I ordered the wrong thing here. I was thrilled to see a new restaurant quickly replace the rapidly closed Dumplings: reimagined. Cemitas Pueblas joins the recent spate in Mexican offerings in Hyde Park including the tasty tacos sold at Z&H and Hyde Park Taco Station. Being a taco lover I ordered the pollo and the al pastor both of which were incredibly bland, the chicken more so. The salsas helped to kick the tacos up a notch, but the taste itself was seriously wanting.
Here's why I will be back - the service was friendly and quick, and seeing as though I think I caught them on an off day and they're a new business in the area I want to give them another shot. Next time I'll be trying to horchata and the cemitas. But I hope and pray they work on the taco flavors and throw in some seasoning!

I have a new favorite taco place!

While on a "neighborhood walk" with friends who live in Hyde Park, our final stop was tacos at Cermitas Puebla. It was a perfect way to end the day!

Cermitas Puebla is super sleek and contemporary inside. You order at the counter and place your card face up on your table. I went with the Taco Pollo and my husband went with the Al Pastor sandwich.  My tacos were good although I recommend grabbing the optional sauces. They add another level of taste. My husband liked his sandwich but would've liked a bit more spice/heat. The hottest level sauce was the perfect compliment. The chips & salsa were excellent and the salsa was awesome on my tacos. 

I'm jealous that Hyde Park has this amazing restaurant. We need a Cermitas Puebla in the South Loop.

So I'm going to preface this review by saying two things:
1. I'm from Tucson, AZ where we have access to actual Mexican food made by actual Mexican people at pretty bare bones prices - think nothing on the menu over $8. 
2. I've lived in Mexico City and Puebla and know that you don't need to break the bank to make great tasting Mexican food. 

Ok, now the review of Cemitas - Hyde Park. 

The place looks great and seems to be cashing in on the Chipotle model of assembly line-esque service which has proven itself pretty effective. However, at Cemitas this doesn't seem to be the case, as the food comes out fast but is cold and hastily prepared. 

I ordered the Al Pastor sandwich which came with literally eight strips of sad looking pork on it, one of which was all gristle and inedible. Atop my now seven lonely strips of room temp pork was a mountain of Chihuahua cheese that had any semblance of flavor surgically removed from it. The bun was cold, and the "spicy" al pastor pork was so flavorless it felt like I was working my way through a mouthful of erasers. 

The one saving grace was that the sauces on offer were actually very solid and ranged from mild to fairly spicy. However, it sucks that you have to employ them rather enthusiastically if you want to tease out any kind of flavor from your meal. 

The guacamole as a side is quite tasty, but is either different from the one they use on the sandwiches or is simply not flavorful enough to salvage the turbo-bland sandwiches. 

Finally, the price point is too high. After two sandwiches, a side of guacamole, and a coffee, we ended up spending a little over $30. Which is comparable to a night out at Kuma's Corner where the quality is outstanding, the quantity is enough to slay a grizzly, and the food isn't cold. 

All things considered, we know where we'll be spending our next $30.

Veggie tacos were delicious. Two would be sufficient at a great price. I added avo & onions and it made my tacos quite tasty. The hubs got the Arabe Cemitas and it was awesome! Their chips are yummy too. Cooked right and not too salty! And the delivery was SO fast! 15-20 min tops!

Big reason why we will be back is they did forget one of my tacos, but its their response that was so great. I called to tell them not to bring me another one but just to let them know of the mossing item and ticket that was wrong. She admitted fault (something most people don't do in general) and then offered to refund both the tacos. Something we didn't want her to do but she insisted. We're all human, everyone makes mistakes. It's how she handled it is why we'll definitely be back & continue to order from here. Great customer service!

Welcome to H.P. we're happy to have you.

Great New Mexican food spot!  I love their chicken.  Very fresh. Everything is very fresh.  Guacamole and the two milder salsa are great, the hot has a weird tang.  Guacamole on a taco is 2.00, though so probably would just get the 4 oz instead next time.  So glad to finally have something good here, since Edwardos left:(

Bad experience.  And that was before I even tasted the food.

I ordered 3 carne asada tacos, and 2 fish tacos to go.  $22.  Okay, no problem, they must be really good.

NINETEEN minutes later, after standing in the cramped corner with the other people waiting for to-go orders, I finally got my order.  I couldn't help but notice that the people who were eating in got their food within a few minutes, while the rest of us hovered in the drink/bus station corner waiting for our names to be called.

Another note:  I always think it's so tacky when I see employees snacking while on their shift.  I saw multiple employees eating chips and refilling their drinks at the fountain while I was waiting.  Perhaps the owners don't mind this, but as a patron it seems unsanitary and unprofessional.

Lastly, I checked my order when I got in the car, and it was wrong.  But, upon noticing how TINY these tacos are, I was thrilled that it was wrong BC they gave me an extra fish taco.  I considered going back in to order a few extra BC there was NO WAY my husband of normal stature will be full from his 3 tacos, but realized I didn't have another 20 minutes to wait.

To be clear, I just want to say that if these tacos were amazing, I would deal with all of this and support this local business.  But, these tacos were average at best.  Bland, needed some salt or something.  

Lastly, I am not a student, but so many people in the area are.  I'm not sure, with these prices and portions, that they will be able to make it.  Another Hyde park disappointment.

So..it has the bones of a good restaurant, but there are a few snags that don't make it perfect. Firstly, as many other reviewers indicated, the tacos are unforgivably small for the price. They were yummy, but my stomach was like...

...where they at? Because I felt nothing.

Secondly, the service was friendly, but I saw the cashier handle/prepare food and drinks, which I was under the impression was not best practice. You just handled money from the person in front of me a minute earlier and now you're touching my food/drink? Eehh... 

Other than that, I enjoyed it!

There were a lot of students there when I went, which is great. But don't get the idea that this place is for students on a budget. $11.50 is kind of ridiculous for just a sandwich, even a thick one. For that reason, it remains to be seen how viable the place is; it isn't fancy enough to draw people willing to pay more, but it's a little too pricey for hungry neighbors to make it a frequent stop.

The restaurant Hyde Park needed. Not the one we deserved. 

From the ashes of the mythical disappointment that was Dumplings: White Bastardization Reimagined rises like a blindingly glorious Phoenix Cemitas Puebla, a no-nonsense, reasonably priced, amazing service Mexican restaurant serving up classics and its sesame seed bun cemitas. 

Upon first walking in, you'll be greeted by a savory, heavenly aroma of cooking Mexican food as you approach the counter. Lovely employees take your order and brought food and sauces to our table in record time that would put even the fleet footed Achilles to shame. 

My friend and I started with a 4 oz chips and guac (the small size). Fresh avocado? And housemade toasty, salty chips? Too good to be true. A great guac blend where no onion or tomato overpower the flavor. Instead you get a precious medley of guac fit for a rey.

My horchata simply delighted me. While I could do with more cinnamon I noted immediately that unlike other horchatas I've had, the elixir wasn't watered down. The milky taste of rice water you want from a good horchata was ever present. 

My taco government precioso hit just the spot. Add the lime! 

The cemita was gargantuan. A true behemoth. A Titan of flavor. A mountain of beautifully grated oaxacan cheese overflows in decadent splendor. Each bite of my milanesa cemita blended great textures and flavors I practically nut.

While the price may be a dollar too steep, what you get is amazing value; enough to power you through the day (or through your next charged frantic Yelp review). A must try, and hopefully a staple of your regular eating out rotation, for I hope Cemitas Puebla makes a home out of Hyde Park.

Stopped in last night for dinner. My bf and I had tacos, ceviche, & chips and guac.  The service was good, food was good and the environment clean & friendly.  I especially liked their trio of salsas---the chipotle/bbq was amazing!
This is such a welcome addition to hyde park! The staff was great and it's a lovely space right near campus. Yum!
Great tacos, very flavorful! Also it's new and not to busy, staff was very friendly and prices are great. Definitely try if you're in the area.

I had high hopes for CP after reading reviews of their other locations. But I regret to report that this food is mediocre. Chicago is full of joints offering delicious tacos al pastor for a buck or two. Here you will pay much more for a dry and bland version in both the sandwich and tacos. The requisite onion and cilantro do not redeem it, nor do the salsas. 

The bread on which the cemita is served is too much for the cheese and protein it carries, and it had a slightly off--perhaps under-baked--quality to it. 

I can't help but feel that the owners determined that their prospective clientele lacks the sophistication to appreciate quality, flavorful Mexican food. Why else offer this undistinguished product?

May I invite the proprietor to visit the Maxwell Street market on any Sunday morning and experience delightful, inexpensive Mexican food. Perhaps some inspiration will rub off.

Just had the breakfast sandwich, Jamon Chico ($4.45).  I love the fresh mini bun and delicious ham & egg filling.  Think I might opt out of the Oaxaca cheese next time.  Comes with 3 salsa's to go. Very spicy, but fun to try.  Added a cup of hot coffee, good brew.  Happy to see a new food choice on 57th St.

Not as pricey as Packed before it, but still overpriced given the portion sizes. The tacos are tiny, the cemitas have too much bread (although the bread is quite good) and not enough stuff in them, the ceviche doesn't have enough seafood in it. Not bad otherwise. Certainly not bland, unlike what some of the other reviews are saying.
Customer service is great. Not like 18th street Mexican but way better than Chipotle (gag)! Also one of the owners is gracious! Try it out!

Need to update my review. Just paid $13 for three tiny tacos. The carne asada was gummy and fatty. Disappointed. Disappointed that I'm still getting charged for tiny bits if tomatoe and tiny shreds of lettuce. 

Tiny tacos. Some tastier than others. Kind of lacks flavor. They give more chips than salsa which lacks heat and salt. They charge for lettuce and tomatoe on tacos. The cemitas which they are known for aren't very good. Better tortas at los comales. Carne asada is tiny bits of meat some harder than others. Service is either very attentive or not. A little spacey and don't really smile much. Really don't like how they serve chips and salsa. Chips are on a plate. Feels weird. Not many options on 57th street and it's not bad. The taco spot on 53rd is way better and way more authentic.

Nice fast food, restaurant level.
Quality ingredients. Excellent Mexican chips and guacamole!
I had my first jamon genitals! Very nice! Great bread!

3.5/5. The cemitas are huge, fresh with great texture; however, the flavor is a bit bland and requires salsa. Unfortunately, the red and green salsas also tasted like they needed salt, to me, but the chipotle was good. I think people tend to lowball Mexican food generally, but even I think the prices are a touch too high. Also, the whole calavera (skull) motif is so overdone and commercialized right now for anything "Mexican," so that's a little annoying.

More positives: The horchata is amazing, I love the selection of beverages and the few sides they have, and the service is super friendly and pretty efficient. 

Hyde Park needs more Mexican food in its traditionally lackluster (but improving) restaurant scene, so if they can spice up the sandwiches and not raise prices, I will keep going back.

Delicious food, wonderful and fast service, substantial portions, and a good price point; in other words, the antithesis of everything folks hated about Packed. The salsas--oh, the salsas--are worth the trip alone. To sample each one, two US Dollars will get you the most generous "small" serving of chips I've ever seen. Also, they were very gracious with my thousands of questions about ingredients. Heads up to any vegans: if you get the veggie cemita without cheese and add a side of beans, you will be living the life; if you add a scoop of said beans to the cemita, you'll be living your best life.
Great addition to the hood! Highly recommend for a quick lunch. I will be back to try the ceviche!

I ordered the Carne Asada Cemita to go.  The overall flavor of the sandwich was very good, including the roll (I don't like sesame seeds but I couldn't stop eating this...) however I had 3x more cheese than carne asada, so my sandwich was more of a Oaxaca Cheese Cemita with a little Carne Asada, hence the 3 star rating instead of 5.  
I intend on visiting the location on the north side so I can understand if I experienced "new location" growing pains on my visit.

This place is solid. Give it a try. Sandwiches and horchata are great. Looking forward to trying the tacos. The cemita rolls are soft and crispy at the same time, but not so crispy as to tear your mouth apart. The atmosphere, though there's not a whole lot they can do with that space, is a bit lacking and staid. Besides decoration, some soft materials on the walls would help cut down on the noise. Cloth napkins are nice touch. Yelp has this as '$' right now, but it's really it's '$$' if you get anything (drink, chips, beans, etc.) other than a sandwich (~$9). Two sandwiches, beans, small chips&salsa, and two drinks was $35. Looking forward to the next visit!

This place was wonderful last night.  I am so glad they have come to the neighborhood.  I had an al pastor cemita and an horchata.  The al pastor could have been a little sweeter and the horchata a little less watery, but those are minor complaints.  It was quick and delicious, especially the mild salsa.  I will be back!

No complaints on the food itself, both tacos and cemitas (sandwiches for the uniformed) have been tasty, with meats and accompaniments prepared well. The menu's graphic design looks nice from a distance, but repeatedly I've watched customers get lost trying to figure out what is on offer and what each item comes with. This confusion is compounded by the number of times the staff has gotten orders mixed up. My most recent visit featured an extended back and forth with a server who tried to convince me that I had ordered chorizo tacos despite a clearly labeled receipt. Adding to the general ambiance of confusion, the menu includes alcoholic beverages, despite the assurance from staff that the establishment is strictly byob. Maybe after a few months getting established all of this will iron itself out, and I can be satisfied to have a taco joint that is open in the evening to visit in Hyde Park.

love this new place in hydepark. 
very clean and friendly.
the cemitas are great. 

but more importantly, their chocolate cookies are like.. the bomb.
i may be biased here. they taste like these awesome cookies I used to have back in pittsburgh during my college days!

One of my favorite spots just opened a new place in Hyde Park and it is every bit as good as, if not better than, the Fulton one. I had the Milanesa Cemita, an al pastor taco, and half the Oaxaca cheese quesadilla, all of which were delicious. My girlfriend had the Cemita Pollo, which was even better here than at the Fulton location. The décor is very nice as well. They also have a breakfast menu, served until 11, which includes breakfast tacos and mini breakfast cemitas. Reasonably priced. Will definitely be coming back here during the school year

This place cannot  get an order straight. I called in three chorizo and egg breakfast tacos, at $3.45 a pop, only to find there was no egg in them when I got home. They need to get their act together. Their tacos (breakfast and regular) are also too expensive.

Food was tasteless, especially the ceviche.  We had various tacos and none were good.  I did like the pico de gallo, which was fresh.  I also liked the horchata which was not too sweet.  I wanted to like it but I am still craving a good ceviche, alas.
At a hefty $9.50 for a carne asada cemitas sandwich that lacked much carne, it was a disappointment. What we did enjoy was the amazing Horchata. The place is clean, modern with fast service.

I am so conflicted about you, Imperial.  On the one hand, I feel like you are a bit overpriced for a noodle house.  On the other hand, I wonder if I am just not fully appreciating what you are trying to do?

Known for hand cut noodles and dumplings, I have to say, all solid.  Hand cut noodles are al dente, as are the dumpling skins.  Skillfully made indeed.  (The dumplings in spicy Szechuan sauce is delicious.)

On the other hand, I think their broth is just ok, and their soup noodles relies too heavily on the taste of their stir fried sauces and pastes for flavor.  Now don't get me wrong.  The food is sophisticated here.  

Overall, the service is good, the place is Chinese-chic, and as a Chinese brother who understands that good Chinese food deserves to be priced just as highly as food of other ethnicities, you get my four-stars, baby.

Yummm!! We spent at least an hour trying to eat find a place to eat lunch at around 1.30 on a Saturday...apparently not a good idea, especially since there was a big rugby game or something and the wait for everywhere was an hour plus. So we wandered in here because it looked like there were open tables for fast seating. We got a table right away!

We ordered dim sum from the lunch menu. They had a special with certain plates for $5 only. Each dumpling plate comes with 3 pieces unless otherwise specified. I had the siew mai (shrimp and pork), zhao ji (pork with crisp rice disk), and something off the $5 menu that I believe was chee cheong fun (glutinous rice noodle-cakes) lol. We also got spring rolls, Szechuan xiao long bao (soup dumpling) and a mushroom soup to share. All of the food comes out at different times which actually works well because if it all came at once, the sheer amount would overwhelm you. My favorite was the xiao long bao and zhao ji dumplings! Everything was well cooked, flavorful, and tasted authentic - not greasy or fatty.

I think for the amount of food it was a very reasonable price too! Service was attentive and polite, and our server made sure to explain the menu with us which was helpful because we had never done dim sum-style dining before. The food was so much that we skipped dessert but the egg tarts looked really good. 

The atmosphere was far more relaxing than a lot of the other trendy restaurants around here, which are good but super hectic at a busy (???) time like that. I'm so glad we decided to stop in!!!

My friend referred me to check out this place (because of the colorful xiaolongbaos) while I was in Chicago for the weekend. As soon as I got there, I realized that the ambiance and decor was quite modern, unlike most Chinese restaurants I've been to. As my party was being seated, I noticed the restaurant's open kitchen area, where they were making the lamian. 


The menu is pretty standard, and a little bit pricey for lunch. I ordered a Combination Xiaolongbao for myself and the Tiger Shrimp Wok Fried Lamian to share with my friend. 


- Combination Xiaolongbao: I shamelessly ordered this all for myself because I really wanted to take foodie photos for Instagram. The waiter also told us that the combo had each of the six xiaolongbao flavors, so I wanted a sampling of everything. The dumpling wrappers were a bit thicker/heavier than I had anticipated. I thought that the Shanghai, Spicy Szechuan, Duck, and Crab were pretty tasty. To me, they were all different versions of the standard xiaolongbao. The Truffle and Gruyere were an interesting twist on the traditional dumplings, but a bit overpowering, especially the broth. 
- Tiger Shrimp Wok Fried Lamian: This dish wasn't anything too special. It was on the oily side as well. 


I would stick with the xiaolongbaos. On the plus side, our waiter was the bomb. He gave us plenty of time with ordering as well as some recommendations on touristy things to do in Chicago.

Imperial Lamian captures very well the Oriental architecture, intricate carved wooden dividers, and traditional bird cages from the Qing/Han dynasty. I especially enjoyed trying their creative twist the Shanghai styled Xiao Long Baos. An order of 6 combination Xiao Long Baos come in a bamboo steamer and ginger soy sauce. The flavors ranked from my favorite being #1 are Yellow - Gruyere, Orange - Crab, White - Shanghai, Red - Spicy Szechuan and Black - Truffle. I didn't get to try the Green - Duck, but I'm sure it's delicious! Their food is bit pricy, but I honestly love the interior design and don't mind spending a light lunch here again.

Very intrigued by their photogenic Jasmine Tea Smoked Ribs though.

There are certain dishes here that are overly pricey - in the sense that you can get them elsewhere in Chinatown for a decent quality but cheaper.  But there are other dishes here that are so worth coming for and paying the price.  Chicago really has been missing a high-end Chinese restaurant that does food of this caliber. Though since I moved away, more and more of them seem to be popping up (Duck Duck Goat also comes to mind). 

Here are the dishes I think are worth coming for: 

- The xiao long bao.  We ended up trying three kinds: the shanghai, the szechuan, and the gruyere.  I would probably come back for the shanghai and the gruyere, although a part of me cringes at the price (since you can get these so cheap in Shanghai!). But these are the best xiao long bao I've had in Chicago, so worth it if you want to get your fill. To be fair though, the competition for good xiao long bao in Chicago is not very stiff.  

- The hand pulled noodles. Ok, these are probably the star of the show. I would come back again and again for these hand pulled noodles.  There is also a guy who is pulling and making the noodles right in the restaurant (they have a big window so you can see him).  The brisket pulled noodles are so good.  The texture of the noodles is excellent, really expertly pulled.  They are not really the wide hand pulled noodles though, if you like chewier, thick noodles. They are the thinner ones, but they still are pretty chewy and delicious. We also tried the minced pork hand pulled noodle dish, which was good as well.  If you are choosing between the two though, go with the brisket.  If you don't want to spend that much money, the hand pulled noodle soups are the best value for your money. 

- Tiger shrimp fried la mian: We loved that soup la mian, so wanted to try the fried version.  I'd honestly skip this and try some of the other dishes. It's delicious, but you can really get fried noodles anywhere. Not worth the money in my opinion. I think we got some sort of beef fried noodle too, but again - not super special and not worth the money in my opinion. 

- Yang Chao Fan (fried rice with char siu, tiger shrimp, asparagus, and egg): Also yummy, but you can get yang chao fan anywhere too. Not super special and not worth the $16. 

- Asparagus: Good vegetable dish, but nothing outstanding about it. 

- For dessert, we had these salted yolk buns. These were probably some of the best sweet buns I've ever had.  They were salty but sweet and rich and creamy in the middle - and served hot and fresh. 

If I were to recommend you get anything here, I would recommend a selection of the xiao long bao (I really liked the shanghai and the gruyere) as well as the hand pulled soup noodles.  And finish your meal off with the salted yolk buns.  You will leave happy and full.

High expectations for $60 pp dinner with no booze. Hit n Miss. Precision cooking with good ingredients in a common menu.  Shareable is passé.  Sunda is to Japanese, and Lamian is to Chinese.  Related?  Better version of PF CHANG.  *wink*

PRICING is comparable to the area.  Limited LUNCH and BRUNCH may be a better value.  2 booze COCKTAILs @$15 and WINES by glass @$10 has excellent pricing.

SHAREABLE CRAB ($16) - good value for 2 crabs as divey places charge $9 for one.  Great breading and flavor.  The wok tossed dried shrimp, chili, curry leaves and shaved almonds is great as rice topping.  With a side of rice, it can be an affordable singular dinner dish.

XIAO LONG BAO COMBINATION ($18) - flavor failed to be addictive.  First and Last.  Wrapping is a tad too thick.  Amused with color coding.  Vinegar is too strong and overpowers the bao flavoring.  You know CHEESE is NOT in chinese cooking right?  Chinese American it is! *LOL*

EGG TART ($8) - impeccable pastry crust, with a perfect egg custard.  3 pcs @$2.50+ each.

Heroine in AMERICANO COFFEE ($5)?  Normal regular espresso is $2.  Normal regular Americano is $2.50.  WHY o WHY is it $5?  Only ESPRESSO OR AMERICANO in LAVAZZA beans.  NO foam or steam milk for you!

RARE TEA CELLAR selections.  $3 Bottomless Blackberry Jasmine iced tea was delicious.

SERVICE is friendly and informative.  It was amusing that food deliverer insisted that he tells me the Xiao Long Bao contents even though it was color coded.  How sweet!  *kiss kiss*

OPEN WINDOWS gives beggars access solicit for $$. You feel guilty if you don't carry cash.  Difficult to enjoy a pricey meal when you are less than a ruler away from the streets.

EMPHASIS on presentation with nesting that is made of rice noodles.  Unfortunately it is inedible.  Wasn't the imperial days fond of carved edible flowers?

While on a trip to Chicago, my concierge recommended this restaurant. I would stick with the dumplings and dim sum here. We really liked the spicy Szechuan soup dumpling, mapo tofu, zhao ji and Szechuan wonton. The latter of these 3 was presented very nicely. 

Unfortunately, we didn't feel the same about the wok dishes, sides or noodles. We had the sea bass wok, the fried la mian noodles and the broccoli side. Those were mediocre at best and if we hadn't had the dumplings, I would probably have a much loser review. 

Drinks were good. Don't remember dessert.

Imperial Lamian tries a bit too hard would be the over arching theme here.  This is a place that has 4 kitchens, each for different types of food.  This means quicker food delivery but unfortunately not great timing.  If you come here with a large group, they will do their best to time the meal correctly, but people will inevitably receive their food earlier/later than you.

The menu is not huge, which is fine...although maybe a bit surprising given the 4 kitchen setup.  

Presentation of the food is wonderful and I would say is the only redeeming quality to this place.  Unfortunately, presentation does not make up for poor food taste.  The food has mediocre flavor at best, which is pretty upsetting given the price.  That is where the straw breaks the camel's back.  Value.

The portion and flavor of the dish you get, in comparison to the price...is nearly laughable.  This was an expensed lunch for work and I still was appalled by the disconnect here.  Kung Pao chicken, which portion size is lacking, and flavor is absent is $20.  Are you kidding me?  You could go to any chinese take out place around town, pay $8 and get twice the portion with over twice the flavor. 

Overall, this place is a big dissapointment.  The extra star was for food presentation and service.

Man this is a hard review. I'll try to explain to you all why I'm giving it 3 stars. 

Soup dumplings are great here. Really tasty with the assortment of flavors. My buddy and I split the following soup dumplings: Shanghai, Spicy Szechuan, Crab, and Duck. All very good. It's a bit pricey the cheapest coming in at $7 for 3 dumplings. Dumplings were 5 stars no doubt. 

We also split the Mince Pork noodles. This is soup base. It's very tasty. It's about your typical overpriced Ramen prices here in the Chicago area. Lol. But didn't mind as it was really good. Very smooth tasting. Not to salty, felt like there was no MSG or any of that sort in it. Really clean broth. 

We also split the Pork Belly dish. This is where this place left a sour taste in my mouth. Most of the "entrees" are in the range of $20-$30. We both wanted to try the pork belly and even asked the waitress what she recommended. I was excited when the Pork Belly came out. There were 4 square pieces in the bowl that it came out on. I was thinking to my head, ok there's definitely going to be more pieces underneath. Nope. I was wrong. There was only 4 pieces. WAIT, WHAT? I JUST SPENT MORE THAN $5 ON ONE SQUARE PIECE OF PORK BELLY!?!?! Yeah left a really bad taste in my mouth. My friend agreed as well. 

I'll go back again for sure for the soup dumplings and the noodles. And hopefully the rating will change but for now the 3 stars will have to do.

Had dinner here for 'date night'. It was my 1st time at the restaurant and the ambience was nice and the restaurant was warm, which is always a plus. The food - well, let's just say I had the best sea bass I've ever had and some mighty fine jasmine tea smoked ribs as well. The only negative was that they got off on their timing so the ribs were just warm while the sea bass was piping hot. Still, I'd go again in a minute!

The food was mediocre at best! Really expensive for the small portions of bland dishes! We had to
Wait a long time even though we had a reservation!  Would not go back!

The deco was very hip, mixing the western contemporary and Chinese designs pretty well. Food was more on the mediocre side. The colorful Xiao Long Bao (juicy dumplings) were good for picture-taking but didn't taste as good as the ones from Din Tai Fung (if you're a juicy dumpling expert from the west coast you would know what I'm talking about). The dumpling skin was a little bit thick and didn't come with enough juice inside. We've also tried Gua Bao, Stuffed Chicken Wings, Wagyu Fried Rice and Gailan. All of them tasted above average but came in very small portions. Don't be surprised when you think you've ordered enough but left with a half empty stomach.

The waitress proclaims that this is the best Chinese restaurant in Chicago.  I like that confidence, although I cannot agree.  Certainly the decor and ambitious menu are admirable.  The dim sum is pricy, and the dishes creative, with fresh ingredients.  The authentic ethnic dishes are a big question mark for me, although I have always been a little lost in Chinese-American Chicago.  My culinary family upbringing is very different than what I find here.  I do love the Xiao Long Maos although they are on the smaller size.  The ham sui got, har gao, and shui mai were outstanding.  The ma po tofu was not not the saucy, spicy soft bean curd dish that I am used to--it is a fried tofu wrapped in deep fried tofu with sweet dipping sauces.  I enjoy the seafood hot and sour soup, but prefer a little more heat.  The shrimp lo mein did not live up to my expectations.  Imperial Hamian is an experience.  Stick with the traditional dishes, and you will enjoy the experience.

Came here on a post-happy hour whim. Ordered the minimum must-haves of soup dumplings, dim sum, and lamian and can't wait to taste the rest of the menu. 
Truffle dumplings were outstanding, pumpkin shaped dim sum were adorable and filled with a rich duck flavor bomb. Pork belly in the lamian was the silkiest pork belly I've ever had - at first, the thick strip of fat is daunting but I joke not, it melts in your mouth, absolutely worth it.

As a lover of dim sum, I was thrilled to find out that there is a fantastic dim sum restaurant walking distance from my apartment (downtown Chicago). Usually I take the trek to Chinatown because I know that the dim sum I will have there will be authentic, inexpensive, and absolutely delicious. 

Although Imperial Lamian is definitely upscale, the quality of the food and the ambience truly justify the price point. Upon entering the restaurant I was absolutely captivated by the decor and the attractive hosts and hostesses. Between the design of the space and the dress code, I knew that I was going to have a fantastic experience because I am one who takes pride in appearances. 

The wait staff all wore black (my favorite color) which kept everything uniform. I love the menu. It is very easy to read and it is not overwhelming like most Asian restaurants are in Chinatown and other areas. 

I ordered the Gua Bao (porkbelly with spinach buns) and the assortment of xiaolongbao:  SHANG HAI, SPICY SZECHUAN, DUCK, CRAB, GRUYERE, and TRUFFLE. What I absolutely adore about these were the intersection between east meets west: the majority of the dumplings stayed authentically true to its Asian roots, but the gruyere and truffle were such a delightful surprise with a modern European twist on an Asian staple.

I actually loved every single one of the dumplings. The porkbelly bao was fantastic as well, but the only thing that bothered me was that the bun kept sticking to my teeth -_- this was not okay when you're trying to sit pretty with your date lol.

Expensive but authentic Chinese, with fantastic hand-picked noodles. The beef soup noodle was the perfect way to end a cold day. Get it with the soft boiled egg.

They also have a great XLB ($20 for 6). The XLB comes in 6 unique flavors, including cheese and truffle. The skin isn't as thin as Din Tai Fung, but it's a close second. The steamed dim sum is also tasty.

I was really impressed. The spicy XLB were delicious and actually spicy. I got the handpulled noodles in bone broth soup with beef brisket and it was delicious, tender noodles and the brisket was even more tender and slightly sweet which made for a great flavor mashup with the broth. 

The wait on a Friday night wasn't horrible, about 20 min when we arrived after 8pm. I'm excited to check out the Chinatown location but I'll definitely be back here

Fantastic ambiance for an Asian fusion. Surprisingly the authentic looking xiaolong baos are amazing. Such a pleasure to find a bao place in the heart of town. Don't have to run to Chinatown anymore. Readers, if you have suggestions for good Chinese hotpot place in the loop or in the nearby hoods, please comment below. I appreciate it. 

Anyway, service was pleasant and the wine list suffices the pairing with Asian fare. Conveniently located, only drawback will be the loud music on a weekday. I guess being neighbors to the pubs influences the choice. 

Easily 4 stars if not more. Will be back again w friends and family

This is absolutely the most amazing Chinese food I have ever had!! Where do I start? The Pumpkin Duck Puffs were delicious! The colorful Xiao Long Bao was remarkable and an easy conversation piece at the table. Dinner was absolutely delicious. Our service from the front door on was superb. Being able to watch the La Mian noodles being pulled was entertainment in itself. And make sure you don't leave without tea!!! Loved it!

I really liked this place. We came in around 6 with no reservation and they were able to seat us. The paintings on the wall in the back room were really cool. I had heard about the hand pulled lamian here and the soup dumplings so we tried one of each. 

We ordered the spicy Szechuan dumplings and ate them (with a little instruction from our waitress). Delicious. I also liked the bright colors. She suggested that we add one more on since there were 2 of us and they come in 3s, which was a great call. 

I also ordered the mushroom lamian with char siu added on (for $2). It was delicious and just what I needed for my slight cold. I loved the flavors although wouldn't have minded a little more spice. My friend got the char siu and wonton lamian and after adding their homemade chili sauce, was a huge fan. 

All in all, loved the decor, the service was good and the food was delicious. I definitely want to come back to try their dim sum, which looked delicious on the other tables.

Imperial Lamian brings a great new option to downtown serving more upscale & chic Chinese food in a trendy environment. 

Service was okay...our server was great but another that came around asked strange things of us. Also, their benches are really far from the table making it hard to eat without scooting them forward. I loved their interior though and they have great windows that open over one section of the restaurant. I wish I was sat in that section.

We went straight Dim Sum on our first visit -
-Shanghai Xiao Long Bao $7 for 3 - Pork soup dumplings! There's a special way to eat these and we did it wrong.YouTube it! These were very good and loved them.
-Ham Sui Gok $9 for 3 - New menu item! My favorite dish of our lunch with a glutinous rice flour shell. 
-Xiang Gu $8- New Menu Item! Mushroom filled dumplings. Loved these and it was a different type of dim sum than I'm used being all veggie. Plus they are inside of a very cool, almost sparkling, semi-translucent dough wrap.
-Szechuan Wonton $10 for 5 - Spicy pork explosion! Smaller in size but packed with flavor and served in a pool of soy sauce for some added saltiness.
-Zhao Ji $8 for 3 - New menu item! The presentation on these dumplings was masterful with a cool spiderweb of dough incasing them into the pot. It sure looked cool but more importantly, they tasted great!

Important to note, they don't have their colorful, signature dim sum dumplings during lunch. Dinner only. :( 

I really liked Imperial Lamian's food and plan to go back for dinner very soon to try more items. Their ambiance is wonderful but service leaves a bit to be desired.

Very pretty decor 
Food was good, not mind blowing. 
Xiao long bao = Shanghai  and spicy were good 
Hand pulled noodle soups= minced pork better than beef
Jasmine tea smoked ribs= smoky delicious
Salted egg baos with green tea ice cream were outstanding !!!

FANCY CHINESE

It used to be Chinese wasn't too fancy unless you went to the Mandarin Oriental or the Peninsula. Nowadays, I guess there's an appetite for chic Chinese fare in a hip environment. Imperial Lamian fills that bill in a choice Gold Coast/River North location.

This is the first North American outpost of this Indonesian chain. The interior is dark and elegant. There's no shortage of hosts, hostesses, and managers at the front of the house and walking through the restaurant to smile at me, ask me how everything is, and thank me for my business. Too many, in my opinion, but maybe this was an anomaly. 

The menu is daunting. There are multiple areas for appetizers, dumplings, noodles, main courses, and fried rices. In retrospect, it all seems so familiar, but when I looked at it in front of me, I felt a bit overwhelmed.

A test of a great Chinese restaurant is Hot and Sour soup by my book. This was just okay: heavy in the corn starch and light on familiar ingredients like mushroom. Two mini saucers of hot and sour flavoring offered to customize the soup to my liking set this presentation apart. I dumped both in and still had a soup not close to my Aristotelian ideal. 

Next came these cute little color coded soup dumplings which were hand made and burst with a pop off broth coddling the crab and brie interiors. This was more substance over flavor because while the craft of the dumpling was spectacular, it fell short on taste. 

The highlight and savior of the meal was the slow-cooked broth served with the hand pulled lamien noodles and Chinese barbecue pork, char siu. This was a bowl of heaven. The noodles were made before my eyes in the open kitchen. They had a slightly sweet toothiness. I'd definitely go back to try other combinations of lamien. It's better than I've ever had. 

My server was very helpful in making suggestions and negotiating the menu. She put me at ease. Since I avoided most of the entrees, I got out of the restaurant for under $50, which I consider a coup!

Overall if you order the right thing, it's excellent; but that menu is minefield. Coupled with the fact that this was the most expensive Chinese restaurant I'd ever eaten in, I left slightly underwhelmed.

Terrible host service on October 27th, 2016. Misled me entirely about expectations for getting seated. Average food. For the price, you would expect better host care, better setting of expectations, etc.

The bathrooms are oddly dirty for a nice restaurant and the drink choices pretty limited.

Upscale Chinese in a beautifully decorated space.  The environment is elegant and trendy.

We started with the  MISO Blossom tofu, royal trumpet mushroom, wakame, goji berry. Absolutely beautiful and delicious.  Normally I would say miso is just miso but the presentation made the tofu blossom look like an anemone in the sea.  Yes, that is exactly what it looked like! 

Next we had the CRISPY SPRING ROLL - Carrots, royal trumpet & wood ear mushroom Each roll packed a mouthful of flavor that was remarkable. And just for kicks we also had the PRAWN ROLL -Tofu wrap, nori and HAR GAO- Shrimp dumpling. These did not disappoint.

We had the IMPERIAL- Mixed greens, watermelon radish, charred shallots dressing which felt like a great way to cleanse our pallets before we started our adventure. 

We of course could not pass up the namesake Lamian noodles and tried the 
MIXED MUSHROOM -Miso vegetarian broth, shiitake & enoki mushrooms, carrots, bean sprouts, snow peas.  It was very nice to see the noodles being made behind the counter in the window to the kitchen but unfortunately as delicious as they were they lacked enough broth.  I was glad to see that the broth was veggie friendly.  The bowl of noodles is just what you would need on a cold Chicago night.

For me the show stopper was the CRISPY PRAWN - Wasabi aioli, mango, passion fruit.  Crispy, tangy, savory and creamy all in one.  The prawns were generously sized and the helping is plenty full. Presented in a wonton basket this is a dish not to miss.

For sides we had the GAILAN - Chinese broccoli, soy glazed, roasted garlic, ginger jus and wouldn't miss an opportunity to have the housemade chili to go with everything.

To end the meal we had a sesame lotus paste ball.  A semi sweet finish to a very royal feast.

I would highly recommend Imperial to anyone looking for a upscale Chinese meal in the River North area.  The food was great and the service was working out it's kinks but still good.

Upon walking into this swanky restaurant (and also based on the Yelp ratings) I was genuinely excited to eat here. It's not often I feel like you find a good, upscale Chinese restaurant outside of Chinatown.

Normally, I am not one to spend a lot of time on the service, but I think this is where our experience started to go down hill. Our server was just pleasant enough to get by. She took our order and kind of left abruptly. She offered no explanation about the menu or about what she recommended.

We started with hot and sour soup, schuezwan wontons and spring rolls. For entrees, my husband ordered the sea bass and I ordered the kung pao chicken. Note: everything is a la carte so rice was an extra $3. 

We got the wontons and soup immediately. Both were delicious and had great heat. Then randomly, a food runner appeared with 2 seabass. We were confused since we only ordered 1, so we kept one and sent the other back. There was no explanation provided as to why there was a mixup. Also, I am not sure if this was one of those restaurants that brings stuff out tapas style as its ready, but if it is, they didn't explain this.

The seabass was a major disappointment. My husband couldn't cut through it with his fork because it was tough. We had to ask for a knife. I tasted the fish and it was extremely rubbery and tasted old. He was not able to finish the fish because the knife wouldn't clutch through the ends.

We received our spring rolls 5 minutes after the seabass and the chicken almost 10 minutes later (that also after asking the status). The spring rolls didn't have much flavor, but the chicken was delicious. It's not for the faint of heart as it does pack some heat.

During this time our waitress never checked on us. We had to flag someone first available to even get us a knife. Around the time I got my chicken, I did order another drink, but that took so long that it finally arrived at our table when our food had been cleared and we were ready to pay. 

Overall, this place does have promise. There is definitely room for improvement in this extremely competitive restaurant environment. If I do come back, maybe I will try the food other reviewers recommended.

We sat next to the window where they were hand making the dim sum I ordered. It was impressive to watch them make and tasted impressive too! My bf ordered the beef brisket in broth with the hand pulled noodles he loved how tender the beef was and over all would order again, however the beef was a bit fatty. I guess that's what it takes for tender and flavorful beef. One star off for being a little pricey for dim sum. But understandable for not having to drive out to China town. Will come back to try more.

A relatively new addition to our River North temporary neighborhood, opened last March in a corner space at State and Hubbard that has seen a high restaurant turnover.  

Let me say upfront that I have taken away one star at the...um, suggestion...of my wife, who considered their prices a poor value for money, and was heard to mutter the phrase "tourist trap."  Repeatedly.  All afternoon.  Point taken, but my comments will be based on my impressions of the restaurant itself, leaving financial considerations to the discretion of the reader.

This is an open room, clean and modern in decor, and refreshingly clear of "Happy Lucky Golden Dragon" ornamental cliches.  There's a mix of U-shaped booths and tables for two and four.  Open kitchen.  Separate bar area along the Hubbard Street side.  

Arriving at about 1:00 Sunday afternoon, we were seated at once in the only moderately full dining room.  We discovered that only dim sum is served before 5:00 on Sundays.  Don't expect the traditional roving dim sum carts, though; all choices are from a fairly limited printed menu.  We tried:

- Szechuan Spicy Xiao Long Bao.  A bamboo steamer with three pink bao, filled with a very spicy finely-ground meat, and a side of soy sauce and shredded ginger.  I liked it; my wife drew invidious comparisons to the fare half a mile down the street at Wow Bao.

- Shrimp and Pork Siao Mai.  Topped with some sort of orange roe.  Tasty but not especially memorable.

- Tiger Shrimp Noodles.  A modest-sized portion of a stir-fry of hand-pulled noodles, shrimp, bean sprouts, three colors of bell peppers, and onion, topped with a fried egg.

Overall I'd give food, service, and ambience four stars; food selection (at the hour of our visit--we haven't tried the dinner menu) and value two.  Our three fairly small items ran about $34.

Convenient to public transportation, two blocks south of the Grand Avenue station on the Red Line.  On the 36-Broadway and 29-State bus lines.  One block (eastbound on Illinois) or two (westbound on Grand) from the 65-Grand bus; also, in season, one block from the free Navy Pier "trolley" (really a bus tarted up to look like a 1900-era streetcar), which loads at the southeast corner of State and Illinois.

Came in on date night with my husband with reservations for a Friday night at 7:30 pm. What a gorgeous restaurant! You will never eat at another PF Chang or Big Bowl again. Not after you visit this place. The interior has a mix of brass and steel, making this restaurant look exotic and smart. The menu took and years to construct perfectly- and the wait was worth it. The soup dumplings seem to be what they have perfected but everything was great, and can't wait to come back for lunch once that starts too! 

I felt the rush of the NYC vibe, great sound quality playing the latest pop hits, a rush of bussers and waiters going back and forth, and not one seat available. Chefs table was awesome- I want to meet the chef's on my next visit. Our waitress was probably the worst part about our whole dining experience. After being seated, she came quickly talking about the water choice, specials, and the cocktails, and the teas and told us she'll be back. She didn't introduce herself and had no smiles. I understand it was a busy night but I would expect finer service! 

On that menu: 

Cocktail on the Specials: Trans Atlantic for $13. I have never tried Maraschino Liqueur but I'm on a hunt for it and being able to get the good quality of Hangar 1 Vodka got me spending that 13 in River North happily. 

Blue Xiao Long Boa for $10 and some of the money from ordering the specials goes towards charity- a win, win! Poke two holes in the boa to get that soup out and that black pepper beef had the freshest black peppers I have tasted in awhile with a kick of heat, I fell in love. The prettiest and tastiest blue food I have ever had and all the other boas have fun colors too. 

Tiger Shrimp Noodles: Not many places in Chicago where you will find that your shrimp has been curled to make the presentation of the dish to look extra special! I appreciate the simplest of flavors and the noodles did that for me. 

Su Chafan Fried Rice: Ever dig in fried rice and it's sticky, or some parts of the rice is just not cooked well, or it's too salty? I would come back just for the fried rice. It was that PERFECT. You just have to get it to balance out any meat dishes. And definitely try to get the seafood fried rice to get a presentation of the crab and lobster plated on your dish- just for presentation.
