Kung Pao: Got my mouth heated with delight and I'm so picky about sauces, that even if it's a little bit more thick then it should be, I turn away but I was not disappointed with the Kung Pao at all. The pieces were cut so perfectly for bite size portions, and even the vegetables were diced with precision. It was nice to have cashews in the dish that kicked it up a notch! 

Dessert: They are dim sum boas. Come in 3. Got the salted one and I wasn't impressed but some people according to reviews- were! Maybe I was just too full to enjoy it but I think they should expand their dessert menu for sure! 

Am I coming back? Oh, you bet I am. Can't wait for them to open up for lunch!

Came here for dinner with my boyfriend to celebrate his new job. I was really excited to try this place because 1.) it's authentic Chinese food NOT in Chinatown, 2.) it's more upscale than the Chinese restaurants in Chinatown, and 3.) I heard great things about their soup dumplings. Yes, it's definitely pricier, but you're also paying for the location, the ambience, and the experience.

Between the 2 of us we ordered the Shanghai and the peppered beef (a special that day) soup dumplings, beef brisket hand pulled noodles, London duck, and wagyu oxtail fried rice. I REALLY loved the refined presentation of each dish, which you often don't get in Chinatown. While everything was quite delicious and something I would definitely order again, the soup dumplings were my absolute favorite. The skin is made very tender and thin, and there's lots of flavorful soup inside. I also have to say that the beef brisket was extremely tender. Kind of just melts in your mouth and releases the soup that got soaked into it. SOOO GOOD. 

The only thing I didn't like was that the kitchen is an open kitchen that is separated from the dining area by small pane of glass. It is really cool to watch them make the hand pulled noodles, but when they're making them, the chef will slap a stretched out piece of dough onto the counter top making an extremely loud firecracker noise. We were not sitting by the kitchen, and it was pretty disturbing and made me flinch every time. I looked back a few times and saw the girl sitting next to the kitchen literally turn her back to it because it was driving her crazy.

Loved everything about Imperial! The atmosphere and service were great and the food was amazing. I got the Lost in Translation drink- a little strong but def worth trying. We got the Goa boa as an app (the spinach buns are to die for) and the beef and noodle bowls as main dishes. My only comment would be that i wish they had some better dessert options but besides that, will be back soon for sure!

one star for decor
one star for service
one star for their dim sum and la mien
No stars for their wok dishes (ironically most expensive)
No stars for their Price for quality/value 


$100+ for lunch is ridiculous. 
Lesson learned.

I have mixed feelings about Imperial Lamian. We live close by so there was a lot of anticipation for this place to open. The venue is quite beautiful and you can tell a lot of attention to detail was paid on the decor. If anything it's creative and interesting to visit. Also, you can see the noodle masters working on their craft with the open kitchen concept. Very cool. 

The food is good but not great for upscale Chinese food. The best dishes were the lamians - I've tried three kinds: Char Siu & Wonton, Braised Pork Belly, and Beef Brisket. The noodles were very good, great texture and fresh. Flavors of the broth also complimented the noodles well. We also tried the xian long baos (Shanghai and Crab) and although the filling tastes good, they are not as delicate as they should be.... and three is just not enough! Compared to Din Tai Fung, the xiao long baos just fall short in dumpling quality.  For dishes, we tried the sea bass and the black pepper beef. Portion size was decent and the flavors were pretty authentic. 

I expected a very high level of service for this type of establishment and found that it was hard to flag down my waiter at times. He seemed to have many tables and was running around quite a lot. Also of the two times we went, we saw the management team visit tables around us but did not stop to talk to us. This place is expensive and the type and level of this establishment does fill a void in the Chicago downtown market, however the service needs to improve to warrant such prices.

Let me preface this review by saying I don't care for American Chinese food at all and I am not Asian by any means. It took a lot of coercing to even get me in the door, However I Loooved this place. This is not your typical fried, Covered in some sauce, Chinese food. Oh no. Every dish packs a ton of flavor and spice, without all the grease. I had a party of 8 and everyone unanimously loved the food. Note: I'm not saying this is healthy food by any means, but it's Chinese food done really well.

Yes it's expensive. Yes it's loud. Yes this is that restaurant on hubbard that has been 2 other restaurants in the past 5 years. It's a nice, more casual and relaxed alternative to say stk or rpm, but with very competitive food. 

Everyone loved the garlic chicken. Venison puffs. Chicken wings. Noodles. Fried crab. Highly recommend those. If you don't like spice. You probably won't appreciate this place. Try it out.

Yes they have valet.

MUST VISIT!! 
This is an absolutely incredible place for Chinese food.  The decor is excellent, the food is nothing short of incredible!  Check out my other reviews, I rarely give 5 Stars. This is every bit as good as the finest restaurant you'll visit of any cuisine.

I started withthe Xiao Long Bao.  Now, if you've had bao from other places, it pales in comparison to what you'll have here.  The server teaches you the proper way to eat it.  It is first taken out of it's bamboo steamer at table you place it in your spoon, puncture it and let the broth drain, then drink the broth and eat the bao.  It's spectacular and not "bready."  The Gruyere bao is stunning as is the Spicy Szechuan.

I then had the braised pork belly la mian.  The pork was delicious and plentiful and full of incredible flavors.  The noodles were made fresh to order, and one could tell (not just by the authentic artist behind the kitchen counter) but by taste.  The beef broth also very fresh and all the tastes were distinct but harmoniously in concert like a Mozart symphony (good one, eh?).

The drinks were amazing and unique.  This is not your typical Chinese place. This  is authentic cuisine in a fun, hip atmosphere in a great part of town (River North).  I think the curse is broken at the corner of State and Hubbard.  The two previous restaurants failed, the last being Centro.  One won't be able to get in here in a few weeks.  

I'll be returning soon to try the other menu items I simply had not room to eat.

Uber-excited about this opening but first visit was blah. This is sadly not a good choice for people who frequents Chinatown and values food quality over ambiance. The xiao long bao we so looked forward to were just ok: wrapper not delicate enough, not juicy enough and the crab one I tasted was way too salty. The venison puffs, however, were amazing.

Lamians are their saving grace. We tried minced pork, beef brisket & charsiu and wonton, all three had very interesting & distinct broth flavors with excellent noodles. However, stick to the soup ones. The stir-fried beef lamian was a yawn and is on par with $8 stir fry noodles you can get at any Asian/pan-Asian restaurants in town, yet it was priced at an exorbitant $16 with half the portion size. I get this is river north which has a different price range, but it really doesn't add anything new or exciting for diners that are familiar with authentic Asian food and not afraid to venture out to the neighborhoods. I think the clientele will be mostly tourists that want Chinese food near Michigan Ave and don't mind paying a premium. 

To their defense, the drinks menu looked interesting so I'll likely come back for that. Also heard they have a great tea selection, which the waiters don't hesitate to push on us multiple times. Other than that, service was warm & friendly.

Given that I'm not from Chicago and that it was my first time in the area, I've decided to visit this restaurant after reading all the kind reviews it had on numerous foodies blogs... and guess what? I really enjoyed it! Firstly, I was really happy to find out that it was located right across the street of my hotel which allowed me to drink a little bit more than the usual lol. 
I was welcomed with smiles, I even received compliments about my outfit (Yeah I know... but it's always nice once in a while). I was seated not too far from the entrance, the room was half full and not noisy, I ordered the Hot Garlic Chicken with Asparagus, their Shanghai Sunset as well as their Salted Egg Bao for dessert.... Everything was perfect! I will definitely go back the next time I'm around!

River North used to be home to several Chinese restaurants, some were even hip at some point in their lifespans. They went away but now Imperial Lamian is here to lay claim to the vacated crown. 

I'm pleased to say that Imperial Lamian is all around excellent. They really shine with the soup dumplings (conveniently color coded as to their contents) and noodles, both are house made. In fact everything we had including several varieties of soup dumplings (dumplings with a brothy filling if you are not familiar), several dim sum selections, jasmine tea ribs, seafood fried rice and car siu wonton noodles were excellent. 

The noodles (after which the restaurant is named) have a perfect balance of chewiness while still remaining tender and the dim sum (such as the siew mai) are as good as you will find stateside. 

I have been to China several times and while far from an expert I do think that I understand great Chinese food from the run of the mill American version that is ubiquitous. Imperial Lamian is not exactly authentic and has certainly been modified to appeal to Americans but nonetheless veers towards what one might find in Shanghai as opposed to the mall. Regardless of what it is it tastes great. 

The space is quite nice looking with large abstractions of traditional abacuses serving as dividers and bird cages as lamps while an open kitchen runs the length of the dining room. The floors are elaborately tiled but regrettably the designers neglected the ceiling  leaving a bare industrial steel canopy in full view. 

Service was efficient and good but not overly friendly, thou to be fair these servers have a lot to do. Each table typically orders many small plates and keeping up with that must be a chore. The dumplings and dim sum come out of the kitchen very quickly. 

I had a Singapore Sling which tasted nothing like any one I have ever had. Not good or bad but not what I expected. 

The downside is the cost. I hate to factor that in too much but when they charge $3 for a small bowl of white rice I feel that I should mention it. A fairly normal meal for two can easily hit $200 after tip which is very expensive for noodles. The prices can be deceptive as they appear reasonable but portions are generally small and you will order more than you think you will. 

All told however I am excited to return. Although virtually all of the menu appeals to me next time I think I will simply have some soup dumplings and a bowl of noodles (here served something like ramen but with less broth) and forego the shared plates. It's a great addition to the area and offers some much needed diversity of cuisine as well.

Amazing! Pure and simple. 

This was a group lunch selection I went along with because one guy was so excited and the rest of us were starving after a bike ride. I didn't have hopes for anything more than mediocre food when I saw how upscale and Asian-y the decor was though (bad past experiences with fancy Asian fusion places) - but I was proven wrong, so wrong. Note the decor was impeccable! You walk into a lobby which has been made to look like a fancy birdcage, stunning.

Shanghi soup dumplings (xian long bao) to start: Truffle one was to die for. Cheese (Gruyere) was good. Crab was edible but I wouldn't get it again - nothing  special. All dumplings came out at the perfect temperature which is a black magic I've not experienced anywhere else. They were definitely hot but the soup didn't burn your mouth like they do at all other places I've gotten them at, what?!?!? Talented chef in the back. Dumpling skin wasn't dried out like I've seen at other restaurants. You need to order these!!! 

Got the pumpkin duck dumplings (puffs) which were visually stunning: shaped like little pumpkins on a bed of lettuce. Fried to a gorgeous color. My partner got a nice piece of fatty duck in his filling but my piece was all pumpkin filling, YMMV.

Mushroom bao were shaped like big fluffy white mushrooms. Complete with stem, dusting of brown color for character, and defined gills, wow! Great heavy mushroom flavor.

Zhao ji (dumplings) had the most stunning presentation I could imagine. There are pictures in other Yelp reviews of the fried lattice and 3 dumplings in the middle. Good tasting but I wouldn't make a trip here just to eat them.

Beef lamain: fantastic flavor; beef perfectly cooked and fell apart in my mouth. Noodles were really out of this world. Only regret that because food came out whenever it was ready, we ignored the bulk of the noodles until the end of the meal and the noodles ended up a bit soggy - not the fault of the restaurant, but this is a pro-tip for all patrons: eat all the noodles as soon as they come out; do not let them linger in the broth! Get this noodle dish!!!!!

Spicy lamain was worth taking a few bites of but if I had to eat a whole bowl by myself, I'd be ever so slightly disappointed. Slight Schezuan spicy-hot, but muted.

Eggplant (vegetarian) dish (forgot the name) came with chunks of turnip cake which were really yummy: tasted just like my mom and grandma's recipe (mmmmm, scrumptious). How they did that without meat is a delicious mystery.

Shuimai was good...but ultimately just "okay", not the centerpiece of the meal. Not dried out and made the traditional way with chopped pork.....but something kept them from blowing me away. I would skip them here and go to an authentic dim sum place. I am snobby about the taste of shiumai though.

This place was so pricey!!! $12 for 3 Shanghai soup dumplings?!?!? Yikes! But service was impeccable, and there were dishes cooked so perfectly a miser like me couldn't complain. I'd come back here to eat in a heartbeat.

Summary: get beef lamain noodles, eggplant dish, and truffle shanghai soup dumplings. Probably worth paying for a plane ticket to eat these here again.

Ever since I heard this restaurant was planning to serve soup dumplings, I knew I had to come and check it out. 

My friend and I shared:
Shang Hai Xiao Long Bao (soup dumplings)
London Duck - pulled crispy duck, momo wrap, cucumber, scallions, hoisin
Wagyu Oxtail Fried Rice - XO sauce, asparagus, egg

We started off with the shang hai xlb. Sadly, the broth came out of one of the dumplings. The next one I ate had plenty of broth and great flavor. 

Next came the duck. It was crispy and delicious. I would definitely order this dish again. 

Lastly, we ate the fried rice. It had a nice spicy kick to it with chunks of oxtail. The finely cut asparagus added great texture.

We also ordered the crab xlb, but since dim sum service was a little slow that night, we cancelled the order. We were already full from the duck and fried rice that we didn't have room to eat more dumplings. 

The space was beautifully decorated. I also like the open kitchen where you can see everything being made. It's definitely more expensive than if you went to Chinatown, but you get good service and a beautiful atmosphere. My friend and I are already talking about coming back here soon!

Decided to try this one out on a Friday night.  There was a wait, but luckily they take your phone number and text when the table is ready.  Very nice!

The dumplings (dim sum) was super hot and average.  The big draw is their hand pulled noodles.  You can watch the chefs making them through a window in the dining room which is pretty cool.

The duck entree and half chicken was very tasty.  The prices were a little high for what you were getting.  

The place started emptying out around 8:30 so I think it's a great spot to eat after work before going home.

I was lucky to be treated to this outstanding meal by my two dear friends, for my birthday! I was thrilled with every bite! 

When, I went to rave about this place on Yelp I was shocked, that they are not reviewed better! I see most of it has to do with the price point vs portions. I am guessing it is because we - as a society are used to the Chinese food being more affordable. As a proud foodie, I learned to shake off any stereotypes- I will happily pay premium for uniquely prepared dishes with exotic ingredients! This is exactly what you get in this place! 

I must say our experience was greatly improved by our AMAZING, passionate about the food waitress, Maria! She didn't just know all the dishes on the menu she had her favorites and made us feel at ease about some of the ingredients we didn't know! Maria shared with us that she celebrated her own birthday at Imperial. I think that speaks volumes of the place when someone chooses to spend their special day at work! 

We shared a variety of dishes, even my miso soup was the most interesting version of its kind! We shared a sampler of Xiao Long Bao and SPICY SZECHUAN (!!!) and Gruyere were out of this world, the later remind me of Vietnamese Colonial cuisine, Peking Duck was, beyond words and Shrimp fried rice although more traditional but solid, prepared with herbs which added extra layers of flavor! We also had a Dessert Bao Trio filled with egg-custard, so yummy, I had a tough time sharing (even though I really like my friend Ally)

I must add that this place has a perfect ambiance for it's location in River North. It is incredibly elegant with unique details that leave your eyes occupied throughout your meal. The tables are either facing the windows, ideal for a romantic evening, or have a fascinating kitchen view where you can see how all of their fabulous dishes are made! From marble inlays in the floor tile to ancient Chinese calculator-inspired booth separators the decor is remarkable!

I must return!!!

This restaurant is gorgeous in a great location. If you're expecting cheap, large quantities, you are in the wrong place. It's a bit pricey but high quality food and service. Two of us went and spent $130 together. Caveat, we ordered 9 items and one drink because we wanted to try a little of everything. Warning: long review!

I'll go through our food items:
Crab & duck soup dumplings (xiao long bao): I am thrilled that I can get delicious soup dumplings in Chicago now. You can actually watch the chefs make the soup dumplings by hand in the open kitchen layout. 3 per order and I would go back for these. 

Braised pork belly lamien: again, like the dumplings we got to watch the chef hand make the noodles, which was awesome. The noodles were fresh and and broth was flavorful. I would just say for 14 dollars, I would expect to see more than one piece of pork belly. If you go you have to try one of the lamien dishes. 

Clay pot chicken: not very memorable. I was too into the lamien to pay attention to this one. I didn't think much of it, but it wasn't bad. This dish became leftovers. You have to order rice on the side, and we got the jasmine rice. It's just regular rice. 

Crispy pork belly: self-explanatory. It comes with 9 small pieces with mustard. It's delicious, but a bit too salty for me. 

Egg tart- a normal egg tart. You get 3 of them on one order. 
Salted egg bao- YUM, salty, sweet and fresh out the steamer. Also get three per order. 

Lastly, drinks. We got a jasmine tea that was very high quality and fragrant. We steeped three pots of tea and it was still good! 
Lantern four 9ine: Great! Not too sweet and the first time I've had sparking sake which was delicious. 

I also took a tour of the kitchens and prep areas that aren't part of the open kitchen. It's extremely clean and organized everywhere I went. Thanks for reading.

Great food! Great service.
The decoration is fancy. Combined both oriental and modern style. You can watch the kitchen as they prepare your food, which makes it better.
The xiao long bao is the best I've ever had in American. The most authentic Shang Hai style xiao long bao. They did some innovation by changing the color of it. Taste really great.
Lamian is also wonderful. The noodle itself is LanZhou style but the soup is actually not. Still, taste great.
For the dessert, we ordered Lunar Blossom. Which literally looks like luna! Inside is ginger cake covered by cream, on top of which is vanilla icecream. Wonderful idea. 
All in all, we had a wonderful dinner in this place. will be back.

Had dinner at Imperial Lamian after the Ireland New Zealand rugby game. The place is hip and not your typical Chinese restaurant.  We shared a lot appetizers and had couple of the noodles dishes. The minced port and short ribs. We also had couple of enters.  Some of the dishes are very good and some are just ok. That why I am giving them 4 stars.

This cool place is different than the typical Chinese restaurant.  First, it's located in the hip River North area.  Second, the decor is upscale and modern, with nice Chinese touches like giant abacus room dividers, bird cages and ceramics.  The kitchen is on display and you can see the lamian (hand-pulled) noodles being made.  The menu and service are Western, with real waiters and bus-staff.  There's specialty cocktails, beer and wine - nice.  The clientele is a mix of Asian and non-Asian.

Niceties aside, it's still about the food isn't it?  So let's get. down. to. it.  The must-eat items here are the xiao long bao (XLB) or Shanghai-style soup dumplings.  I've waxed about these in the past but the ones here are nearly perfect.  The skins are thin and chewy, and strong too, with nary a leak to be seen.  The broth is abundant and the filling is properly porky and gingery.  The vinegar is spot-on too - Chinkiang-type black vinegar with slivers of ginger.  But here's the interesting twist - those are just the standard Shanghai dumplings.  There's also duck, crab, spicy Szechwan, gruyere and truffle.  What the heck is going on here?  Now duck, spicy and crab are within the XLB canon but gruyere and truffle?  I think Yan forgot how to cook this one.  The crab variety was really tasty, all sweet crabby goodness.  The gruyere ones were surprisingly delicious too - think of them more like some of the tastiest agnolotti you've ever eaten - that's how you get the FUNK out!

The other thing this place is known for is lamian or hand-pulled noodles.  The noodles are made in full view in the display kitchen.  It's quite a show, all that pulling, stretching and pounding.  Anyhow, the noodles are served either in soup or stir-fried.  We tried the beef brisket soup noodle, which is their take on the iconic Chinese nu rou mein (beef noodle soup).  While the beef was tender and flavorful, the soup was cold and the noodles were too thin for my liking.  A long blond hair in the soup was an unfortunate find (but it improved our tab for sure.)  The stir-fried lamian with shrimp was tasty but was not anything special.

Other items we tried included squash dumplings made to look like little pumpkins - beautiful and delicious, fried turnip cake - delicious, mushroom spring rolls - ok, stir-fried Chinese broccoli - ok.  The stewed pork belly with preserved vegetable (mei cai ko rou) is a pleasant surprise to see on the menu; it was decent but not spectacular.

Our desserts were great.  The star dessert is the lotus sphere.  This is dessert and a show.  A sphere of white chocolate is presented and then hot chocolate sauce is poured over it in a radial pattern, melting the white chocolate where it has been poured, causing the sphere to open up like the petals of a lotus flower, revealing a cube of ginger cake topped with vanilla gelato and raspberries inside.  Wow, and it tastes good too!  The salted egg bun is a play on an egg; a steamed bun filled with a decadent liquid "yolk" of sweet and salty egg-custard-caramel.  Also quite delicious.  The egg tarts (dan tat) are small but tasty as well.

All in all, this is a very impressive place.  Can't wait to have more XLB!

Really enjoyed my experience here.  My husband and I strolled in pretty late after shopping in the area.  The staff was very friendly and accommodating (with our bags). We were seated almost immediately and our server made some great recommendations.  

We ordered about 5 dishes to share including the soup dumpling sampler (highly recommend) and char Sui and wonton lamian. The prices are a little steep for Chinese food, but the quality, taste and ambience definitely makes it worth it. 

I hope I'll be able to go here one more time before leaving Chicago.

Nice modern place. We were seated at the tables next to the kitchen window. Great view since they make all from scratch. Noodles, dumplings etc. Services is super friendly and excellent. We had the soft-shell crabs, the dumplings mushroom, pork-belly buns, ribs, pork kind of taco so good... Kind like a Mexican carnitas taco but made in China.

The only thing that didn't like was a weird machine noise that comes from the kitchen.... Don't know what it is, but they got to fox it.

Definitely coming back.

Great experience and I'll probably be back. Try to get a table next to the kitchen so you can watch them. 
Staff was friendly and the food good. Go try it out for yourself.

Superior service and exceptional food are always a winning combination.

We started with crab and duck xiao long bao, and three dim sum selections: char siu (lightly baked crispy dough) pumpkin puff (almost too cute to eat), and the seared turnip with egg and sprouts (that and a bowl of rice would've have been a great lunch).

We then had the clay pot chicken (mild spice and sweet), London duck (an easy play off the classic, served with pancakes), and two kinds of La Mian (pork belly and beef brisket).

Everything was amazing, fully flavored, and generous in portion.  Even though we were stuffed (with to go containers to enjoy the next day), we still ordered dessert: egg tarts, pineapple cake, and salted egg bao.  Mmmmmm, sweet, custardy eggy goodness.

I have to mention the fantastic service again.  Just perfect.

I went out to this restaurant solo on a Thursday night. I made reservations for 1 at 9:15 PM and was seated immediately when I arrive. The restaurant looked relatively empty considering it was late at night.

Breaking down my rating:
Service: 2.5 Stars - My waiter was VERY awkward and did not know how to upsell the menu (or sell the menu at all for that matter). Another waitress came over and picked up his slack. I ordered the mushroom Lamian with a Soy Egg, and after I was done, he came over to ask if I wanted any hot sauce for it.

Food: 3.5 Stars - The Lamian broth was amazing. The noodles are all made in house which was really great. I got to see the chefs making the noodles since their kitchen is open. I was totally full on half a portion of Lamian. 

I did find everything extremely salty though. I also ordered the dessert with a "caramel like" custard in the middle. It was extremely doughy on the outside but the inside was nice. I was able to eat 2/3.

Ambiance: 4 Stars - The lights are dim and the decor is nice.

I met some friends at Imperial La Mian for dinner during the week and had an enjoyable meal.

Décor: The vibe is Asian, which shouldn't surprise you, but it's very nicely done with a modern feel to it. There are a bunch of tables and booths, that do not feel crammed together, that are able to accommodate any size group and there is even a private room in the back (separated by a curtain). There are a few smaller tables that are in front of the kitchen (that is nice and open to the dining room). Lighting can be a bit low in the evening but the abundance of windows help provide a decent amount of natural light.
Bathroom: clean, well looked after, and carries the same vibe as the main dining room.

Staff: We had two waiters and they were both knowledgeable about the menu, laid back, and friendly. They provided good service and were backed up by a solid crew of bus boys.

Food: Wow, we had a little bit of everything so I'll point out the highlights. The Stuffed Chicken Wing was AMAZING, the Hot & Sour Soup was very tasty (and they provided where you could increase the hot or sour to taste!), the Xiaolongbao (soup dumplings) is pretty solid (a bit small, but very tasty - we had Shang Hai, which was our favorite, Spicy Szechuan, and Duck), Fried La Mian (tiger shrimp was very good and a decent sized portion), and some entrees. Everything came out hot and fresh and tasted excellent. They spaced the courses out pretty well too so the table was not over loaded.

Value: It's a new spot in the middle of River North so the prices are a bit higher, but they are by no means out of this world.

I've been needing a place to get my Soup Dumpling fix ever since leaving NYC and this spot will tide me over for now...

Imperial Lamian is great. I've been twice now and there's a lot to love. The atmosphere is swanky and fun and the menu is delicious. Must tries include the xiao long bao (especially the truffle and spicy szechuan), the pork belly la mian and the yang chaofan. The cocktail list is great as well- I loved the Lost in Translation. Super fun with a group because you can try a lot, but also great for a date night!

Amazing food and great flavors in all the apps and main, but would love it if seasoning and salt can be toned down a bit for my taste. I took out one star because the service was a bit slow. Also, the desert that blossoms into flowers made of white chocolate and ginger cake inside, while looked great, was a bit too intense for my palate and the texture of the cake was just ok. Definitely going back for everything else!

My stomach is full and I have a smile on my face!  My wife brought me here for my birthday dinner and Imperial Lamian definitely was 5 stars and lived up to the anticipation.  

Food:
Pumpkin Puff: they look like cute little mini pumpkins and are filled with roast duck and butternut squash.  The crispy texture/crunch of the outside is perfectly complemented by the flavorful and piping hot filling in the middle. So good.
.
Seared Turnip: one of my favorite dishes of the evening! I'm not even a fan of turnip, I'm a carnivore, but I would order this every time.  Seared turnip with XO sauce, egg and bean sprout.  My god...
.
Shanghai soup dumplings: flavorful soup and tasty dumplings, reminds of soup dumplings I had in NYC.  There are multiple types, will definitely try others next time.
.
Beef Brisket Lamian: hand pulled noodles! Perfect texture.  The bone marrow broth was tasty and definitely not too greasy or heavy which was nice. The soy egg was a nice touch as well.
.
London Duck: pulled crispy duck (perfect amount of crispiness), with momo wraps, cucumbers and scallions and hoisin.  The flavor profile is a nice mix and the momo wraps come out steaming hot! Which is a nice touch compared to other Asian joints that give you the plain old rice paper type wraps.
.
Jasmine Tea Smoked Ribs: OH MY GOD.  Best Asian ribs ever.  In all honesty, you can tell they put so much TLC into prepping the fall off the bone meat and the smoky jasmine flavor profile.  I wish BBQ joints would put such thoughtfulness into their rib preparation.  Will come back and get 2 orders next time.  Probably my favorite for the night.
.
Salted Egg Bao: our meal ended with a divine dessert.  You hear the word egg and dessert and get puzzled right? The outside of the Bao was so light and airy and the inside salted egg mixture tasted like sweet cake batter with a hint of salt.  We were so glad it came with 3 baos!!!

Decor: trendy, industrial, modern, meets China. 
.
Service: not sure what the reviews here are talking about. Service was excellent from start to finish.  Our waitress made several recommendations that were home runs and things we would have never tried before and Peter the manager I believe, was so friendly and welcoming and checked in on us several time throughout the evening with smiles and pleasant conversation.  

Was an amazing birthday dinner and will definitely be coming back again.

The food I had is the Beef Brisket Lamian. Highly recommend! However, it seemed that it would take FOREVER to get a table. We were a group, and waited there without being notified how long we would wait. All I was told was "as long as the table is set up", "in a few minutes." What is even worse, we felt we were forgotten by the waiters, even though they were busy walking around. 

So dining suggestions would be: Do make reservations or call before you arrive to see how long you would wait. Enjoy!

Second time is not the charm. Cocktails are still heavily diluted and the lamian this time is a bit off. Consistency on the food is lacking and consistency on the poor drink is sadly consistent.  It would be hard to pay this place a third visit.

No consistency translates to sad customer.

Imperial Lamian, with their many locations in Southeast Asia, has decided to expand to the US and their first expansion is not, as one would expect, in New York, but actually in Chicago! Comparisons will inevitably be made to Chinatown restaurants. Yes, you will pay much more at Imperial Lamian. Some dishes will probably be better in Chinatown. If you bring your Asian parents here, you most definitely should NOT show them the bill. But the ingredients are going to be better quality. You'll eat on fancier plates. You won't need to inspect your chopsticks and potentially clean them in your tea. And service will be much, much better. Overall, I liked my experience here and I would come back again.

The vibe here is trendy Asian and the decor is lovely. Two large murals are done by a local artist. One reminded me of Minnie Driver, judging you while you slurp down noodles.

In true Chinese superstitious fashion, dim sum dishes are served with 3 pieces (the Chinese word for "four" sounds like the Chinese word for "death", so it is considered unlucky to serve anything in 4s). This always makes it very annoying to dine in parties of 4 and you will need to order an extra piece of anything from the dim sum section. The price they charge for that extra price almost makes it worth just getting another order. For example, they charge $7 for the shanghai xiao long bao, which comes with 3 dumplings, and to get an extra one they charged $3. The "I-need-to-get-the-best-deal-possible" side of me would probably just get a 2nd order. The XLB is probably the best I've had in Chicago (then again, I really haven't had a good one in Chicago), but they're not perfect either. It seems they still need to work on the consistency of their skin -- 2 out of the 6 we had were broken and therefore all the delicious juices had already leaked out. Major no-no. Also the pork was a tad on the dry side. We could all learn a thing or two from the OCD-ness of Din Tai Fung, the ultimate master of XLB. The pork was a little on the dry side as well. The spicy szechuan XLB is SPICY. Too spicy for my tastes. Those szechuan peppercorns are abundant and linger on your tingly lips and tongue.

The Beef Brisket noodle was my favorite dish of the night. My fiancé, ever the oxtail connoisseur, immediately commented on the richness of the broth and how it must be made with oxtail. We confirmed with our server that indeed that is why it was so tasty. A proud moment. If I'm going to be picky, I wish the noodles were a little thicker and more al dente. Texturally, I could not tell they were handmade -- honestly they reminded me of those red box dried Chinese noodles from my childhood that my mom used to use whenever making a noodle dish. The beef was good, I personally would prefer it with more tendon -- but it's probably a good balance for the customer base that would visit. I would recommend adding an egg as well. Definitely the best beef noodle soup I've had in Chicago. UPDATE: Came back again for the beef noodle soup and it was not the same. Consistency issues.

Other dishes:
Golden Mapo tofu - A little overly breaded and fried.  Wouldn't order again.

Tiger Shrimp Lamian - Great wok flavors. Shrimp really well cooked. A little on the oily side.

Ox-tail Fried Rice - Great wok flavors. Very tasty. Rice cooked really well, fluffy and not oily at all. Would order again.

Green Beans - Delicious. I want a jar of that ground park to eat w/ rice.  Would order again.

Jasmine Tea Smoked Ribs - Delicious dish, ribs prepared very well, very flavorful, fall-off-the-bone, but small portion for $26. I think there were 6 ribs.

Egg Tarts - Bite size, flaky dough, custard part was good, but flavor hidden by the dough. When they're this little the dough to custard ratio is off.

My friends from school recommended me to this new upscale Chinese restaurant in downtown Chicago. Its fancy decor and super cool dinnerware drew my attention in the first place. 

Salty egg buns: this is what I asked for literally the moment I sat down. I was told that their salty egg buns are the best, and indeed, the buns lived up to my expectation. The fillings are authentic salty egg yolk, so I would definitely recommend this item!!

Combination Xiao long bao: these Xiao long baos are quite on par with Lao Sze Chuan's. With more flavors (such as truffles, duck, crab and cheese) as options, I would say the classics are still the best. In other words, stick with Shanghai xiaolongbao or the crab ones, and forget about ordering the combination. The yellow one (filled with cheese) is not so worth your money...

Asparagus: small portion, but very flavorful. Order it to accompany with all the carbs-heavy buns. 

Crispy pork belly: decent dish because the meat is not so fat/oily. Order it if you have never tried it, otherwise there are better pork bellys in Chinatown.

Char siu: I loved their char siu buns!!! They kind of baked the buns from the outside, which made the texture different from the char siu buns that you typically get from an Asian supermarket. 

Beef brisket ramen: according to my friends, their ramen is a hit or miss. I, however, happened to enjoy their beef brisket ramen--it definitely doesn't give you the flavor from a Japanese ramen place, but the beef brisket is well cooked, and the noodles is okay too.

Overall, order as many dim sum buns as possible. Ramens are decent, but avoid the special flavored Xiao long baos!!

The foods are super delicious. I personally think the food has high quality. The ambience and decor made you feel you want to sit and keep eating. We ordered 4 combo xiao long bao, ox tail fried rice, beef brisket lamien & crispy duck. Hands down the food worth to visit. I really liked the ox tail fried rice. This place deserved a five star.

Thank you very much Imperial Lamian for opening up in the near north side. We were sorely missing having an option such as this in the area and appreciate you coming into our lives.

This is pretty authentic food. We had pulled noodles, a variety of dim sum dishes, sesame seabass and the ribs. All of them were very good. 

We were seated at a table right near where the kitchen is, which makes for a great meal being able to see the various dishes put together. 

The decor is really nice, and I am one that does not care at all about the insider of a restaurant as much as the food tastes good going down and plays well inside. 

Only downside may be that it is not a cheap restaurant, but I cannot complain too much considering it is in River North.

We've been here for both dinner and brunch and the food was awesome both times!

For brunch:
we had spicy szechuan xiao long bao, Char siu, egg tarts. All delicious!

For dinner: ham siu gok, pumpkin puff (my favorite!), Braised pork bell lamian, har gao.

We drank the jasmine iced tea both times which was very light and tasty. Great ambiance and wonderful service.

I love all kinds of Asian food and I've gone to Asian restaurants pretty much at least once a week, whether it's Japanese, Chinese, Thai, Vietnam, etc. As such, I've pretty much tried most things out there.

One of a few things I never tried in the US was a classy, upscale Chinese restaurant. Well, when I heard that this restaurant was about to open, I was excited. Upscale and authentic Chinese? That's certainly different.

So, we headed there during their soft opening and had a great dining experience. We went there once more for Easter dinner and, once again, we had a great dining experience. Service was on par with River North type restaurants. Ambience was great. Lighting was perfect. And the restaurant was decorated very nicely with modern Asian setup. Even the dining ware and plates were very nice (just be careful with the sharing bowl since it can tip easily).

Now let's talk about the most important thing: the food.

There are plenty of options in the menu to order different kinds of food if you plan to go there once a month. I certainly haven't tried everything, but the ones I've tried were either good or great. For this review, I will just list my favorites:

Appetizer:
1. Stuffed chicken wing: If I can only order one food from this restaurant, this is the one I will order. It's jumbo chicken wing stuffed with tiger shrimp and fried to perfection. Nuf said.
2. Softshell crab: This is my second most favorite. Deep fried and mixed with crunchy almonds. Yum!

Soup: I'm not a soup kind of guy... I don't order soup.

Salad: I'm 95% carnivore. I will eat free salad though.

Xiao long bao:
I ordered all except the veggie one for the obvious reason. I loved everything I ordered. My son loved it so much, he ate 8 of these on his own. He's 7 years old by the way. My favorite from this category are the spicy Szechuan and duck.

Dim sum: I haven't had a chance to order this yet. So no comment on this for now.

Lamian:
My favorite is the fried shrimp lamian. Like I said, I prefer something not soupy. My wife ordered the braised pork belly and loved it.

BBQ:
I only tried the roasted duck so far. It's good, but nothing can beat the stuffed chicken wing, period.

Fried rice:
I ordered the Ox tail... and I had trouble eating it because of the veggie... LOL. Next time, I'll ask them not to put veggie in it. If you like veggie, you should find this dish tasty.

Entree:
By this point, I was usually very full already. I did order the Jasmine tea smoked ribs and it was really good. I want to try the prawns and scallops next time.

Sides:
Really? You don't order sides when you go to River North restaurants. You order the good stuff you can't cook yourself.

Desert:
My poor tummy couldn't take anymore food. Maybe next time... maybe...

Drinks:
My wife and I love their mixed drinks. We're not much of beer drinker, but I can see they have tons of beers you probably can't find anywhere else. If you're a beer drinker, you should try their specials.

I wanted to try something new this past weekend, so we went to Imperial Lamian for dinner Friday night.  The inside was nice and welcoming, and our server was good.  Unlike some places, she openly told us what her favorite dishes were.  That was much appreciated b/c the menu is a bit large and we didn't know where to start.

We started with the Spicy Szechuan Bao - which was different than I expected.  I was picturing Wao Bao where the inside was stuffed with meat.  While the Spicy Szechuan Bao was stuffed with meat - there was also a broth so it was helpful that they explained how we should eat them - so as to not get burned.  In our eyes - they weren't terribly spicy.  I think they need to kick up the spice a bit more.  We also had the Pumpkin Puff Dim Sum - filled with butternut squash.  We really did like this one in terms of presentation and taste.  The starters were the highlight of the meal.

For our entrees, we had the Roasted Duck BBQ (something our waitress told us they were known for - their duck) and the Crispy Prawn Wok Dish.  My husband found the duck dry in flavor - whereas, I found it very messy to eat.  They came with momo wraps, but the wraps quickly ripped when you tried to grab them.  The Prawn's dish was good (my husband liked it more than I did), but it was a bit too creamy for me.  

For drinks - I had the Imperial Punch - very sweet, but lacking in "punch."  I didn't feel any of the alcohol in it and for $13 a punch, I didn't think it was worth it to get another one.  Which leads me to price.  Yes - the restaurant is pricey.  Each of our entrees were about $24, and for the prawn's dish, there was maybe 7 prawns - so to me, that dish certainly wasn't worth the high price.  

Would I go back?  No.  It's a bit overpriced for what you're paying and there are so many more Asian/Chinese restaurants in the area that are better tasting and more reasonably priced.

So while this place is on the more expensive side... Oh my god. Their xiao long bao are out of this world. It is difficult to find good handmade soup dumplings in Chicago. I've only found one more place in the city that can compare. Everything else I had was delicious, I just was a little disappointed when I left still hungry and out of money.

Atmosphere is really nice. Loved the interior design and ambiance. Very "River North" and does not feel like a typical Chinese restaurant at all. Open kitchen so you can see (and hear) the chef hand pulling noodles and banging it on the table.

What we ordered:
-Shanghai style soup dumplings: Came with 3 pieces. Delicious! Skin was good, soup was nice and sweet, and meat was great as well. Although, I did wish it was more piping hot and only came with 3 pieces for $7 when I can get a basket of 10 in Chinatown for same quality. 
-Har gow: Presentation very pretty. Also just came with 3 pieces. Shrimp was bouncy and you can really taste the cilantro and white pepper. Again, tasted like your typical har gow at any dim sum place at a premium price.
-Braised brisket lamian: One of my favorite dishes of the night. Soup was rich and flavorful. Tastes like the ones from Hong Kong. We added an egg which was delicious. You can taste tea and soy in the egg. The noodles had such a nice texture. Nice and chewy and really took on the flavor of broth. Beef, on the other hand, was a little dry for my liking. I am used to it being fattier, more tender, should almost fall apart when you pick it up and melt in your mouth.
-Yan Chaofan: Basically, your typical "yang chow fried rice". They got the taste and everything right. Don't get me wrong. It was delicious, but the presentation was not authentic and also such small portion. Came in a stone bowl. Again, I could get the same exact thing for half the price and triple portion elsewhere....
-Jasmine smoked ribs: Amazing! Fall off the bone tenderness. Had tea leaves incorporated with the ribs. Sweet and smoky with hints of tea leaf flavor. I thought that this dish deserved its price, because it was something unique and I can't get it in Chinatown.
-Beef stir fry lamian: Small portion. Came with crispy wonton strips on top. As my party and I were eating this, we all agreed that it tastes exactly like lomein from PANDA EXPRESS. LMAO!
-Salted egg yolk buns: Dessert. Really good steamed buns with creamy salted egg yolk inside. Again, delicious and executed well but I can get two orders of this in Chinatown with same caliber of taste and quality.
-1000 Miles drink: Loved this. Had great yuzu flavor and the jim bean apple crisp was delicious. Wish it were stronger though cause it's $14. LOL.
-Yue Lao drink: Also delicious but needs to be stronger. 
-Hot sauce: YES I LISTED THIS. Why?! Because they charged us $2 for a tiny ass saucer of hot sauce. WTH? lol. Did not inform us that it's an extra charge. I know it's only $2, but it's a condiment at authentic Chinese restaurants just like salt and pepper is on every table at American restaurants. Embarrassed for them to nickel and dime us for hot sauce! 



Service was overall good, but need to still work out some kinks. We found that we had to ask for refills of water quite a bit. Food came out with long periods in between dishes. Waited a while to get our receipt to sign. 

Overall, we found that the food was delicious and executed well and tasted authentic. The presentation and experience was not authentic. We also found the food to be overpriced for what it is. If it were more unique (like the Jasmine tea smoked ribs), I wouldn't mind paying the price that they charge. Most of the items we ate tasted exactly the same as Chinatown, only at a premium price and smaller portion. This is a perfect place for Americans that aren't comfortable going to Chinatown for authentic Chinese food and would like a fine-dining experience. My Chinese parents would be pissed if I took them here. LOL.

I was there for the soft opening weekend which the overall service was great, but there's still potential for improvement. Management was very attentive and checked with every table to see if everything was okay.  It's great to have addition of a "GOOD" authentic Chinese restaurant in Chicago area. Regards to the menu, there is a good portion of traditional authentic Chinese food and few items that is contemporary Chinese. Everything was good, but few were exceptional and I would probably ordered it again. (shrimp dumpling, oxtail fried rice, crab soup dumpling, fried softshell crab, crispy prawns). The other entrees are good, but is also available in other Chinese restaurants at a less premium price. Overall, the Chinese cuisine served here is very refined in flavor and presentation. It could be on par with some of top rated Chinese restaurant in the West coast/Toronto/Vancouver, however this is at a much higher price tag. For Chicago standard, this is probably one of the better or best! 

Crab soup dumpling $12 - All the XLB is 3 dumplings per order and made fresh to order. This particular XLB would be my favorite. It was very juicy and mouthful of crab. 

Gruyere pork soup dumpling $10 - Interesting combination of gruyere (FYI-it's cheese) and pork. For cheese lovers, you will enjoy this juicy dumpling. For those unfamiliar with cheese, might taste more like spoiled pork dumpling. Verdict - I ate all 3 dumplings for the table and I enjoyed it. 

Shanghai pork soup dumpling $7 - In comparison to the other XLB, this was the least favorite because the dumpling was on the drier side. BUT, the dumpling is still better and more refined in flavor than most places in Chicago that serves XLB. The dumpling was NOT completely dry, but just damp. The pork flavor was delicious. 

Spicy Szhechaun soup dumpling - I heard it's pretty spicy.. 

Shrimp dumpling (Har gow) $8 for 3 - One of my favorite! I'm not usually a fan of shrimp dumpling, but the shrimp was crispy, fresh, and very flavorful!

Beef brisket hand pulled noodle $15 - Imperial Lamian is known for the hand pulled noodle which was presented and made by the executive chef inside the open kitchen. The flavor is tasteful, but not too rich. Braised Beef brisket was tender and flavorful (the usual good beef brisket from a typical bowl of beef brisket noodle). Noodle was enjoyable. I rather spent $15 on this bowl of noodle that is made with care then a bowl of ramen. 

fried soft shell crab $16 - Loved it! The batter was light and it was flash fried soft shell crab placed atop bird's nest (taro?) with shaved almonds (seasoned/stir fried)

Wagyu Oxtail fried rice $16 - Very impressed, the fried rice was not greasy! It was flaming with flavor! Full of "wok hay". Portion size of a ~6inch stone pot. 

seared turnip with xo sauce $10 - not your typical stirfry turnip!  It was cubed and soft to bite, stirfried with scrambled eggs and scallion. Plenty and plenty of flaming "wok hay"

Roasted Duck $30 for 1/4 of a duck - a good duck with crispy skin. It reminds me of the roasted duck from the old "phoenix restaurant." It's good, but you paying for the location of where you are consuming the duck. 
 
Crispy prawn with wasabi aioli sauce atop with passion fruit and mango $23 - My favorite! It's the Refined and glamourized version of walnut shrimp. The jumbo shrimp (16-20/lb) was lightly batter and mixed with a light wasabi aioli mayo sauce. Very nice presentation!

3cup claypot chicken $20 - Tender and delicious chicken in claypot. It was okay and I think my mom would like it more than I would. Served in ~6in stone pot.
 
Wagyu Osso Buco (veal) $34 - This was our last entrée after 2 hours of seating. It's served as a shank with tender meat. It was tasteful, but we were too full to enjoy it. It was okay. 

Braised Pork Belly $23 - Good and tender served in a small tea claypot. Probably comes with 2 pieces? It was good and I didn't think it was anything special or amazing.  Comparable to most places that serves a "good tender" pork belly. 

Scallops with xo sauce $34 - compared to other entrees, this is quite a generous portion of scallop with at least 8 pieces of large scallop (don't forget that scallop shrinks in size when it's cooked). Cooked just right and not overcooked. 

jasmine rice $3 bowl - the usual white rice

egg tart $8/ 3 tarts - Good and you can get about 1.5  generous bite out of it. Served warm and flaky crust. 

Sesame ball with red bean lotus paste - Good and could also be found at most dim sum place for half the price. 

Total bill for 6 ppl - ~$400

I would come back again and would order my favorite entrée as mentioned above. Overall service was attentive, although not perfect, but they were very open to feedback. It's awesome that the 3 chefs are Asian decent which makes it more legit.

The food here is very good. I love London duck and Shanghai xiao long bao. Har gao is also fresh and delicious. The atmosphere and decoration are classy Chinese. They have opened kitchen so you can see they make fresh dumpling and noodle-that's nice. Only few cons are the portion of the food is quite small, lack of attentive service, and the lamian dishes are plain.

Imperial Lamian was all right. The restaurant was darkly lit, incredibly loud, and had weird décor. It was all right I guess. The food was decent but pricy, but they ran out the beef brisket la mian at 7:30pm on a Friday. That was disappointing.

In light of the beef la mian running out, my girlfriend and I shared the peking duck and a bowl of pork belly. The noodles were tasty but the Peking duck was expensive and slightly overcooked.

I'm not going to weigh this into my rating too much because it may have just been a non-representative bad egg but my waitress was also rather unpleasant and awkward. I ordered my beef la mian and asked for a simple substitution of including some vegetables in my dish. She was like, huh that's weird but I guess I could ask, as if hoping that I would say don't worry about it. I remember there was a long pause after that and she was like yeah I don't think we can make that substitution, because of the line handlers couldn't make the customization. I was like uhh ok, I'll just get it as is. She disappears for about 10 minutes before coming back and telling me that they had run out of beef brisket. She was unapologetic and cracked a joke saying I could order another dish so that I could get my veggies. I wasn't amused. She presented other unpleasant qualities, but I've ranted enough.

Long story short, Imperial Lamian is all right.

Love this place! The food and drinks were amazing and the service was warm and friendly.

First, the dim sum: I ordered the pumpkin puff and the mushroom, both blew my mind with the unique presentation and the taste. The clasic items, such as the siu may and the xiao long bao were also really tasty. We ordered duck, crab, and original. The xiao long bao were especially good, with juicy filling, aromatic broth, and perfect skin. VERY RECOMMENDED!

The other menu was also brilliant. The lamian noodle had great texture and the broth was very rich in flavor. We also tried the lobster fried rice and oxtail fried rice. The fried rice were a savory goodness!

The dessert made a wonderful finale for our meal. We tried the sesame ball, salted egg bao, and the egg tart. The salted egg bao was my favorite dessert with the perfect filling. 

Our meal was made complete with great cocktails. My favorite was the imperial punch, my boyfriend had the thousand mile journey. We both enjoyed them.

Our waitress was very friendly and helpful. The ambiance of the restaurant was also chic yet cozy. Overall, I recommend this restaurant!

Imperial Lamian is a great edition to River North.  Read the other reviews on Yelp came in with very low expections but i have never seen anything like this. The open kitchen is a sight to see, love the fact how everything is freshly made and not greasy like your typical chinese resturant.

The Xiao Long Bao was tasty and delicate. The skin so thin and the filling sweet and succulent. Havent seen anything like this in Chinatown.  The Lamian Dishes was great. I love how the noodles were cooked aldente and the broth was so flavourful, the waiter later informed us how the broth was cooked for over 8 hours with no msg no wonder i didnt feel leaving extremely thirsty like i normally do when I eat in Chinatown.

The only dwnside to this place is on the pricey side but i guess it being in River North, with the quality of the food, location and the ambience all in all I'll say worth every dime.  Cant wait to go back there again and try the wok dishes.

This place was the definition of mediocre. 

We had a bowl of noodles + black chia siu + two orders of soup dumpling and Jasmine tea short ribs.

Before we started, I asked the waitress if we could mix and match the bao -- I will admit the entire reason we were there was because I wanted a picture of the colorful bao. However, she did not know the answer and had to ask. This really irked me because if it's advertised as such on the website (in picture form), why wouldn't she know the answer? Even worse, the answer was no -- I would have to pick only one or two (to complete the picture would have been 60+ dollars). The bao did not come out the same as the picture, I felt like at a fast food restaurant, where the pictures are better than the food.

In terms of the rest of the food, everything was ok -- the Jasmine tea short ribs was incredibly inconsistent. The first piece we had was burnt and too crispy with no taste. However, the middle of the rack was better and made up for the bad first piece. Black chia siu was literally the same thing you could get from Chinatown but twice the price and half the size. The bowl of noodles was actually pretty good -- I would consider coming back just for a bowl of noodles. It was pricey but I've paid similar prices for ramen but the meat, noodles and broth were all quite good.

Overall, I would not suggest the restaurant in the future to my friends that are obsessed with Asian food like I am. You can go to Chicago's Chinatown and get similar tasting food for 1/3 of the price. I would admit that the service was better and it felt cleaner than some of the grittier restaurants in Chinatown but alas, I do not recommend paying that price for mediocrity.

This place just gets better and better. The service is great, food comes quick and flavors are so authentic. No MSG flavors, all full and natural. 
Recommended: spicy soup dumplings, seafood fried rice, salty dumplings for dessert and of course ANY of the Lamian. 

For a restaurant of this quality and location I was surprised how reasonable it was. It's so worth it.  Thanks to Arielle the always smiling server who recommended the place!

The food and service is very good.  I'll have to go back, because there are too many dumplings to try.  I love that you can watch the chefs pull noodles in the kitchen.  I had the duck xiao long bao soup dumplings, and these were my favorite.  So good and savory.  I tried the mushroom dumpling, and I thought it was decent, and the har gao shrimp dumpling, which I wasn't very fond of.  It had a very overpowering seafood flavor and lot of texture going on.  I guess I was expecting something more delicate.  I tried the beef brisket la mian, too.  It was very flavorful and delicious.

We went to imperial lamian on Saturday 2/27.  We were informed that they were only in a soft opening but we had a great experience.  The server also noted that the full menu was not available but we were very happy with what was available

The lantern cocktail was top notch

We ordered dim sum x3, fried rice bowl, duck, beans, and a soup bowl that is escaping my memory and everything was fantastic

We can't wait to go back and try it again!

There are fewer vegetarian options here than I expected but the ones we had were delicious. We really liked the crispy pickles, the mushroom dim sum and the hand pulled noodles in broth. Skip the boring spring rolls, which had a weird burnt flavor. The place is nicely designed but I can imagine it getting really noisy. The waitress was extremely friendly and was knowledgable about the vegetarian options.

The noodle was nicely made, prepared and served. We ordered the wonton noodles with pork, fried lamein and crispy shrimp.  The noodles in soup was the best. The broth was nice and complimented the fresh noodles nicely. The fresh noodles had nice texture. 
Ask for a table near the noodle pulling station. It's dinner and a show.
We stayed away rom the soup dumplings. They looked over priced and didn't look so authentic. After growing up with Joe's Shanghai and having soup dumpling at Ding Tai Fung, we shy away from multicolored dumpling which the skin looks a little too thick. 
They pride in serving Shanghainese dishes, but I only saw lamein, soup dumplings and braised pork. 
The crispy shrimp had an interesting twist. The mayo was wasabi flavored. Aside from the mayo sauce, the shrimp would have been well done with a little crispy exterior. I don't think they were prawns, more like jumbo shrimp. 

All in all, it was nice experience; the wait staff was nice and the noodles were great. (You can get the same stuff for less than 1/3 the price in NY's Chinatown.

Aside from the shoddy service I had most recently (this was the second time I'd eaten there in about 3 months) I think this place is great! It's lively, with good ambiance and a visual into the kitchen where you can hear them smacking noodle dough onto the counter. 

I've had the pumpkin puff and jasmine tea ribs, both of which are probably among my favorites and very popular here. I've never had the noodle dishes but that's more a personal thing - I'm positive they're as delicious as everything else. Go in a group; a group that's hungry. Aside from smaller dimsum that you can order and try many of, the potions on the entree type dishes are relatively generous so you would have lots to try.  The front of the house team seemed knowledgable and friendly, capable of gauging what you have and if it's enough for your table or if your table will collapse from too many dishes. 

Important to remember - they tell you that everything you order will come out when it's done, not when you're ready or when you think it should come because it's dim sum, not a noodle dish, for example...so plan accordingly. It's not a gesture meant to make you feel rushed, but it makes for a fun time trying to find room to put everything on your tiny table.

Food was pretty good, service was meh. 
Atmosphere: The space looks cool when you walk in, but it has a lot to be desired as a fun place to get together. It's cavernous and loud, and not entirely comfortable. We were seated at a two-top next to the waiter's station in the middle of the dining room, and it's a space that definitely shouldn't be a table. I kept getting bumped by waiters.

Food: The noodles were incredible, though! The hand stretch them in an open kitchen. The broth I had was tasty. The Xiao Long Bao have a gimmicky dyed dough situation, but it was fun to see them when they finally came out (more on that later). I've had better soup dumplings for half the price, though. The lamian are the star of the show. We also had a couple of vegetable starters. Nothing special, but nothing gross either. 

Service: Man, was the service a real detractor. Our waiter was smug and acted like I didn't know anything about Asian food, but dude was the white guy in the equation. I'm cool if you want to explain the menu to me, but the muttering during my dinner choices was a passive aggressive child's move. Plus, he chastised me for ordering the combination xiao long bao because it was a combo (duh); I guess he was so busy tut-tutting my decision that he completely forgot to put in my order, because he brought us the bill before we got them. I had to remind him. To his credit, he comped us, though. Our waiter was also kind of gross- unkempt and dirty in a stained uniform, but not in a cool way. Just unhygienic. I'm glad the super friendly girl shadowing him brought us our food. 

Overall, go for the noodles if you happen to be in River North, but don't expect great service. Better yet, just hike it down to Chinatown for the real deal. I mean, if I'm gonna get brisk and borderline rude treatment, it may as well come with a discount and and authenticity upgrade. Or, if you're in for a more Westernized experience, hit up Duck Duck Goat. It's way cooler, has a much better bar list, they also make their own noodles, the service is friendlier and the space is 100% cooler.
Nope. Glorified Chinese food. Three dollar signs and upscale for sure.

Great food, horrible service. We had reservations for four on Saturday at 8 and they ran out of ingredients for multiple menu items. Umm what? How does a restaurant "run out" of ingredients on probably your biggest night during high time? They didn't have spring rolls, a few other appetizers, and they even ran out of ginger beer for my amaro mule haha. 

The food we did order was good though, the mushroom dim sum and clay pot chicken were solid. Waitress was horrendous, slow service and had to remind her twice about drink orders.  I guess this is what you would expect from a new, posh river north restaurant. Probably won't come back.

Excellent service!  Our hostess America was supercharged w personality (and the  cutest ever). Our server Monica was absolute tops at her job, attentiveness, knowledge of all menu items, and recommendations. The kitchen executed their orders like masterful clockwork. Amazing duck/butternut quash dumplings, crispy fried duck w citrus glaze, wagyu ox-tail noodle in marrow broth, shrimp fried rice, coconut ice cream.  They're doing everything right here.

Good was decent but service wasn't good. We sat outside and they brought my meal first, 10 minutes later, our appetizer, then 10 minutes later my girlfriends meal. I know this might sound picky but who wants to eat their meal without the other people having their food? 

This is restaurant 101.
Big fan of this restaurant. Much needed genre in this area of Chicago. Nice ambience and the food was very good.

Went there for brunch on a weekend. It wasn't crowded at all. The decor of the restaurant was stylish, modern, and pleasant. The food was delicious but overpriced.

The traditional Shanghai soup dumplings (xiao long bao) were probably the best I've ever had, and you can taste a difference in quality compared to the cheaper soup dumplings in Chinatown. We also ordered the Char Siu & Wonton La Main, a pork bun, the Spicy Szechuan Xiao Long Bao, and a couple other dishes. These were good but not amazing. Overall the difference in quality isn't enough to offset the very high prices. I would go back for the delicious Shanghai soup dumplings but nothing else.

YELPERS GOT IT WRONG! 


For the love of God, I read some of these reviews and I can't help but laugh at the level of pickiness and whining. This is a NEW restaurant, yes they will have some hiccups here and there so you have to take that into consideration. (I personally didn't experience any)

Although my Yelp profile doesn't show it, I'm the HUGE Chicago foodie, I can tell that I've tried them all from best to worst. Here's what I think of this place:

Food: Downtown Chicago was missing a gourmet Chinese restaurant. The level of detail involved in creating some of this food is amazing! Trust me, if you like any type of Asian food, you'll love this place. 

Prices: I saw so many complain about the prices, the reality is that you're at busy downtown Chicago area, so if you want to dine on a dime I suggest a restaurant outside of river north. The menu has prices on it, so if you see that it's too expensive don't order. The last time I went there I was with 3 other people, we ordered A LOT of food and we each had a drink, total was $210.. I think that's a deal for the meal we had!

Service: very friendly and extremely professional. 

Overall this place is awesome ! If you want good food, good service and a fun atmosphere.  Go here and I promise that you won't regret it!

Dim sum for dinner! Loved the ambiance. Not your typical kitschy Asian decor, industrial and open. Surprisingly not loud either for a very busy Saturday night. Although the food was a bit pricey, it was well worth it as it was all excellent. Service was superb as well.

--hot & sour soup; spicy and unique--mustard greens(?)
--jasmine spare ribs are a MUST. So tender, it fell right off the bone.
--baked pork bao was delicious; it was the bun that made it
--Xiang Gu mushroom filled dumpling was a terrific surprise in a translucent noodle; have never had this before and loved it
--the sioa mei was not unique, but was nonetheless delicious
--Terrific wine selection. Had a bottle of a New Zealand Sauvignon Blanc that was a delight
--coconut sorbet with pineapple cake for dessert was perfect portion to share
--after dinner we had French 75 cocktails; they were made perfectly, although I would have preferred to have also had the lemon rind as well

My dining companion and I both agreed that we would definitely go there again.

Great great great authentic Chinese food ..I love the craft cocktails ... The bar manager Patrick jumped behind the bar as we sat and introduced us to some amazing drinks that coincide with saké ... I have brought friends there for the different atmosphere and amazing ribs .... Yes the ribs are the best ever .. But make sure you get one of their craft cocktails they are an experience for your taste buds all by itself

The service at Imperial Lamian was great, we had two waiters! One of which literally explained everything on the menu to my friend and I. However, the quality of the food we ordered was just average. My friend and I split the Bom Bom salad, Kung Pao chicken, and Salmon. The quality of the chicken was really poor as the chicken was extremely fatty. That was disappointing considering this a more upscale chinese food restaurant. Overall I think this place is over rated.

My wife took me here for my birthday this evening.  The service was excellent and the food was decent.  It was a little pricy for the portions but it was still good.  We had the Pork Belly Bao, stuffed wings to start and ordered the Shanghai,  Szechuan, and Truffle soup dumplings, pork pot stickers, mushroom dumplings, pork shrimp dumplings, shrimp In passion fruit sauce, pepper steak, and brisket noodles.  The brisket noodles and pepper steak were our favorites.

I'd rate this at 3.75/5 if I could.  We started with the pumpkin duck dish which I thought was good but not great.  We followed this up with the Shanghai and Szechuan XLB, beef brisket noodles, and hot garlic chicken and all were wonderful.  If rating this just for food alone I'd give our meal a 4-4.5/5, but the service left a lot to be desired.  Although friendly, it seems they haven't quite worked out the kinks and there were some mix ups where food was delivered to the wrong table, etc.  Great decor, great take on Chinese cuisine, and good drink selection, but the service needs to improve.  I'm confident the service issues we experienced were due to them being new and dining on a Friday night, but I hope they get this figured out quickly!

This restaurant is another addition the increasingly more saturated upscale Chinese restaurants in Chicago, but I must say it is my favorite (in comparison to Duck Duck Goat and Shanghai Terrace). The dumpling are extremely juicy, albeit a little overpriced, the cocktails are expertly made, and the lobster fried rice was absolutely delicious. Also, service was attentive and great. 

I would definitely recommend to anyone who doesn't mind dropping some cash on extremely high quality authentic Chinese food.
Service was really good and they were very flexible in accomodating my dad who was in a wheelchair. We really enjoyed the soup dumplings and hand pulled noodles.

Service was awesome. Xiaolongbao even better than in shanghai. Dish were awesome. And the desert was like an alinea thing. Def. One of my favorite restaurant in chicago

Edit: went there again. Tried the bar and drinks were OK. Could have been better :) xiaolongbao are always awesome and I think I'll just keep ordering them everytime I go. Tried some other dishes and everything was awesome again

Can't believe the rating on this place is so low!!! Is phenomenal Chinese food! I would
Highly recommend the spicy XLB dumplings and garlic chicken

One of my favorite bars in Chicago, if not my #1. Perfect for a girls night out to dance, date night, casual cocktails, group of friends... Henry's has something for everyone!

The upstairs has amazing cocktails, small bites, a dimly lit bar area with plenty of bar seats and tables, and a pool table. Killing Floor is perhaps the best cocktail ever crafted - jalapeno tequila, watermelon, and lime. Spicy, fruity, and refreshing.

Downstairs has a bangin dance floor, always a great crowd (fun but not too rowdy, crowded, or young), board games, and at midnight they have pizza or treats for the crowd stocked in an old school 1970s fridge.

They have a pool table and although the Cubs were playing in he World Series the place was not overly crowded. There were still open seats at the bar. 
Staff is pretty friendly. I ordered a Pinot noir they said they only had one kind. It was decent.
Ordered the crispy cod taco and the mushroom taco. They were really nothing special. I was still hungry so got the cheesy fries and those were ok.
I wouldn't recommend the food here. But a good place to check out a game and a grab a few drinks with friends.

Meh. I have been to Henry's before in that past for some alumni events to meet and greet, and overall Henry's is a great place to chow down on some appetizers and enjoy some drinks while networking. And I'll say that Henry's lower level Rec Room was probably one of my favorite spots in River North. BUT hard to say I'll be back after an incident that occurred Saturday evening. 

So this past Saturday, I had suggested to my friends visiting from out of town that we check out Henry's and the Rec Room. We were having a really enjoyable time here drinking and dancing, when I got trampled by this tall lanky dude with thick glasses. Stumble over me and step on me kicks once, no big deal. There was no pushing or shoving going on, but I simply put my hand out to keep him from stepping on me because he was clearly drunk as a skunk bumping into folks left and right. Security was already in process of escorting out tall drunk lanky glasses dude AND two other guys that apparently had some sort of argument with him, and in this process since I apparently was protecting myself from having him trample over and step on me again. Security grabbed me and told me I needed to leave. What infuriated me the most was that tall drunk lanky glasses guy obviously was associated with the staff and security there at Henry's because as soon as we all got kicked out, they let him stay in. I spoke briefly with the other two guys that I got kicked out with (no affiliation what so ever) but just trying to get more info on why they were kicked out. And as it turns out, tall lanky drunk glasses guy stumbled all over them too. They were definitely more heated about it, but I was more upset I got booted from my friends. I tried to talk to security while outside to find out who tall drunk lanky glasses guy was, but they kept a vow of silence and told me to get lost.

What was an excellent night, ended up turning sour for me. I had tried calling management to discuss the situation, yet they were being rude about it. It was a good run Henry's, but probably won't be back anytime soon. 'Til next time.

Came on a special 2.10 night where everything was $2.10. I made it rain $ for sliders.

I had the tomato and cheese, pbj, tuna salad, and sirracha mayo oyster. Oyster and tuna were the bombbombbomb. I probably had like 50 sliders that night. 

The space is awesome. Very wicker park without being in Wicker Park. There's pool tables, art, couches and lots of drinks with dim lighting that makes everyone look good. Service was wonderful. They handled our crazy food orders and bills without any drama. What more can you ask for in a place?

I would go back as I see they've got a happy hour deal. I'll make it rain for sliders any day.

Came for pre dinner drinks. Happy hour menu price for the beverages are very reasonable. 
Tried a couple of sliders and they were all good. The menu is quite limited though and I suggest going elsewhere for dinner.

Keep your receipts. My tab was closed out by the GM and he added the tip and I am guessing forged a signature, since he won't provide the original copy. It wasn't for a large amount but his attitude towards my inquiry tells me it happened more than once.

Randomly picked this place to meet for Cinco de Mayo happy hour with a new friend.  It's a pretty cool and casual spot in River North with a decent sized bar.  We ended up sitting at the bar and couldn't stop laughing because they had some 70s porno playing on the TVs. I thought all their drinks were pretty strong, including the sangria.  They have a pretty good happy hour deal, house cocktails for the price of the hour it currently is.   My friend and I also split their merk's cheddar fries and we each has a few sliders.  I had the plain burger ones and was kinda disappointed since this is a DMK bar and DMK burger is excellent so i was expecting something better I guess.  I do like that their menu is all small bar bites though and I would definately come back.

One of our go to spots in River North. They play some of the best music. Can't beat 90's right? It varies to hip hop, pop, rock, alternative, the music great from all eras. 

The Hubbard area can be known for pricey drinks and pricey food. But this place doesn't come close to both. Drinks are affordable, food is great. The problem with the drinks being affordable is that I always end up ordering to many shots and drinks and it does not suit me well the morning after. It's probably the most laid back chill spot on Hubbard. You don't have to worry about the River North reputation here, snobby, stuck up, etc. It's great!
Prebottled alcoholic drinks were too sweet and kind of mediocre but the classic sliders were really good!

I would give Henry's a 4.5!
